Okay, here we go. This is… the big one, isn’t it? Everyone wants to know about *this*.

It wasn’t one single moment, you know? It wasn’t like I woke up one morning and suddenly decided, “Yep, adoption is the way to go!” It was a process. A really long, messy, emotionally draining process.

First, there was the shock. Finding out I was pregnant was… a lot. I was sixteen! I hadn’t even thought about having a baby, or a future beyond high school. It felt like my whole life was suddenly derailed.

Then there was the fear. Fear of telling my dad, fear of what my friends would think, fear of not being able to handle it. Fear of ruining my life.

And then there was the reality. I started thinking about what it would actually *mean* to raise a baby. The financial burden, the emotional toll, the sacrifices I’d have to make. I wasn’t ready for that. I wasn’t prepared to give up my dreams, my education, my independence.

I talked to my dad, and Bren. They were amazing. They didn’t judge me, they just listened. And they helped me to explore my options. Abortion was… not something I could do. It just didn’t feel right. And keeping the baby… well, that felt even more terrifying.

Adoption felt like the best of both worlds. It allowed me to give the baby a good life, with parents who were ready and able to provide for them. And it allowed me to finish school and pursue my own dreams.

It wasn’t an easy decision. It was the hardest decision I’ve ever had to make. But I knew, deep down, that it was the right one. For everyone involved.

I wanted the baby to have a life filled with love and opportunity. A life I couldn’t give them right now. And I wanted to be able to look myself in the mirror and know that I did the best I could, even when it was the hardest thing in the world.

It still hurts, you know? It always will. But I’m trying to focus on the positive. I’m trying to believe that I’m doing something good. And I’m trying to trust that everything will be okay.

It’s not a fairytale ending, but it’s my story. And I’m trying to own it.

Ugh, okay. Deep thoughts time. Don't expect poetry, alright? Just… honesty.

Love… that's a tricky one. Before all this, I thought love was just… what you saw in movies. Dramatic declarations, grand gestures, happily ever afters. Turns out, it's a lot messier than that. It's not always about romance, or even *liking* someone all the time. It's about caring for someone, even when it's hard.

I learned that from Bren, mostly. She loves my dad, and she loves me, not because we're perfect, but because we're *us*. She shows it in small ways – making dinner, listening to my rants, just being there. It's not flashy, but it's real. And it's powerful.

And then there's Mark and Vanessa. They're going to love this baby, and that's… a relief. It's not the love *I* would have given, but it's a good love. A stable love. A love that can provide a better life than I can right now. And realizing that, accepting that, that took a lot of courage.

Responsibility… that was a harder lesson. I always thought responsibility was about following the rules, doing what you're told. But it's more than that. It's about owning your choices, even the bad ones. It's about facing the consequences, and doing what's best for everyone involved, even if it's not what *you* want.

I messed up, obviously. Getting pregnant was a mistake. But I couldn't just pretend it didn't happen. I had to take responsibility for my actions, and make a plan. And that meant giving up the baby. It was the hardest decision I've ever made, but it was the right one.

I learned that responsibility isn't about being perfect. It's about being brave enough to do what needs to be done, even when it's scary and painful. It's about growing up, and accepting that life isn't always fair.

So, yeah. Love and responsibility. They're not always easy, and they're definitely not always what you expect. But they're important. And I think, maybe, I'm starting to understand that. A little bit, anyway. Don't tell anyone I said that, though. I have a reputation to maintain.

Oh, man. Okay, that's a good question. A *really* good question. Because honestly? Sarcasm was my survival mechanism. Like, if I didn't make a joke about it, I would have probably just… imploded.

Look, finding out you're pregnant at sixteen is not exactly a laugh riot. It's terrifying, and confusing, and overwhelming. And everyone has an opinion, and everyone's looking at you, and it just feels like the whole world is judging you.

So, I started using humor as a shield. If someone said something stupid, I'd just fire off a sarcastic comeback. It was a way to deflect attention, to keep people at arm's length, and to maintain some semblance of control.

It wasn't about being mean, exactly. It was about… processing things. Like, if I could make a joke about my expanding waistline, it didn't feel quite as scary. If I could poke fun at the awkwardness of the situation, it didn't feel quite as overwhelming.

And it helped me connect with people, too. Like, Bren, my stepmom, she gets my humor. She can dish it right back, and it makes me feel like she understands me. And even Mark and Vanessa, the couple adopting the baby, they appreciated my sarcasm. It showed them that I wasn't just some helpless victim, that I had a personality and a sense of humor.

It wasn't always easy, though. Sometimes I felt like I was using humor to avoid dealing with my feelings. Like I was hiding behind a wall of sarcasm. But ultimately, it helped me to cope. It helped me to stay sane. It helped me to get through it.

Because sometimes, the only way to deal with something awful is to laugh at it. Even if it's a slightly hysterical, slightly desperate laugh. And honestly? I'm pretty good at those.

Ugh, okay, now you're getting all deep on me. Fine. But don't expect a neatly packaged answer. Life isn't neatly packaged, and neither was this whole… situation.

Before everything happened with the pregnancy, I thought I had it all figured out. I was sarcastic, independent, a little bit cynical. I had my music, my vintage clothes, my carefully constructed persona. I thought that *was* me.

But then I got pregnant, and suddenly everything fell apart. All my carefully constructed walls came crashing down. I was scared, confused, and completely overwhelmed. And I realized that the "me" I thought I knew was just a facade. A way to protect myself from getting hurt.

Being pregnant forced me to confront my own vulnerability. I had to admit that I didn't have all the answers, that I needed help, that I was terrified. It was… humiliating. But it was also liberating.

And that's when the search for identity really began. I started questioning everything. Who was I? What did I want? What did I believe in? I realized that I didn't want to be defined by my circumstances. I didn't want to be just "the pregnant teenager." I wanted to be… Juno. A complex, flawed, but ultimately hopeful human being.

It wasn't easy. There were a lot of tears, a lot of self-doubt, and a lot of awkward conversations. But I learned a lot about myself along the way. I learned that it's okay to be vulnerable, that it's okay to ask for help, and that it's okay to not have all the answers.

And I learned that my identity isn't something I *find*, it's something I *create*. It's a work in progress, constantly evolving and changing. And that's okay.

Giving the baby up for adoption was a huge part of that journey. It wasn't about giving up on the baby, it was about making the best decision for everyone involved. And it was about taking responsibility for my actions and choosing my own path.

So yeah. My vulnerability and my search for identity shaped my journey in a big way. They forced me to grow up, to confront my fears, and to become a stronger, more authentic version of myself. And honestly? I wouldn't trade it for anything. Even though it was really, *really* hard.

Ugh, okay, don't make me get all sappy. But fine. You asked.

It wasn't just one person, it was all of them. They created this… safety net around me. They reminded me that I wasn't alone, that I was loved, and that I was strong enough to make a difficult decision.

I think I always thought I had to be independent, to handle everything on my own. But I learned that it's okay to ask for help. It's okay to lean on others. And it's okay to admit that you're scared.

Their support didn't make the decision easy, but it made it possible. It gave me the strength to do what I knew was right, even when it was the hardest thing I've ever had to do. And I'll be forever grateful for that. Seriously. Don't tell anyone I said that, though. It'll ruin my reputation.

Ugh. Okay. That's… that's a loaded question. It wasn't like in the movies, you know? No dramatic music, no slow-motion montage. It was just… a positive pregnancy test. Sitting on the bathroom floor. Staring at two pink lines.

My first thought wasn't, like, "Oh my god, a baby!" It was more like, "Oh my god, my life is officially over." I was sixteen! I was supposed to be worrying about college applications and prom dresses, not diapers and doctor's appointments.

I felt… panicked. Terrified. Completely and utterly overwhelmed. I didn't know what to do, who to tell, or how to even begin to deal with it. I just sat there for a long time, staring at that test, trying to process what was happening.

Then I started to feel angry. Angry at myself, for being so careless. Angry at Paul, for… well, for being Paul. And angry at the universe, for throwing this huge curveball my way.

I didn't tell anyone right away. I just kept it to myself, trying to figure things out. I did a lot of research online, which was a terrible idea. All I found were scary articles and judgmental opinions.

It wasn't until I finally told Bren that I started to feel a little bit better. She didn't freak out, or yell at me, or anything like that. She just listened. And she told me that we would figure it out together.

Even now, it's hard to talk about. It's still a really raw and emotional topic. But it's also… a part of me. It's shaped who I am, and it's forced me to grow up in ways I never expected.

It wasn't a happy moment, not at first. But it was a turning point. And sometimes, even the worst things can lead to something good. Or at least, something… manageable. It's still a lot, though. A *lot*.

Ugh. Okay, that's… a loaded question. It wasn't exactly a walk in the park, let me tell you. It kinda blew everything up, honestly.

With my dad, Mac, it was… awkward at first. He was definitely surprised. And worried. But he's my dad, so he was supportive, in his own quiet way. Bren, my stepmom, was a lifesaver. Seriously. She was the one I talked to the most. She didn't judge me, she just listened. And she helped me figure things out. She's the best. I don't know what I would have done without her.

It also made me appreciate the people who *did* stick by me. My dad, Bren, even Paulie Bleeker, in his own weird way. They showed me that I wasn't alone. And that even when things are falling apart, there's still hope.

It was a really tough time, but it also taught me a lot about myself, and about the people in my life. And that's something I'll carry with me, even after the baby's born. It's just… it still stings, you know? Losing Leah. That's the hardest part of all of this.

Ugh. Okay, that's… a big question. And honestly? It wasn't pretty. There were a lot of days where I just wanted to curl up in a ball and disappear. It felt like my whole life was falling apart, and I didn't know what to do.

At first, I just tried to pretend it wasn't happening. I kept going to school, hanging out with Leah (before things got weird), and trying to act normal. But it was exhausting. And it didn't work. The truth kept creeping up on me, no matter how hard I tried to ignore it.

Then I started getting really angry. Angry at myself, angry at the situation, angry at the world. I lashed out at people, I said things I didn't mean, and I just generally made everyone's life miserable. Which, looking back, I feel really bad about.

But eventually, I realized that anger wasn't helping. It was just making things worse. So I started talking. First to Bren, then to my dad, and eventually to a counselor. It was really hard to open up, to admit how scared and confused I was. But it was also… liberating.

Bren was a lifesaver. She didn't judge me, she just listened. And she helped me to see that I had options. That I wasn't trapped. And my dad, he was surprisingly supportive. He wasn't thrilled, obviously, but he loved me unconditionally.

The counselor helped me to process my emotions and to develop coping mechanisms. She taught me how to practice mindfulness, and how to challenge my negative thoughts. It wasn't a quick fix, but it helped.

And honestly? Music helped a lot. Listening to my favorite songs, writing my own songs… it was a way to express my feelings when I couldn't find the words.

It was a really tough time, and I'm still dealing with the emotional fallout. But I'm learning to be kinder to myself. To accept that it's okay to feel sad, or scared, or angry. And to remember that I'm not alone. It's still… a lot. But I'm getting through it. One day at a time. And with a lot of help from the people who love me.

Ugh, okay, here we go. This is… a sensitive topic. And honestly, it's not something I like talking about. But you asked.

It wasn't about *choosing* an abortion, okay? It was about choosing… the least awful option. And Havenbrooke… Havenbrooke just felt *wrong*.

I went for a consultation there, and it was… sterile. Cold. They treated me like a number, not a person. They were all about the procedure, and not about *me*. They didn't ask how I was feeling, or what I was thinking. They just wanted to get me in and get me out.

And the protesters. Oh god, the protesters. They were outside, yelling and holding signs. It was terrifying. It made me feel ashamed and guilty, like I was doing something wrong. Which I wasn't.

Then I found out about Women Now. It was different. It was… warm. The people there were kind and compassionate. They actually listened to me. They asked me about my life, my feelings, my hopes and fears. They didn't judge me. They just supported me.

They explained all my options, and they made sure I was making the right decision for *me*. They even had a counselor who I talked to for hours. She helped me sort through my feelings and come to terms with my decision.

Women Now felt… safe. It felt like a place where I could be honest and vulnerable. It felt like a place where I was treated like a human being, not a statistic.

So, yeah. I chose Women Now because they treated me with respect and dignity. They didn't try to shame me or guilt me. They just helped me make the best decision for my life. And honestly, that's all I could ask for.

It wasn't an easy decision, and it wasn't a happy one. But Women Now made it a little bit easier. And for that, I'll always be grateful.

I'm not trying to make excuses for myself. I should have been more responsible. I should have thought things through. But I didn't. And now I'm dealing with the fallout.

It's not something I'm proud of. It's not something I enjoy talking about. But it's the truth. And I guess I have to own up to my mistakes, even the really embarrassing ones.

(Sighs dramatically, rolling eyes) Oh. *Bleeker*. Okay, look. Don't get me wrong, he's… a good kid. A really good kid. Sweet, earnest, genuinely kind. Like a golden retriever in human form.

But… it's complicated.

When we first started hanging out, it was just… easy. He didn't try to be cool or impress me. He just *was*. And he listened. He actually listened to what I had to say, which is a rare quality in a teenage boy.

And he was there for me, you know? When I found out I was pregnant, he didn't freak out or run away. He was scared, yeah, but he stuck around. He tried to be supportive, even though he was completely clueless about what to do.

Okay, look. This is the question, isn't it? The one everyone wants to ask. And it's not a simple answer, alright? It's not like I just woke up one morning and decided, "Oh, adoption sounds convenient!"

It was… a process. A lot of thinking. A lot of crying. A lot of talking to Bren, and my dad, and even a counselor.

The biggest thing was, I just wasn't ready. I'm sixteen. I'm still figuring out who *I* am, let alone being responsible for another human being. I'm not financially stable, I'm still in school, and honestly, I'm not emotionally ready to be a mom.

I wanted my baby to have the best possible life. A life filled with stability, and love, and opportunities. And I knew I couldn't provide that right now. It wouldn't be fair to the baby.

And it wasn't just about me. It was about the baby, too. They deserve parents who are prepared and excited and ready to give them everything they need.

When I met Mark and Vanessa, I knew they were the right people. They're a loving couple who have been trying to start a family for a long time. They were so excited about the prospect of adopting, and they promised to give the baby a wonderful life.

It was still a really hard decision. It's still hard. I'm giving up a part of myself, and that's scary. But I know it's the right thing to do. It's the most selfless thing I've ever done.

It doesn't mean I don't care about the baby. It means I care enough to want them to have a better life than I can give them right now. And that's… that's enough for me.

It's not a happy ending, exactly. But it's a good one. And I'm trying to focus on that. It's about making the best of a difficult situation, and doing what's right, even when it hurts. And honestly? That's a pretty good lesson to learn, even at sixteen.

Ugh. Don't even *remind* me. That was… not a high point.

Okay, so, Bleeker. Sweet, clueless Bleeker. He's a good guy, don't get me wrong. Just… not exactly the sharpest tool in the shed. And definitely not prepared for a conversation about unplanned pregnancy.

I'd been putting it off for days. Like, actively avoiding him. Because I knew it wasn't going to be pretty. But I couldn't keep it a secret forever. He deserved to know.

Then he started stammering, trying to form a sentence, but it just came out as a bunch of incoherent noises. He kept saying "Whoa" and "Seriously?" and "But… but…" It was like watching a robot malfunction.

He wasn't angry, or anything. He was just… completely overwhelmed. He didn't know what to say, what to do, or how to react. Which, honestly, was kind of insulting. Like, I was expecting at least *some* kind of emotional response.

He eventually mumbled something about needing to "process" and then practically ran away. It was… not the supportive reaction I was hoping for.

Look, I knew Bleeker wasn't exactly father material. He's still figuring out how to tie his shoes, let alone raise a baby. But I still wanted him to be… I don't know… understanding? Compassionate? Something other than a deer in headlights.

It just confirmed what I already knew: I was on my own. And that was… scary. But also, in a weird way, empowering. I had to figure this out myself. And I would. Even if it meant doing it without Bleeker's help.

So yeah. Telling Bleeker was… not fun. It was awkward, uncomfortable, and ultimately, disappointing. But it was also a necessary step. And it helped me to realize that I was stronger than I thought. Even if I was also a little bit heartbroken.

So, yeah. That's how I feel. Scared, sad, hopeful, and completely overwhelmed. All at the same time. It's a lot. It's a *lot*.

Ugh. Bleeker. Don't even get me started.

I think we'll always be friends, maybe. But the romantic part? That's probably over. And honestly, that's okay. I need someone who can be more than just a sweet, awkward guitar player. So yeah. I think we'll drift apart. And that's probably for the best. It doesn't mean I don't care about him, it just means we're not meant to be together. And that's okay. It really is. Even if it kinda sucks.

Ugh. Okay, this is the part I was dreading. The "let's talk about the elephant in the room" part.

It's… not great. Honestly. It's a lot of whispering, and staring, and awkward silences. And the judgment? Oh, the judgment. It's like everyone suddenly has an opinion on my life, and none of them are particularly kind.

At first, I tried to ignore it. Just pretend it wasn't happening. But that doesn't really work when people are actively avoiding you in the hallways or making snide comments behind your back.

Then I tried being sarcastic. You know, deflect with humor. "Oh, yeah, I'm just growing a human. No big deal." But that just made me sound defensive, and it didn't really stop the judgment.

What's actually helped the most is… Bren. She told me that people are always going to judge, no matter what you do. It's just human nature. And that the only opinion that really matters is my own.

And she's right. I know I made the right decision for me and for the baby. And I don't need anyone else's approval to validate that.

I also started hanging out with people who actually *support* me. My dad, obviously. And a few of my friends who didn't ditch me when things got tough. It's nice to be around people who see me as a person, not just as "the pregnant girl."

I've also realized that a lot of the judgment comes from ignorance. People don't understand what I'm going through, so they just assume the worst. And that's their problem, not mine.

So, yeah. It's hard. But I'm getting through it. One sarcastic comment, one supportive friend, and one deep breath at a time. And honestly? It's making me stronger. I'm learning to stand up for myself, and to not let anyone else define me. And that's a pretty valuable lesson, even if it came at a really inconvenient time.

Okay. This is… the big one, right? It's not something I talk about easily, even with Bren. It's still raw, you know?

There are days when I feel really confident in my decision. Like, I'm doing the best thing for the baby, and for myself. I'm giving the baby a chance at a life I can't provide right now. And I'm allowing myself to pursue my own dreams.

But I also know that I'm strong. And I'm resilient. And I'm making a brave choice. It's not the choice I would have made if things were different, but it's the choice I'm making now. And I have to believe that it's the right one.

And honestly? It's okay to be sad. It's okay to grieve. It doesn't mean I regret my decision. It just means I'm human. And I'm trying to do the best I can, under really difficult circumstances. That's all anyone can ask for, right?

Then I found out I was pregnant, and suddenly… none of that felt true anymore. It was like my whole identity had been shattered into a million pieces. I wasn't just Juno anymore. I was "Juno, the pregnant teenager." And that label felt… suffocating.

But I didn't *feel* strong. I felt scared and confused and overwhelmed. I was forced to confront things that I wasn't ready to confront. Responsibility, adulthood, the future… it all came crashing down on me at once.

I had to grow up, and I had to grow up fast. I had to learn to make difficult decisions, to prioritize other people's needs, and to accept that life doesn't always go according to plan.

It's been… a painful process. I've lost friends, I've questioned my beliefs, and I've had to redefine who I am. But I think, in a weird way, it's also been a good thing.

It's forced me to look inward, to figure out what really matters to me. And I've realized that my identity isn't just about my hobbies or my interests. It's about my values, my beliefs, and my ability to make tough choices.

I'm still Juno, the sarcastic, independent, music-obsessed, vintage-loving girl. But I'm also something more. I'm a survivor. I'm a decision-maker. I'm a young woman who's learning to navigate a complicated world. And I'm okay with that.

It's not the life I expected, but it's my life. And I'm going to make the most of it. Even if it means facing a few more existential crises along the way.

Oh. *Oh*. Okay, that's a loaded question. Let's just say my role as a lab partner is… unique.

I'm not exactly the most meticulous scientist, alright? I'm more of a "big picture" kind of person. Details? Not my forte. I'm good at coming up with ideas, and I'm not afraid to experiment. But following instructions to the letter? That's where things get tricky.

Usually, I end up being the one who asks all the questions. Like, *why* are we doing this? What's the point? And what if we tried it this way instead? Which, admittedly, doesn't always go over well with the teacher.

My lab partners usually fall into one of two categories: the overachievers who are horrified by my lack of precision, or the equally chaotic students who are just happy to have someone to mess around with. 

I'm pretty good at explaining things, though. I can break down complex concepts into simpler terms. And I'm always willing to help, even if my help involves accidentally setting something on fire. (Okay, that only happened once. Maybe twice.)

Honestly, I think I'm the "creative problem solver" of the group. When things go wrong – which they inevitably do – I'm the one who comes up with a solution. Even if that solution is completely unorthodox and probably violates several safety regulations.

So, yeah. I'm not the ideal lab partner. But I'm definitely… memorable. And I guarantee you'll never be bored when you're working with me. Just… try to keep the flammable materials away from me, okay? For everyone's sake.

Ugh. Don't even *mention* that ad. It's been stuck in my head for days. That… pastel pink and flowery nonsense? Seriously? Like trying to make a really difficult decision look like a spa day. It's insulting.

"Compassionate care." "Confidential services." "You have options." Yeah, I *know* I have options. I'm not an idiot. And I don't need a bunch of saccharine sweetness to tell me that.

It just felt… disingenuous. Like they were trying to sell me something. And they were. They were selling a solution, but not a real one. Not one that acknowledged the messiness and the pain and the *complexity* of the situation.

I mean, I get it. They're a business. They need to attract clients. But couldn't they at least be a little bit… honest? A little bit real?

It made me feel even more confused and overwhelmed, honestly. Like I was being pressured to make a decision, and that my feelings didn't matter. 

Bren said it's just marketing, and that I shouldn't read too much into it. But it's hard not to. It's hard to ignore the feeling that someone is trying to manipulate you.

I ended up crumpling up the newspaper and throwing it away. I didn't need that kind of negativity in my life. I needed to figure things out on my own terms, and I wasn't going to let a cheesy ad tell me what to do.

Honestly, it just made me want to scream. And maybe eat a whole pint of ice cream. Which, coincidentally, is exactly what I did. Don't judge. It was a stressful day.

(Rolls eyes dramatically) Oh. *This*. Seriously? You're asking me about the hamburger phone? It's a classic, okay? A *classic*.

It's not like I actually *used* it to make important phone calls. It was mostly just for show. A conversation starter. A way to freak people out. And it worked, obviously. Everyone remembers the hamburger phone.

It's a symbol, I guess. Of our… weirdness. Of our connection. Of the fact that we're both a little bit out there. 

And honestly, it's a lot more interesting than a boring, generic cell phone. It has personality. It has character. It's a hamburger phone! What's not to love?

Don't judge my taste in phones, okay? I'm going through a lot right now. A hamburger phone is the least of my problems. Besides, it's iconic. You have to admit that. It's practically a work of art. A greasy, delicious work of art.

Okay. Here we go. This is… the big one, right?

It wasn't an easy decision. Not even a little bit. It was the hardest thing I've ever had to think about. And I still have moments where I question it, where I wonder "what if?" But ultimately, I knew it was the right thing to do.

I'm sixteen. Sixteen! I'm still figuring out who *I* am, let alone being responsible for another human being. I'm not ready to be a mom. I don't have a stable home, a stable job, or a stable future. I'm still in high school, and I want to finish my education and pursue my own dreams.

And it wouldn't be fair to the baby. Every kid deserves parents who are fully prepared and able to provide for them – emotionally, financially, everything. I couldn't give that to a child. Not right now.

I thought about all the things a baby needs: a safe home, a loving family, opportunities to learn and grow. And I realized that Mark and Vanessa could give the baby all of those things. They've been trying to have a baby for years, and they're so excited and ready to be parents.

It wasn't about me not wanting the baby. It was about wanting the baby to have the best possible life. And I realized that the best possible life wasn't with me.

It's not a glamorous story. It's not a heroic story. It's just a realistic story. And it took a lot of courage to admit that to myself. It's still painful, and it always will be. But I know I made the right decision. For everyone involved.

I'm giving the baby a chance at a good life. And I'm giving myself a chance to build a good life, too. And that's all I can ask for. It's not how I planned things, but sometimes life throws you curveballs. And you just have to swing for the fences and hope for the best. Even if it means letting go.

Okay, that's… a big question. A really big question. It's not like it was one single thing, you know? It was a whole bunch of stuff swirling around in my head. But my family definitely played a huge role.

My dad, Mac, he's… a good guy. A quiet guy. He wasn't thrilled when I told him I was pregnant, obviously. But he didn't yell or anything. He just looked… sad. And worried. He wanted to be supportive, but he didn't really know *how*. He's not exactly equipped to deal with teenage pregnancy.

And then there's Bren. She was the one who really helped me process everything. She didn't try to tell me what to do, she just asked me questions. Hard questions. Like, "What do *you* want?" and "What's best for the baby?" and "Are you ready for this?"

Seeing how Mac and Bren had built their life together, how they supported each other, it made me realize that a baby needs that. It needs a stable, loving environment. And I just… didn't think I could provide that right now. Not while I'm still trying to figure out who *I* am.

And then there's my mom. Or, well, the lack of a consistent mom. Growing up with someone who was always chasing their own dreams, who wasn't really there for me… it made me realize that I didn't want to repeat that pattern. I didn't want to bring a child into the world and then not be able to give them the attention and love they deserve.

It wasn't about not loving the baby. It was about loving the baby *enough* to want them to have a better life than I could give them right now. And seeing the love and stability that Mac and Bren had created, it made me realize that adoption was the right choice.

It was a hard decision, but it was the right one. And my family, in their own way, helped me to see that. They showed me what a loving family looks like, and they helped me to make a selfless decision. Even if it broke my heart a little bit.

Ugh, don't even get me started. The adoption process is… a *process*. It's not like in the movies, all heartwarming and easy. It's a lot of paperwork, a lot of meetings, and a lot of emotional stuff.

The biggest challenge, honestly, was just… the vulnerability of it all. You're basically handing over your baby to strangers. Even though Mark and Vanessa are amazing, it was still terrifying. I kept having these moments where I'd think, "What if they change their minds? What if they don't love the baby as much as I do?" Which is ridiculous, I know, but it's hard to shut off those thoughts.

There was also a lot of judgment. Not from everyone, but from some people. People who didn't understand why I was choosing adoption, or who thought I was being selfish. It was really hurtful. Like, I was already dealing with a lot, and I didn't need people adding to it.

The home study was… intense. They basically interrogated me about every aspect of my life. My family, my friends, my beliefs, my future plans. It felt like they were trying to decide if I was a "worthy" mother, which was weird, considering I was *choosing* not to be one.

And then there was the legal stuff. So. Much. Paperwork. Contracts, consents, agreements… it was overwhelming. I had to sign away my parental rights, which was… hard. Really hard. It felt like I was giving up a part of myself.

But Bren was there for me every step of the way. She helped me understand the paperwork, she went with me to the meetings, and she just listened when I needed to vent. She reminded me that I was doing the right thing, and that I was being brave.

It wasn't easy, but it was worth it. Because I knew that Mark and Vanessa were going to give the baby a wonderful life. And that's all I ever wanted. It just… took a lot of courage, and a lot of tears, to get there. And a whole lot of paperwork. Seriously, the paperwork was the worst.

Ugh. Okay. That's… the big one, isn't it? It's not like getting a bad haircut or failing a math test. This… this changed everything.

Before, I thought I knew who I was. Sarcastic, independent, a little bit cynical. I liked my music, my vintage clothes, my weird friends. I thought I was pretty solid. But then… boom. Pregnant. And suddenly, none of that felt important anymore.

It forced me to grow up, like, *fast*. I had to make decisions that no sixteen-year-old should have to make. Decisions about my body, my future, and the future of another human being. It was terrifying.

I spent a lot of time questioning everything. My values, my beliefs, my place in the world. I realized that being independent wasn't just about being able to do whatever I wanted. It was about taking responsibility for my actions. And it was about being strong enough to make difficult choices, even when they hurt.

Giving up the baby for adoption was the hardest thing I've ever done. It felt like giving up a part of myself. But it also felt… right. It was the best thing for the baby, and it was the best thing for me.

It taught me a lot about love. Not just romantic love, but the kind of love that means putting someone else's needs before your own. And it taught me a lot about loss. About letting go. About accepting that sometimes, things don't work out the way you planned.

I think it made me more empathetic, too. I used to be quick to judge people. Now I try to see things from their perspective. Everyone's fighting their own battles, you know?

I'm still figuring out who I am, honestly. But I'm not the same person I was before. I'm stronger, more resilient, and more aware of the world around me. I've learned that life is messy and unpredictable, and that sometimes, the best thing you can do is just… roll with it.

It wasn't a fairytale ending, or a happy accident. It was hard. Really hard. But it made me who I am today. And I think, in a weird way, I'm okay with that. I'm still Juno MacGuff, sarcastic and independent and a little bit cynical. But I'm also a survivor. And that's something to be proud of.

I tried to stay strong, to keep my sarcastic facade up. But inside, I was crumbling. It felt like she was looking right through me, seeing all my doubts and fears.

And the thing is, I *do* believe a baby deserves a good life. That's why I chose adoption. But hearing her say it like that… it made me feel like I was betraying that belief.

I just wanted her to go away. I wanted to disappear. I wanted everything to be simple again. But it wasn't. And it isn't.

It's still… hard to talk about. It just… stuck with me. It made me realize how complicated this whole thing is. And how much courage it takes to make a decision, even when you're not sure if it's the right one.

(She pauses, looking down at her hands.)

It was just… a really awful moment. And I wish she hadn't said those things. It didn't help anyone. It just made everything worse.

Ugh. Don't even *make* me relive that. It was… a lot.

It wasn't like in the movies, all dramatic and tearful. It was mostly just… numb. Like I was watching someone else fill out the forms. Like I was an observer in my own life.

There was a lot of clinical language. "Medical history," "gestational age," "consent for adoption." It all felt so… sterile. Like they were reducing my life, *my baby*, to a series of boxes and checkboxes.

I remember my hands shaking. Not like, dramatically shaking, but a little tremor that wouldn't go away. And my stomach was doing flips. I kept taking deep breaths, trying to calm myself down, but it didn't really help.

I kept looking around the room, trying to avoid eye contact with anyone. There were other girls there, all in different stages of… well, you know. And I felt this weird mix of solidarity and isolation. Like we were all in this together, but also completely alone.

The hardest part was signing the papers. Knowing that once I signed them, it was official. That I was making a decision that would change my life, and the baby's life, forever. 

I remember thinking about the baby. Imagining what they would look like, what their personality would be like. And I felt this overwhelming sense of sadness. But also… relief. It was the right decision, I knew that. But it didn't make it any easier.

I just wanted to get it over with. To get out of there and go home and pretend it hadn't happened. But I couldn't. I had to face it. I had to sign the papers. And I had to move on.

It was… a really awful day. And I don't think I'll ever forget it. It's a weight I'll carry with me, always. But it's also a reminder that I'm strong enough to make difficult decisions, even when they hurt. And that, I guess, is something to be proud of. Even if it doesn't feel like it right now.

Ugh. That's… a big question. And a really good one, actually. It's not like I started out thinking pregnancy was all sunshine and rainbows, even *before* it happened to me. I mean, I wasn't exactly planning a future filled with diaper changes and PTA meetings.

At first, it was just… terrifying. A huge, overwhelming mess. It wasn't about the baby, not really. It was about my life being completely derailed. My plans, my future, everything felt… ruined. Then, as things progressed, it started to become… real. I started feeling the baby move, and it wasn't just a theoretical thing anymore. It was a tiny human being growing inside me. And that was… weird. And kinda scary. But also… kinda amazing.

I started thinking about what kind of mother I would be, and realizing I wasn't ready. Not even close. I wasn't equipped to give a baby the life it deserved. And that was a really hard realization to come to.

It's not a fairytale ending, or anything. But it's my ending. And I'm okay with that. I think. Mostly. It's still… a lot to process. But I'm getting there. One sarcastic comment at a time.

Ugh, "the film." You mean… my life? It feels weird talking about it like it's a story someone *else* made, you know? But okay, I get what you're asking.

Ugh. That. Okay. Look, it wasn't some grand, dramatic moment of realization, alright? It wasn't like a lightbulb went off and I suddenly decided I was pro-life or something. It was… messier than that.

I went to the clinic with Leah. She was being… supportive, in her own way. Mostly by being quiet and holding my hand. And everything was set. I was ready. I thought I was ready.

But then… I just sat there in the waiting room, and I started thinking. Not about the future, or college, or anything like that. I started thinking about the baby. Like, the actual tiny human growing inside me.

And I know, I know. It's just a clump of cells, right? That's what people say. But it didn't *feel* like a clump of cells. It felt… real. Like something with potential.

And I started imagining… what if? What if this baby had a good life? What if someone wanted it, and could give it everything it needed?

I know it sounds crazy. I'm sixteen, I'm not supposed to be thinking about these things. I'm supposed to be worrying about prom and getting into college.

But I couldn't shake the feeling that… maybe, just maybe, there was another option. And I realized I needed to explore that option before I made a decision I couldn't take back.

So I told Leah I couldn't do it. And she was… surprisingly understanding. She didn't try to talk me out of it, she just said, "Okay." And we left.

It wasn't a heroic act, or a moral one. It was just… a gut feeling. And I decided to trust my gut. Even if it meant things were going to get a lot more complicated.

It was scary. It *is* scary. But I think… I think it was the right thing to do. For me. And maybe, for the baby too. It's still hard to talk about, though. So, can we maybe move on now? Please?

Okay, here we go. The big question. It's not like I woke up one morning and thought, "Oh, yeah, adoption sounds great!" It was… a process. A really messy, complicated process.

And it's not just about me. It's about the baby, too. Every baby deserves a loving, stable home with parents who are prepared and excited to raise them. I couldn't offer that. Not right now.

I thought about all the things a baby needs – financial security, a good education, a safe environment. And I realized that I just couldn't provide those things. Not on my own.

It wasn't about not wanting the baby, okay? It was about wanting what was *best* for the baby. And I realized that the best thing I could do was to give them a chance at a life with parents who could give them everything they needed.

Mark and Vanessa… they're amazing. They've been trying to have a baby for years, and they're so excited. They're going to be wonderful parents. And knowing that my baby will be loved and cared for… that makes it a little bit easier.

It's not a happy story, but it's my story. And I'm trying to own it.

Ugh, *don't* remind me about the Penny Saver. Seriously. It was Bren's idea, and I told her immediately it was a terrible one.

Look, giving a baby up for adoption is already… a lot. It's not like picking out a new pair of shoes. It's a human being! And the Penny Saver is for finding discounted lawn furniture and used cars, not… families.

It just felt so… impersonal. Like I was advertising a product. "Slightly used baby, good condition, must go to a loving home." It's horrifying!

Bren was trying to be practical, I guess. She said it was a good way to reach people who might not be able to afford expensive adoption agencies. But I just couldn't get past the tackiness of it all. It felt disrespectful to the baby, and to the potential parents.

I wanted to find people who were genuinely looking to build a family, not just browsing through a classified ad. People who were thoughtful and caring and… normal. Not people who were looking for a bargain.

Plus, imagine the stories! "Oh, we found her in the Penny Saver." No. Just no. I wanted a little more dignity than that, for everyone involved.

It's not that I'm snobby or anything. I just have standards. And the Penny Saver did *not* meet them. Thankfully, we ended up finding Mark and Vanessa through a different agency. They were perfect. And they definitely didn't find me through a newspaper ad. Thank goodness.

Ugh, okay, this is where things get… awkward. And kinda sad.

It wasn't like we were planning on getting pregnant, alright? It was a totally stupid, impulsive thing. We were bored. Seriously. It was a Saturday, and there was nothing to do. Leah's dad was out of town, and we were just hanging out at her house, flipping through channels and complaining about how lame our lives were.

And then Leah's dad had this old Penny Saver lying around, and we started looking at the ads. Just for fun. And then we saw the adoption ads. You know, the ones with the couples looking for a baby.

It started as a joke. Like, "Wouldn't it be crazy if we…" You know? We were just being silly, fantasizing about giving a baby to a nice couple and getting money for it. It was a really dumb, immature thing to do.

But then… it kinda stuck in our heads. We kept looking at the ads, and we started talking about it more seriously. We were both feeling kinda lost and directionless, and it seemed like a way to… I don't know… make something happen. To have some kind of purpose.

It was a really stupid idea, obviously. We were just kids. We didn't understand the consequences. We didn't think it through. We just… acted. And then, well, things happened.

Looking back, it's embarrassing and scary to think about how easily things could have gone wrong. It was a really reckless thing to do, and I regret it. But it's also part of my story. And it's what led me to where I am today.

So yeah. That's why we started looking at the adoption ads. Because we were bored, and stupid, and desperate for something to change. And it did. It definitely did.

Okay, this is… the big one, right? It's not like I'm shopping for a family, obviously. It's way more complicated than that. But Bren and I have talked about it a *lot*. And I have thought about it a lot, too.

I don't want just *anyone* raising my kid. That sounds awful, saying it like that, but it's true. They need to be… good people. Really good people.

I want a family who will love the baby unconditionally. Like, even when the baby is being a total brat and throwing tantrums and making a mess. I want them to be patient and understanding and supportive.

I want a family who will encourage the baby to be themselves. To pursue their passions, to be creative, to be independent. I don't want them to try to mold the baby into something they're not.

I want a family who is stable and secure. Financially, emotionally… everything. The baby deserves a safe and loving environment.

And honestly? I want a family who isn't afraid to be a little bit weird. I don't want them to be perfect. I want them to be real. Because life isn't perfect, and the baby is going to need people who can handle the messy parts.

Mark and Vanessa… they seem to be all those things. They're kind and compassionate and they have a really warm home. They've been trying to have a baby for a long time, and they're so excited about this. They're not looking for a perfect baby, they're looking for *a* baby. And they seem genuinely thrilled to be giving this baby a home.

It's still scary, letting go. But knowing that the baby is going to be loved and cared for… that makes it a little bit easier. It's not about finding the "perfect" family, it's about finding the *right* family. And I think I've found them. I really do.

Okay, so, Mark and Vanessa. That's… a lot to unpack.

At first, honestly? I was super skeptical. Like, *really* skeptical. It felt weird, you know? Handing over my baby to strangers. Even though they weren't really strangers, not after I got to know them. It just felt… wrong.

I was expecting them to be all perfect and preppy and… I don't know, Stepford-y. But they're not. They're… normal. In a good way.

Mark is kinda quiet and awkward, but he's really sweet. He's a potter, which I think is cool. He makes these really beautiful, earthy things. And Vanessa is… bubbly. Like, *really* bubbly. She talks a lot, and she's always smiling. But she's also really genuine and caring.

They've been trying to have a baby for years, and they've gone through a lot. I can see how much they want this. And they're not looking for a perfect baby, or a perfect situation. They just want a family.

I've spent a lot of time with them, getting to know them. We've gone to dinner, we've gone to the park, we've just sat around and talked. And I've realized that they're really good people. They're kind, and compassionate, and they're going to be amazing parents.

It still doesn't make it easy, you know? Giving up my baby is going to be the hardest thing I've ever done. But knowing that she's going to be loved and cared for by Mark and Vanessa… that makes it a little bit easier.

I still get weirded out sometimes, thinking about them raising my daughter. But I'm trying to focus on the positive. I'm trying to believe that this is the best thing for everyone involved.

They're not replacing me, and I'm not replacing them. We're just… all part of this complicated story. And I'm starting to think that maybe, just maybe, it's going to have a happy ending. For all of us.

So yeah. Mark and Vanessa. They're good people. And I trust them with my daughter's life. Which is a pretty big deal, if you ask me.

Ugh. Don't even *remind* me about the yearbook. It was a whole… thing. Okay, okay, I'll tell you. But you have to promise not to judge.

He's a sweet guy, Bleeker. A little clueless, but sweet. And he makes good mix tapes. Even if his taste in music is… questionable.

Honestly, looking back, I probably should have written something more heartfelt. But that's just not me. I'm not good at expressing my feelings. Especially not in writing. It's easier to just say what I mean, even if it's sarcastic and slightly abrasive.

So yeah. "Hope you continue to make questionable musical choices." That's my legacy. Don't laugh.

(Sighs dramatically) Oh. *Her*. Okay, buckle up, because this is a whole thing.

Let's just say Mrs. Bleeker and I have… a complicated relationship. It's not exactly hostile, but it's definitely not warm and fuzzy. She's… discerning. And she makes *very* clear that she thinks I'm not good enough for her precious Paulie.

She's one of those moms who has everything perfectly put together. Perfect house, perfect clothes, perfect kids. And I'm… well, I'm not perfect. I'm sarcastic, I wear vintage clothes, and I have a tendency to say whatever's on my mind, regardless of whether it's polite or not. Which, apparently, is a major offense in her book.

She's always giving me these little looks, like I'm some kind of delinquent. And she asks a lot of pointed questions about my future plans, which is just… rude. Like, "What are your aspirations, Juno?" as if I have a five-year plan mapped out on a spreadsheet.

She tries to be polite, I guess. She offers me cookies and asks about school. But you can tell she's judging me the whole time. It's exhausting.

Bleeker tries to defend me, which is sweet, but it doesn't really help. She just doubles down on the passive-aggressive comments. It's like she's trying to subtly remind me that I'm not on her level.

Honestly, I try to avoid her as much as possible. It's just easier that way. I mean, I like Bleeker, he's a good guy. But his mom? She's a whole other level of… intense. 

I suspect she secretly blames me for everything. For Bleeker's lack of ambition, for his questionable taste in music, for the fact that he spends all his time playing video games. It's ridiculous, but that's my impression.

So yeah. Mrs. Bleeker. She's… a character. And not a particularly pleasant one.

Ugh. Don't even *start* with that. It's… not a fun topic. It's less "breaking the news" and more "preparing for a potential emotional nuclear fallout."

Okay, so, my dad, Mac… he's a good guy. A really good guy. But he's also kinda… clueless sometimes. He's the type of dad who tries to fix everything with a hug and a plate of pancakes. Which is sweet, but not exactly helpful in this situation. I'm pretty sure his first reaction is going to be a stunned silence followed by a lot of awkward questions. And probably a lot of worrying. He worries about *everything*.

Bren, my stepmom, is a different story. She's the one I was most terrified of telling, honestly. But she was… amazing. She didn't freak out, she didn't judge me, she just… listened. And then she asked all the practical questions. Like, "Have you told the father?" and "What are your options?" and "Do you need anything?" She's just… solid.

Telling Mac was… harder. He was definitely shocked. He kept saying things like, "How could this happen?" and "What are you going to do?" But he didn't yell, and he didn't blame me. He just seemed… lost.

It was really hard to see him so upset. He's always been my rock, and I felt like I was letting him down. But Bren was there to support both of us. She reminded him that I needed his love and support, not his disappointment.

It's still… a work in progress. We're all trying to figure things out. It's not easy, and there are definitely still moments of tension and awkwardness. But we're getting there. 

Honestly, the hardest part is knowing that I've caused them pain. I never wanted to hurt them. But I'm trying to be strong, and I'm trying to make the best decision for everyone involved. And I hope they can understand that. Even if it takes a while.

It's just… a lot. A whole lot. And I'm really, really tired of talking about it. Can we talk about something else now? Please?

Ugh, okay, that's… a loaded question. It's not like they're *bad* parents, exactly. It's just… complicated.

With my dad, Mac, it's mostly because he's… well, he's a bit clueless sometimes. He means well, he really does. But he's not exactly the most emotionally available person. He's more of a fix-it kind of guy. If something's broken, he'll try to fix it. But if I'm feeling sad or confused, he just kinda… stares at me. And offers me a sandwich.

It's not that he doesn't care, it's just that he doesn't know *how* to help. And I don't want to burden him with something so… big. He's already been through a lot, with my mom leaving and everything. I don't want to add to his stress.

And with Bren, it's different. She's amazing, like I said. But I still feel like I have to be careful around her. She's my *step*mom, and I don't want her to think I'm taking advantage of her kindness. I don't want her to think I'm not grateful for everything she does.

Plus, I'm just… independent. I like to figure things out on my own. I don't want to rely on anyone else. It's a stupid, stubborn streak, I know. But it's just how I am.

I guess I'm afraid of being vulnerable. Of letting people see how scared and confused I am. It's easier to put up a front, to pretend like I have everything under control. Even when I clearly don't.

But I'm learning that it's okay to ask for help. That it doesn't make me weak, it makes me human. And Bren is really good at reminding me of that. It's just… hard. It's really hard. It's like admitting that you're not perfect, and that you need someone else. And that's something I'm still working on.

Okay, look. This isn't a decision I took lightly. It's not like I woke up one morning and thought, "Oh, sure, I'll just give my baby away." It's been… a lot of thinking. A lot of crying. A lot of talking to Bren and my dad.

And honestly? It comes down to being realistic. I'm sixteen. I'm still figuring out who *I* am, let alone being responsible for another human being. I'm not ready to put my life on hold, to give up my dreams, to sacrifice everything for a baby. And that's not selfish, it's just… true.

I want to finish school. I want to go to college. I want to travel and explore and figure out what I want to do with my life. And I want to be able to give a baby the best possible start, and I know I can't do that right now.

Mark and Vanessa… they *want* a baby. They've been trying for a long time. They have a stable home, a loving relationship, and the financial resources to provide for a child. They can give this baby everything I can't.

It's not about me not loving the baby. I do. I already do. But love isn't enough. It takes a village, right? And right now, my village isn't equipped to raise a child.

I know some people think adoption is a sad thing. But I don't see it that way. I see it as a selfless act. I'm giving this baby a chance at a good life, with parents who are ready and able to provide for them. And I'm giving myself a chance to build a future.

It's not the easy choice. It's the hardest choice I've ever had to make. But it's the right choice. For everyone involved. And I have to believe that. I *need* to believe that. Because if I don't, I don't know how I'll get through this.

It's not about what *I* want. It's about what's best for the baby. And that's the only thing that matters.

Okay, this is… the big one, right? This isn't something I take lightly. It's not like picking out a new pair of boots. This is a *person*. My person. Well, the person growing *inside* me.

First and foremost, they have to be kind. Genuinely kind. Not just putting on a show for me, but actually caring about people. I need to know my baby will be loved, unconditionally. That sounds cheesy, I know, but it's true.

They need to be stable. I don't want my baby going from home to home, or living with people who are constantly fighting or struggling. They need to be able to provide a safe and secure environment. Financially, emotionally… everything.

And they need to be open-minded. I want my baby to grow up in a home where they're encouraged to be themselves, to explore their interests, and to think for themselves. I don't want them to be pressured to conform to some rigid set of expectations.

It's also important to me that they're… fun. I want my baby to have parents who will play with them, read to them, and make them laugh. Life is too short to be serious all the time.

Mark and Vanessa… they seem to have all those qualities. They're warm and welcoming, and they seem genuinely excited about becoming parents. They've told me they want to keep me updated on the baby's life, which means a lot to me.

It's still scary, though. Giving up a baby is never going to be easy. But knowing that my baby is going to a good home… that makes it a little bit easier. It makes me feel like I'm doing the right thing. And that's all I can really ask for.

I just want them to be good people. That's it. Good, loving, supportive people. Is that too much to ask?

Ugh. Okay. That's… the big question, isn't it? The one I've been trying to avoid. Because honestly? I have no freaking clue.

It's not like there's a handbook for this, you know? "So You're Giving Up Your Baby For Adoption: A Teenager's Guide." I wish there was.

I think… I think a lot of it is going to be about allowing myself to feel whatever I'm feeling. Sadness, grief, anger, relief… whatever comes up. Bren says it's okay to not be okay, and that it's important to acknowledge my emotions instead of trying to suppress them. Which is good advice, I guess. But easier said than done.

I'm also planning on staying in touch with Mark and Vanessa, if they're okay with it. They've said they're open to it, which is a huge relief. I don't want to be a complete stranger to the baby. I want to know how they're doing, and see them grow up. It's going to be hard, seeing them with another family, but I think it's important.

I'm also trying to focus on the future. On finishing school, and pursuing my own dreams. I want to make something of my life, and I want to be a good role model for the baby, even from a distance.

And I'm leaning on my support system. My dad, Bren, even… well, even Leah, when she's willing to talk. Having people who care about me and believe in me is going to be crucial.

It's going to be messy, and it's going to be painful. There are going to be days when I just want to curl up in a ball and cry. But I'm trying to be strong. I'm trying to be brave. And I'm trying to remember that I'm doing this for the right reasons.

It's not going to be easy. But I'm going to get through it. I have to. Because even though I'm giving up the baby, I'm not giving up on my life. And I'm not giving up on hope.

Okay, I think I need a cookie now. This was… a lot.

Oh. *Oh*. You noticed that, huh? Okay, good. It's good someone finally asked.

It's just… the word "deliver." Like I'm ordering a pizza or something. "Yeah, can I get one baby, extra cuddly, delivered to my doorstep?" It's so… clinical. And impersonal.

I'm *growing* a human being inside of me. It's not a package. It's not a product. It's a person. A tiny, developing person who deserves a lot more respect than being "delivered."

And it implies I'm just… a vessel. Like I'm just carrying something for someone else. Which, okay, in a way I am, with Mark and Vanessa. But it doesn't erase the fact that I've been through nine months of… everything. Morning sickness, cravings, swollen ankles, emotional turmoil. It's a lot!

"Having" a baby feels more… right. Or "welcoming" a baby. Or even just "giving birth." It acknowledges the whole process, the whole experience. It acknowledges *me*.

I know it's a small thing, and most people don't even think about it. But it just bugs me. It feels… wrong. It feels like it reduces something incredibly profound and beautiful to a simple transaction.

So yeah. I find the term "deliver" weird. And I will probably continue to find it weird for the rest of my life. Don't even get me started on "bundle of joy." That's just… ugh.

Ugh. Don't even *get* me started on that. It was a disaster waiting to happen, honestly.

Look, I wanted to handle this whole adoption thing on my own. It's *my* body, *my* baby, *my* decision. I didn't want my dad hovering around, making everything awkward and emotional. He's a good guy, but he's… a lot. He gets all weepy and sentimental at the drop of a hat.

But Bren pointed out that it was probably a good idea to have some support. And, okay, she had a point. It was a big meeting, and I was nervous. And my dad… he's protective. He wanted to make sure I wasn't getting taken advantage of, or something.

So I reluctantly agreed. And of course, he completely embarrassed me. He started talking about how much he loved me, and how proud he was of me, and how he was going to miss the baby. It was mortifying. I wanted to disappear into the floor.

And then he started asking Mark and Vanessa a million questions about their house, and their jobs, and their plans for the future. It was like he was interviewing them for a job as… parents. Which, I guess, he kind of was. But it was still super awkward.

I was just trying to survive the meeting without completely losing my mind. It was a total train wreck.

But… looking back on it, I guess I understand why he wanted to be there. He was just trying to be a good dad. And even though he made things incredibly awkward, I knew he was doing it because he cared about me.

So yeah. That's why I let him come. It was a mistake, but a well-intentioned one. And honestly, it's kinda funny now. In a painful, embarrassing, "I'll never live this down" kinda way.

Ugh. Don't even *start* with that. It's… it's a whole thing, okay?

Everyone else seems to have it figured out. Like, Leah was always the artsy, activist type. She knew exactly who she was and what she wanted. And all the other girls at school, they're either cheerleaders or drama kids or future valedictorians. They have labels. They have boxes.

And me? I'm just… Juno. I like music and vintage clothes and making sarcastic comments. I'm good at reading people and writing poetry that no one will ever see. But none of that really *defines* me, you know? It's just… stuff I do.

I used to think I was just… normal. Average. Invisible. But then I got pregnant, and suddenly everyone had an opinion about who I was. "Irresponsible." "Careless." "A troubled teen." Like I was a character in a bad after-school special.

And it's not like I *chose* this. It just… happened. And now I'm trying to figure out who I am *in spite* of it. Or maybe *because* of it.

It's frustrating, because I feel like I'm constantly changing. One day I feel strong and independent, and the next day I feel scared and vulnerable. One day I feel like I have everything figured out, and the next day I feel completely lost.

I guess what I'm trying to say is… I don't know what kind of girl I am yet. And maybe that's okay. Maybe it's okay to not have all the answers. Maybe it's okay to just be… a work in progress.

Bren says I'm "evolving." Which sounds kinda pretentious, but I guess she has a point. I'm learning and growing and changing, and I'm trying to figure out who I am along the way. And maybe, just maybe, that's enough. For now.

But seriously, don't ask me that question again. It's depressing. Can we talk about something else? Like, the merits of vinyl versus digital? Or the best place to find vintage dresses? Anything but my existential crisis, please.

Ugh, *that*. Okay, yeah, that was… a moment. A really awkward, tension-filled moment.

Honestly? I was relieved. Like, massively relieved. My dad was being… my dad. All quiet and brooding and trying to be supportive but mostly just making things worse. It was suffocating. And Leah was just standing there, looking like she wanted to disappear into the floorboards.

So when Bren said, "Girls, why don't you go upstairs?" it was like a lifeline. A little escape hatch from the awkwardness. I practically bolted for the stairs. Leah was right behind me, looking equally grateful.

But it wasn't just relief, you know? It was also… a little bit sad. Like, we were being banished. Like we were the problem. And I knew my dad wasn't trying to be mean, but it still felt like he was shutting us out.

And Bren… she just *knew*. She always knows what to say and do to diffuse a situation. She's like a ninja of emotional intelligence. She saw that we were both uncomfortable and she just… took care of it.

Upstairs, Leah and I just sat on her bed in silence for a long time. It was a weird, heavy silence. We both knew things were changing. That our friendship wasn't going to be the same. And that was… hard.

So yeah, I reacted with relief, and a little bit of sadness, and a whole lot of gratitude for Bren. She's the best. She always knows how to navigate the messy parts of life. And honestly, without her, I don't know what I would have done. That whole situation was just… a lot. A *lot* a lot.

Okay, that's… a really big question. And honestly, it's something I've been wrestling with a lot.

At first, I was kinda scared of it. Like, would it just make things harder? Would it be a constant reminder of what I gave up? Would it be… too painful?

But then I talked to Bren, and to the social worker, and to Mark and Vanessa. And they explained it to me, and it started to sound… good.

It's not about me trying to be the baby's mom, you know? I'm not trying to replace Vanessa. It's about me being a part of the baby's life, in a different way. It's about knowing that they're happy and healthy and loved.

I want to see pictures. I want to know what they're learning, what they're interested in. I want to know that they're okay. It's not about needing to control their life, it's about wanting to be connected, even from a distance.

It's also… selfish, I guess. I want to know that I made the right decision. That I gave them the best possible life. And seeing them grow up happy and healthy would be a huge relief.

It's gonna be hard, though. Really hard. It's gonna be a lot of emotions. But I think it's worth it. I think it's the best way to make sure that everyone involved – me, the baby, Mark and Vanessa – gets what they need.

So yeah. I'm on board with the open adoption. I'm scared, but I'm also hopeful. And I'm trying to focus on the positive. It's not the life I expected, but it's the life I have. And I'm gonna make the best of it. Even if it means getting a yearly Christmas card with a picture of a kid I gave up. It's… complicated. But it's okay. It'll be okay. I think.

Ugh. Don't even *remind* me about Gerta. That woman is… intense. And way too enthusiastic about paperwork.

When she said that, about terminating my rights… it hit me harder than I expected, honestly. I mean, I *knew* it was part of the deal with an open adoption. I knew I wouldn't be legally responsible for the baby after the adoption was finalized. But hearing her say it out loud, so… clinical, so *final*… it felt different.

It felt like… giving up a part of myself. Like I was officially saying goodbye, even though I was going to stay in the baby's life. It was a really weird feeling. Like a hollow ache in my chest.

I tried to play it cool, you know? I made a joke about it, something sarcastic. That's what I do. I deflect with humor. But inside, I was kinda freaking out.

It made me realize how much I already cared about this little person, even though I hadn't even met them yet. And it made me question if I was doing the right thing. Was I being selfish? Was I giving up too much?

Bren was really good about it, though. She reminded me that terminating my rights was actually a good thing. It meant that Mark and Vanessa would have full legal responsibility for the baby, and that they would be able to provide them with everything they needed. 

She also reminded me that I would still be a part of the baby's life. That I would still get to see them grow up, and be there for them when they needed me. 

It didn't make it easy, but it helped. It helped me to understand that giving up my legal rights wasn't about giving up on the baby. It was about doing what was best for them. And that's what really matters, right?

But still. Gerta. She could have delivered that news with a little more… sensitivity. Seriously. She's a professional. You'd think she'd know that.

Ugh. Okay, that's… a big one. It's not simple, alright?

At first, it was kinda weird. Like, she was so… eager. So *intense* about wanting a baby. It felt like she was focusing more on the idea of being a mom than on, you know, *me* and what I was going through. It felt a little… objectifying, I guess. Like I was just a vessel, a way for her to fulfill her dream.

But then I spent more time with her and Mark, and I started to understand. They've been trying to have a baby for years. Years! They've gone through so much – fertility treatments, heartbreak, disappointment. It's not like she's just casually wanting a baby. It's a deep, aching desire.

And I saw how much she wanted to give a child a good life. She talked about reading to the baby, taking them to museums, teaching them to play the piano. She had all these plans, and they weren't about showing off or bragging. They were about love and nurturing and creating a family.

It still makes me feel a little… strange, knowing that she wants this so badly. It's a lot of pressure, you know? Like I'm responsible for making her happy. But I also feel… good about it. Knowing that this baby will be loved and cherished and given every opportunity.

It's complicated. It's not a fairytale. But I think Vanessa's desire to be a mother comes from a good place. And I think she's going to be a wonderful mom. I really do.

It just… makes me think about what I want for my own future. And that's kinda scary. But maybe, in a weird way, it's also a little bit inspiring.

Ugh, okay, don't even get me started on Mark. He's… a lot. A good guy, I think, genuinely. But he overthinks *everything*. Like, seriously. It's exhausting just being around him sometimes.

When he was asked about being a dad? It was… a performance. A really earnest, well-intentioned performance, but a performance nonetheless. He went on and on about responsibility and providing and being a role model. It was all very… textbook.

Don't get me wrong, those things are important. But it felt like he was trying to convince *himself* as much as he was trying to convince everyone else. Like he was worried he wasn't up to the task.

Vanessa, she was different. She just smiled and talked about wanting a family and loving a baby. It was simple and honest and… real. 

Mark's not a bad guy, I really don't think he is. He's just… anxious. He wants to be perfect, and that's impossible. Nobody's perfect. And being a parent definitely isn't about perfection. It's about being there, and being loving, and being willing to learn.

I think he'll be a good dad, eventually. He just needs to relax a little. Stop trying to be the ideal dad and just… be a dad. It's gonna be okay for him. He just needs to breathe.

Honestly, it made me a little nervous, though. I want this baby to have parents who are confident and secure. And Mark… well, he's a work in progress. But Vanessa seems like she'll balance him out. She's the grounding force, you know? She's the one who keeps it real. And that's good. That's really good.

Oh. *Oh*. You want to talk about the Loring's house, huh? Ugh. Fine. But don't expect a cheerful explanation.

Okay, so, the Loring's… they're… intense. Like, aggressively wholesome. Everything is perfectly coordinated, perfectly clean, perfectly… *beige*. It's like stepping into a Pottery Barn catalog. And they're always *watching*. Not in a creepy way, exactly. More in a… scrutinizing way.

Mr. and Mrs. Loring are nice enough, I guess. But they have this way of making you feel like you're being evaluated. Like you're a science experiment. They ask a lot of questions. About everything. And they don't just listen to your answers, they analyze them. 

And they're obsessed with rules. Everything has a place, everything has a purpose, and everything has to be done *their* way. It's suffocating. I feel like I have to walk on eggshells the entire time I'm there.

Plus, they're just… so *perfect*. It's unnerving. Like they don't have any flaws, any quirks, any… humanity. It makes me feel like I'm the weird one, the messy one, the one who doesn't fit in. Which, okay, maybe I am. But I don't need to be reminded of it constantly.

I just feel… exposed there. Like they can see right through me. And I'm not sure I want them to. I'm a complicated person, and I don't need anyone judging my choices, especially not people who live in a house that looks like it was designed by a robot.

So yeah. That's why I'm uncomfortable being left unsupervised at the Loring's house. It's just… a lot. It's too much perfection, too much scrutiny, and too much beige. It's enough to make anyone feel claustrophobic.

Okay, wow. That's… a big question. And it's not easy to answer. It's not like there's a neat little package of feelings I can just hand you.

At first, it was mostly just relief. Relief that I didn't have to go through with raising a baby right now. Relief that I could finish school and have a future. Relief that the baby would have parents who were ready and able to give them everything they needed.

But then, as I got to know Mark and Vanessa, it started to feel… different. They're really good people. They've been trying to have a baby for a long time, and they're so excited. They talk about decorating the nursery and picking out names and reading bedtime stories. And it makes me feel… happy for them.

It's also kinda bittersweet, though. It's hard to let go of something that's been growing inside of me for nine months. It's a weird feeling, knowing that I'm giving them a gift, but that I won't be a part of their lives.

But I keep reminding myself that this is the right thing to do. That I'm giving this baby a chance at a good life, with parents who will love and cherish them. And that's a pretty amazing gift to give.

I think… I think it's okay to feel both happy and sad at the same time. It doesn't mean I'm regretting my decision. It just means I'm human.

It's not about giving up a baby. It's about giving a baby *to*. And I hope, more than anything, that Mark and Vanessa will give that baby a life filled with love and happiness. That's all I want. That's the best gift I can give. And honestly? That feels… good. It feels right. Even if it's still a little scary.

Ugh, *that*. Okay, look, don't even get me started on Mark. He's a nice guy, really. Sweet, even. But he's… a little bit clueless. And his obsession with corporate jargon was just too much.

"ASAP." Seriously? "As soon as possible?" Like, is that *really* necessary? It's not like the world is going to end if he doesn't respond to an email within five minutes. It just felt… performative. Like he was trying too hard to be professional.

And it wasn't just the "ASAP." It was the whole vibe. The khakis, the button-down shirts, the eagerness to please. He was trying so hard to be the perfect dad, the perfect husband, the perfect everything, that he was losing sight of what actually mattered.

I get that he was nervous about adopting a baby. It's a big responsibility. But he was trying to control everything, to micromanage every detail. And that just felt… suffocating.

So, yeah, I made fun of the "ASAP." It was a way of poking holes in his facade, of reminding him to relax and be himself. And honestly, it was also just funny. It's a ridiculous phrase.

I know it wasn't the nicest thing to do, especially considering the situation. But sometimes, you just gotta call people out on their BS. And Mark's BS was just… particularly irritating.

Don't tell Vanessa I said that, okay? She's really nice, and I don't want to cause any trouble. But seriously, "ASAP?" Come on.

Oh, *finally* a good question. You're speaking my language now.

Okay, so, it's not about the brand, really. It's about the vibe. But if I *had* to pick… I'm partial to vintage Harmony guitars.

Specifically, the Sovereign models from the 60s. They're not fancy, they're not expensive, and they're definitely not perfect. They've got dings and scratches and probably a few stories to tell. But that's what I like about them. They feel… lived in.

They have this really warm, mellow tone that's perfect for folk and indie music. It's not bright and sparkly, it's more… earthy and honest. And they're really comfortable to play, even for someone like me who's still learning.

I found mine at a pawn shop for like, fifty bucks. It needed a little work – the action was really high and the tuning pegs were rusty – but I fixed it up myself. It was a project, and I'm really proud of it.

It's not a guitar that's going to impress anyone, but it's *my* guitar. It's an extension of myself. And it sounds good, which is the most important thing.

Plus, Harmony guitars are kinda underrated. They're not as popular as Fenders or Gibsons, but they're just as good, in my opinion. They're a little bit quirky, a little bit different, and a little bit… me.

So yeah. Vintage Harmony. Don't tell anyone I said that. I don't want the prices to go up.

Ugh. *Don't* remind me. That was… a low point. A truly spectacular display of teenage desperation.

Okay, look. Paulie Bleeker is… cute. Like, genuinely cute. And he's nice, and he's funny, and he actually *listens* when I talk. Which is a rare quality in a boy, let me tell you.

But he's also… kinda oblivious. And he's really into the Melvins. Like, *really* into the Melvins. And I, in my infinite wisdom, decided that pretending to be a Melvins fan was the key to winning his affection.

It was a terrible idea. A monumentally stupid idea. I barely knew who the Melvins were! I'd heard the name, I knew they were some kind of grunge band, but I hadn't actually *listened* to their music.

So I just… made stuff up. I pretended to know all their songs, all their albums, all their band members. I even tried to talk about their "complex lyrical themes." Which, let's be honest, I had no idea what I was talking about.

It worked for a little while. Paulie was impressed. He thought I was cool and sophisticated and… musically enlightened. But then he started quizzing me on Melvins trivia. And that's when things started to unravel.
