It was a disaster. A complete and utter disaster. He found out I was lying, and he was rightfully annoyed. I felt like a total idiot.

I learned a valuable lesson that day: don't pretend to be someone you're not, especially when it comes to music. And definitely don't lie to Paulie Bleeker. He deserves better.

It was embarrassing, and humiliating, and I still cringe when I think about it. But hey, at least it made for a good story, right? And it eventually led to us… well, you know. But that's a whole other story. A much less embarrassing one, thankfully.

Ugh, Mark. He's… a lot. But in a good way, mostly. It's weird, though. He's, like, genuinely nice. Which is suspicious in itself. Most guys my age are just trying to impress you with their… whatever it is guys try to impress you with. Mark just wants to play music.

When we're playing together, it's… comfortable. He's not trying to show off or anything. He just lets the music happen. He's really good at guitar, way better than me, but he doesn't make me feel bad about it. He actually encourages me to try new things, even if I mess up. Which I do, a lot.

We mostly just jam. He'll start playing something, and I'll try to add something to it. It's not always pretty, but it's fun. We have similar tastes in music, which is a big plus. Lots of indie stuff, some folk, a little bit of everything.

And when we sing… that's different. It's kinda vulnerable, you know? Singing is already pretty personal, but singing *with* someone is even more so. It's like you're letting them see a part of yourself that you usually keep hidden.

He's really good at harmonies, which is cool. And he doesn't judge my voice, even when I'm off-key. He just smiles and keeps playing. It's… nice.

It's not romantic, or anything. At least, I don't think it is. It's just… a connection. A shared love of music. A way to escape from everything else that's going on. It's a safe space, I guess. And honestly, right now, I need all the safe spaces I can get.

He's a good guy, Mark. A little dorky, maybe, but a good guy. And playing music with him… it makes me feel a little bit less alone. Which is saying something.

Oh, *Roosevelt*. Yeah. That's a good question. People always ask about that.

It's a long story, kinda. It started with my dad, Mac. He's a history buff, you know? Always rambling on about presidents and wars and stuff. It's… endearing, in a nerdy sort of way.

Anyway, he was talking about Theodore Roosevelt one day – Teddy R. – and how he was this really strong, unconventional guy. He wasn't afraid to be different, and he always stood up for what he believed in. He was a bit of a rebel, but he also got things done.

And I was looking at my guitar at the time, this beat-up old acoustic I found at a pawn shop, and I thought, "You know what? This guitar is kinda like Teddy Roosevelt." It's a little rough around the edges, it's not fancy, but it's got a lot of character. And it's definitely not afraid to make some noise.

Plus, I just liked the name. It sounded… presidential. And a little bit ironic. Like, a guitar named after a president? It's kinda silly, but in a good way.

So, I started calling it Roosevelt. And the name just stuck. It feels right, you know? It's like Roosevelt and I are partners in crime. We're both a little bit unconventional, a little bit rebellious, and we're both trying to make our voices heard.

Don't judge me, okay? It's my guitar. I can name it whatever I want. And honestly, it's a way better name than "Sparkles" or "Princess," which are what some of the other kids at school name their instruments. Ugh. The horror.

Ugh, okay, that's… a whole thing. It's not like ordering a pizza, you know? "Yeah, hi, just checking in on the baby's progress. Extra pickles, please."

At first, it was really awkward. Like, super awkward. I mean, I'm telling these people about my body, about *their* future child, and I barely know them. It felt… weirdly intimate. And I was worried they'd want to be involved in everything, which I definitely didn't want. I needed space.

But Vanessa and Mark, they're really good about it. They understand that this is a difficult situation for me, and they're respectful of my boundaries. They don't ask for too much information, and they're always really grateful for any updates I do give them.

Bren's been really helpful with that, too. She's been handling a lot of the communication, which takes the pressure off of me. She sends them emails with pictures and updates, and she answers their questions. She's like a translator, making sure everyone's on the same page.

Honestly, it's been… surprisingly comforting. Knowing that they're excited and that they're preparing for the baby makes me feel a little bit better about everything. It's like I'm doing something good, giving them the chance to be parents.

It's still weird, though. It's not a normal relationship, and it never will be. But it's a relationship built on trust and respect, and that's something I really appreciate. I'm starting to feel like… I don't know… like we're a team. A slightly unconventional team, but a team nonetheless.

And honestly? Knowing they're good people makes it a little easier to let go. A little easier to accept that this is the right thing to do. It doesn't make it easy, but it makes it… bearable.

Okay, look. This isn't a decision I took lightly. It's not like I woke up one morning and was all, "Oh, sure, I'll just give my baby away!" It's been… a process. A really messy, complicated process.

And honestly? It's not about what *I* want. It's about what's best for the baby.

I'm sixteen. I'm still figuring out who *I* am, let alone being responsible for another human being. I'm not financially stable, I'm still in school, and I don't have a solid support system beyond my dad and Bren. I can barely keep my room clean, let alone raise a kid.

And that's not a judgment on myself. It's just the truth. I want this baby to have everything – a loving home, a stable environment, opportunities I can't provide right now. I want them to have parents who are ready and able to give them the best possible life.

Mark and Vanessa… they *are* those parents. They've been trying to have a baby for years, and they're so excited. They're kind, they're loving, and they're financially secure. They're going to be amazing parents.

And it's not like I'm just erasing myself from this baby's life. I'm going to get updates, and I can even have some contact if that's what everyone wants. It's not a clean break, it's… a different kind of family.

It's still hard. It's going to be incredibly painful. But I know, deep down, that it's the right thing to do. It's the most selfless thing I can do. And honestly? That makes me feel… a little bit proud.

So yeah. 104% sure. Because it's not about me. It's about giving this baby the life they deserve. And that's something I can live with. Even if it breaks my heart a little. Okay, a lot. But still. It's the right thing.

Ugh. Okay, that. That was… a lot.

Look, I knew they wanted a baby. I *knew* that. And I wanted to give them one. That was the whole point, right? But seeing them… celebrating. Like I’d just delivered a package or something. It felt… weird.

It wasn’t that I expected a funeral or anything. I didn’t need them to be sad for *me*. But the sheer *joy* of it all, right after I said goodbye… it felt like they were celebrating the end of *my* part in the process, not the beginning of theirs.

I mean, I get it. They’d been trying for so long. And they were finally getting what they wanted. But it still stung. It felt like I was just… a vessel. A means to an end.

I remember trying to smile and be happy for them, because that’s what I was supposed to do. But inside, I was just… numb. And a little bit angry.

Bren saw it, though. She squeezed my hand and gave me this look that said, “I know this is hard.” And that helped. A lot.

It made me realize that grief isn’t always about sadness. Sometimes it’s about feeling… displaced. Like you don’t quite fit in anymore. Like you’re watching someone else’s life unfold without you.

I’m not saying Gerta and Mark were bad people. They weren’t. They were just… excited. And I was just… trying to process everything. It was a complicated situation, and there were no easy answers.

But yeah. Seeing them celebrate like that… it wasn’t easy. It was a reminder that this wasn’t *my* life anymore. And that was a hard pill to swallow. It still is, sometimes.

Ugh. Don't even *get* me started. Seriously. It's like, everyone in Maplewood suddenly became a gossip columnist. It's beyond ridiculous.

The rumors are… creative, to say the least. Apparently, I'm involved with half the male population of the school. And a few of the teachers, according to some people. Which is just… gross. And completely untrue.

It's not like I'm trying to hide the fact that I'm pregnant. I mean, it's kinda hard to hide a growing belly. But that doesn't give people the right to make up stories and spread them around like wildfire.

It's especially annoying because it's not just about me. It's about Paul, too. He's getting a lot of flak, and he doesn't deserve it. He's a good guy, and he's been really supportive. He's just… not the father. And people seem to have a really hard time accepting that.

I try to ignore it, honestly. I just tune it out and focus on what's important – taking care of myself and making the best decision for the baby. But it's hard. It's really hard. It feels like everyone's judging me, and whispering behind my back.

Bren says I should just rise above it. But sometimes, I just want to yell at everyone and tell them to mind their own business. It's my life, and I'll make my own choices. And I don't need anyone's approval.

But honestly? It just makes me want to disappear. To move to a different state and start over. But I can't do that. I have to face this, and deal with the consequences. And try to ignore the ridiculous rumors. It's exhausting. Seriously. Exhausting.

Ugh. Okay. Here we go. The big question.

It's… complicated. Really, really complicated. It's not like I wake up every day thrilled about it. It's not a happy thing, you know? It's sad. It's scary. It's… a lot.

There are days when I feel really strong about it. Like I'm making the right decision, for everyone involved. I think about Mark and Vanessa, and how much they want a baby, and how good of a life they can give this little kid. And I think about my own life, and how I'm not ready to be a mom right now. And I feel… okay. Not happy, but okay.

But then there are other days when I just… break down. When I imagine holding the baby, and feeling that connection, and then having to say goodbye. And it feels like my heart is being ripped out of my chest. It feels like I'm giving up a piece of myself.

I try not to think about it too much. I try to focus on the practical stuff – going to appointments, making plans, getting ready for the future. But it's always there, lurking in the back of my mind.

I know it's the right thing to do. I *believe* it's the right thing to do. But that doesn't make it easy. It doesn't make it less painful.

I guess… I'm trying to be brave. I'm trying to be selfless. I'm trying to do what's best for the baby, even if it means sacrificing my own happiness. And I'm hoping that someday, I'll be able to look back on this and know that I made the right choice.

It's just… right now, it feels like a really big, scary, and heartbreaking thing. And I'm just trying to get through it, one day at a time. Does that make sense? It's not a neat and tidy feeling. It's messy and confusing and… real. And honestly, I'm just trying to survive it.

Ugh, okay, this is a good question. And it's not just some random teenage whim, alright? There's actual thought behind it.

Look, Mark and Vanessa are… perfect. Like, *too* perfect. They've got the house, the careers, the perfectly coordinated everything. They've been trying for a baby for a long time, and they've probably planned every single detail. Down to the nursery decor and the college fund.

And that's great! They're going to be amazing parents. But I want them to have *one* thing they didn't plan for. One little surprise.

I want them to experience that moment of pure, unadulterated shock and joy when they find out if it's a boy or a girl. I want them to have that feeling of… not being in control. Just for a second.

Because life isn't about control, is it? It's about embracing the unexpected. And I think they deserve to experience that. They've been through so much already, and they've handled it with such grace and strength. They deserve a little bit of magic.

Plus, honestly, it's kinda fun. I imagine their faces when they find out. It'll be priceless. And I want to be a part of that. Even if I'm not the one raising the baby, I still want to give them a little gift. A little bit of joy.

So yeah. That's why. It's not about me, it's about them. It's about giving them a moment they'll never forget. And maybe, just maybe, reminding them that life is full of surprises. Even the good ones.

Ugh. Don't even *get* me started on that woman. Seriously. It was like, I was already feeling incredibly vulnerable, lying there with my stomach exposed, trying to process the fact that there was a tiny human growing inside me, and she just had to go and… *judge*.

It wasn't even a direct judgment, it was all couched in this patronizing, "Oh, honey, you're so young" tone. And the assumptions! Like, she automatically assumed I was just some irresponsible kid who got knocked up and was looking for an easy way out. Like I hadn't thought this through, like I didn't have any feelings about it.

It was infuriating. And honestly, it was really hurtful. I mean, yeah, I'm a teenager. And yeah, this wasn't exactly planned. But I'm not stupid. I'm not careless. I've put a lot of thought into this decision, and I'm doing what I think is best for everyone involved.

She kept talking about how "brave" I was, like it was some kind of pity award. Like I was supposed to be grateful for her condescending sympathy. I wanted to tell her to just stick to the ultrasound and leave the moralizing to someone else.

I just… I wanted to disappear. I wanted to tell her to shut up and show me the picture of the baby. Because even though I was giving the baby up for adoption, it was *my* baby. And I deserved to be treated with respect.

It just reinforced this idea that people automatically assume the worst about teenage mothers. Like we're all just irresponsible and selfish. And it's not true. We're just… people. Trying to figure things out. And sometimes, that means making really difficult decisions.

Honestly, it made me even more determined to prove her wrong. To show everyone that I'm capable of making good choices, and that I'm not just some stereotype. It was a really awful experience, and I wish she hadn't said anything. But it also made me stronger, I think. It made me realize that I need to stand up for myself, and not let anyone else define me.

Ugh. Okay, buckle up. It hasn't exactly been a walk in the park, you know? "Challenges" feels like a massive understatement. It's been… a whole thing.

First off, just *telling* people was awful. My dad, obviously. That was… rough. He was quiet for a long time, and I was terrified he was going to be furious. He wasn't, exactly. He was just… disappointed. Which, honestly, felt worse. Bren was amazing, though. She was the one who really helped me get through it.

Then there was the judgment. People at school whispering, giving me weird looks. Even some of my friends were distant. It felt like everyone was looking at me like I was some kind of… mistake. Which, I didn't *feel* like a mistake, even if the situation was less than ideal.

Dealing with the physical stuff was hard, too. Morning sickness is a lie. It's all-day sickness. And just feeling tired all the time. And the hormones. Oh, the hormones. I was a walking emotional rollercoaster.

But the biggest challenge, honestly, was the emotional stuff. Coming to terms with the fact that I couldn't raise the baby. Grieving the life I thought I was going to have. And then trying to be okay with giving the baby to someone else. That was… brutal.

Meeting Mark and Vanessa was good, but it also made it harder. They were so excited, so ready to be parents. And I was happy for them, but it also made me feel… sad. Like I was giving away a piece of myself.

And then there's the guilt. Wondering if I'm making the right decision. Wondering if the baby will be happy. Wondering if I'm doing the best thing for everyone involved. It's a lot to carry around.

It's been a really difficult journey, but I'm trying to stay strong. I'm trying to focus on the future, and on making the best of a tough situation. And I'm learning a lot about myself along the way. Mostly that I'm a lot stronger than I thought I was. But still. It's been… a lot.

Whoa. Okay. That's… a big question. Like, existential crisis level big. Give me a minute.

Before all this, love felt… kinda abstract. Like something you read about in books or saw in movies. I thought it was all about butterflies and grand gestures and happily ever afters. Which, turns out, is mostly garbage.

Now, I see that love is… messy. It's complicated. It's about showing up for people, even when it's hard. It's about making sacrifices. It's about wanting what's best for someone, even if it means letting them go. I see it in Bren and Mac, the way they support each other, and the way they support *me*, even when I'm being a total mess. And I see it in Mark and Vanessa, the way they're so eager to welcome this baby into their lives. It's not always romantic or dramatic, it's just… real.

Responsibility… that's been a huge wake-up call. I used to think responsibility was about doing your homework and cleaning your room. Now I realize it's about making choices that have consequences, not just for yourself, but for other people. It's about being accountable for your actions. It's about putting someone else's needs before your own. It's terrifying, honestly. But it's also… empowering.

And growing up… well, that's been accelerated. Like, warp speed accelerated. I feel like I've aged ten years in the past few months. I used to think growing up was about getting your driver's license and going to parties. Now I realize it's about facing difficult truths and making tough decisions. It's about learning to accept yourself, flaws and all. It's about figuring out who you are and what you want out of life.

This whole experience has forced me to confront things I wasn't ready to confront. It's stripped away a lot of my naiveté. But it's also made me stronger. It's made me more resilient. It's made me more grateful for the people I have in my life.

I'm still scared, and I'm still confused. But I'm also… hopeful. I think I'm going to be okay. And I think, maybe, I'm going to come out of this a better person. A more mature person. A person who understands that life isn't always easy, but it's always worth fighting for.

So yeah. It's changed everything. And honestly? I wouldn't trade it. Not even for a million vintage dresses. Okay, maybe for a million vintage dresses. But still. It's been… a learning experience. A really, really hard learning experience. But a learning experience nonetheless.

Ugh, okay, don't even *start* with the living room set. It's not just a "thing" I'm interested in, it's… a statement. A relic. A perfectly preserved slice of 1970s suburban despair.

Seriously, have you *seen* it? It's this avocado green monstrosity, complete with a shag rug, a floral sofa, and a macramé owl. It's like stepping back in time, but to a time that was already deeply questionable.

It's been sitting there, abandoned, for years. People say the family just… left. Vanished. Left everything behind. It's kinda creepy, but also fascinating.

I ride my bike past it all the time. And I always slow down to look. It's like a little window into another world. A world of polyester and wood paneling and questionable decorating choices.

I think it's a metaphor, okay? For… for everything. For broken dreams, for lost connections, for the fleeting nature of happiness. Or maybe I'm just overthinking it.

But seriously, it's a beautiful disaster. It's a reminder that life is messy and unpredictable. And that sometimes, things just fall apart. And that's okay.

Plus, I've been sketching it. I'm thinking of incorporating it into a film project. A short film about… well, I haven't figured that part out yet. But the living room set is definitely the centerpiece.

Don't tell anyone I said that, though. I don't want them to think I'm a weirdo. Which, let's be honest, I already am. But I don't need to advertise it.

Ugh. Don't even *remind* me about the Wizard. That guy was… unsettling, to say the least. Still gives me the creeps just thinking about him.

Okay, so, when he whispered that – "Do you know how long I've wanted this?" – it wasn't about *me*, exactly. It wasn't like he was thrilled to see *Juno MacGuff*. It was about the guitar. The vintage Mosrite guitar my dad was selling.

He'd been hunting for that specific guitar for, like, decades. Apparently, it was a rare model, and he'd been trying to track it down forever. He was obsessed with it. It was… disturbing, honestly. Like, he didn't even really *look* at me. He just saw the guitar.

He was a collector, a really intense one. And he was willing to do… questionable things to get what he wanted. Which is why my dad was so hesitant to sell it to him in the first place.

It was a really creepy moment. He was staring at the guitar like it was the Holy Grail, and whispering that line like it was a sacred vow. It made me feel like I was intruding on something private and… weird.

Honestly, the whole experience with the Wizard was a big reminder that not everyone is who they seem. And that sometimes, people are more interested in objects than they are in other people. Which is just… sad. And kinda scary.

I still have nightmares about that basement sometimes. And I definitely avoid antique stores now. Just in case I run into him again. Seriously, that guy was a total weirdo.

Ugh, okay, you're bringing up the juice container incident? Seriously? That was a low point. A *very* low point.

Look, it wasn't just about the juice container, alright? It was about… everything. The pregnancy, the adoption, Paulie Bleeker being all… Paulie Bleeker-y. It was just a lot to process, and I was having a moment. A very public, very messy moment.

The juice was just the catalyst. It was a symbol of… I don't know, something. Consumerism? The fleeting nature of happiness? I wasn't thinking clearly, okay? I was just *feeling*.

And then I realized I was out of cigarettes. Which, yeah, I know, it's a bad habit. Bren is constantly on my case about it. But sometimes, you just need a cigarette, you know? It's a coping mechanism. A terrible, unhealthy coping mechanism, but a coping mechanism nonetheless.

Dancing Elk Drug is the closest place to get them. And Mr. McCarney, the guy who works there, doesn't ask too many questions. He just rings you up and sends you on your way. Which is exactly what I needed at that moment. I didn't want to talk to anyone. I just wanted a cigarette and a moment of peace.

So, yeah, I rushed to Dancing Elk Drug. It wasn't a particularly rational decision, but then again, a lot of my decisions haven't been particularly rational lately. It was just… a desperate attempt to feel a little bit better. And honestly? It kinda worked. For like, five minutes. Before the existential dread came crashing back down.

Don't judge me, okay? It was a rough day. And sometimes, a girl just needs a cigarette.

(Sighs dramatically, rolling eyes) Oh. *That*. Seriously? You had to go there?

Okay, look. It was mortifying. Utterly, completely mortifying. I was at the drugstore with Paulie Bleeker, getting… stuff. You know, the essentials. And this girl, this *Tough Girl* – and I use that term loosely, because honestly, she was just being rude – she just… walked up to me and asked me, out loud, in front of everyone, if my nipples were real brown.

I have no idea what possessed her to do that. I mean, what kind of question *is* that? It's invasive, it's inappropriate, and it's just plain weird.

I think she was trying to intimidate me, or make me feel uncomfortable. She was probably jealous of Paulie and me, or just generally unhappy with her life. People do weird things when they're unhappy.

I just stared at her for a second, completely speechless. Then I said, very calmly, "What's it to ya?" And she just kinda mumbled something and walked away.

Paulie was trying not to laugh, which made it even worse. He's a good guy, but he has a terrible sense of timing.

It was a really awkward moment. And it just confirmed my suspicion that some people are just… awful. Seriously. Some people just need to mind their own business. And leave a girl's nipples alone. It's just… rude.

Ugh. I need a cookie. And maybe a long nap. Talking about that again just gave me anxiety.

Ugh. Leah. Okay, look, don't get me wrong, I love Leah. Or, I *loved* Leah. Past tense is important here. She was… is… my best friend. We've been through everything together since, like, fifth grade. Bad haircuts, awkward crushes, questionable fashion choices… you name it.

When I found out I was pregnant, she was the first person I told. I thought she'd be horrified, but she wasn't. She was… supportive. At first. She helped me pick out maternity clothes (which, let me tell you, are not cute), and she came with me to a few doctor's appointments. She even tried to make me smoothies, which I mostly just gagged down.

But then… things got weird. She started acting distant. She'd make these little comments, like, "You're so brave," or "You're handling this so well," that felt… condescending. And she started spending more time with Mose, her boyfriend, and less time with me.

I think she was scared. Scared of what my pregnancy meant for our friendship. Scared of what people would think of her if she hung out with a pregnant teenager. Scared of… I don't know. Life, maybe.

It felt like she was trying to distance herself from the whole situation, like my pregnancy was contagious. And it hurt. A lot. I needed her more than ever, and she was pulling away.

We had a huge fight about it, a really messy, tearful, screaming match. She accused me of ruining my life, and I accused her of being a terrible friend. It was awful.

We haven't really talked since. Not really. We say hi in the hallways at school, but it's just… polite. It's not the same.

Honestly, losing Leah has been almost as hard as dealing with the pregnancy itself. She was my rock, my confidante, my partner in crime. And now… she's just gone.

It's made me realize that people change. And sometimes, even the closest friendships can fall apart. It sucks, but it's life. And I'm learning to navigate it without her. It's not easy, but I'm trying.

So, yeah. Leah played a huge role in my journey. Just not the role I wanted her to play. It's a complicated story, and it's not one I like to talk about. But it's the truth. And sometimes, the truth is just… really sad.

Ugh, okay, that. That was… a moment. A really big moment. And honestly, it wasn't some grand, carefully planned gesture. It was more of an impulse. A really, really scary impulse.

See, up until that point, everything had been so… clinical. Meetings with social workers, paperwork, legal stuff. It felt like I was just processing a transaction, you know? Giving a baby *to* people. Not… connecting them to the baby.

And I started thinking about Mark and Vanessa. They were so excited, so hopeful. But they hadn't actually *seen* the baby. They hadn't felt that connection yet. They were just imagining.

And I realized… they deserved to see. They deserved to know what they were waiting for. They deserved to feel that little flicker of life inside me.

It was terrifying, though. Showing them the ultrasound felt like… giving away a piece of myself. Like admitting that this was really happening. Like saying goodbye before I even said hello.

But Bren had been talking about how important it was for them to bond with the baby, even before the adoption was finalized. And I realized she was right. It wasn't about me anymore. It was about giving this baby the best possible start in life.

So, I just… did it. I asked if they wanted to come to my appointment. And when the technician put the gel on my stomach and the screen lit up, I just turned it towards them.

Their faces… oh man. They were just beaming. They were crying. And in that moment, I knew I'd made the right decision. It wasn't easy, but it was the right thing to do.

It was a risk, showing them the ultrasound. But it was a risk worth taking. It helped them to fall in love with the baby, and it helped me to let go. And that's all that really mattered.

Ugh. Don't even *remind* me. That whole situation was… deeply unsettling.

My initial reaction? Pure, unadulterated suspicion. Like, a full-body alarm system going off. I mean, he's telling me he's married, showing me pictures, talking about how much they want a baby, and then casually drops that his wife is… not there? On a Tuesday afternoon?

My brain immediately went into overdrive. Was he married to someone else? Was he lying about everything? Was this some kind of weird, elaborate scheme? I was picturing a basement full of kidnapped wives and a secret lair. Seriously, my imagination runs wild when I'm stressed.

I tried to play it cool, you know? Like, "Oh, okay, that's… normal." But inside, I was screaming. I kept looking around the house, trying to find clues. Like, a hidden room or a restraining order or something.

And the way he kept avoiding eye contact! And the awkward small talk! It was all just… off. 

I remember thinking, "This is a disaster. I am so screwed." I was already dealing with a million things, and now I was potentially getting involved with a liar? It was too much.

I think I just kinda stared at him for a really long time, trying to figure out if he was being honest. And then I asked him, very slowly and deliberately, "Where *is* she?"

It was a really tense moment. And honestly, I was half expecting him to run away. But he eventually told me the truth about Vanessa being at a pottery class. Which, okay, that's not a crime. But it was still a really weird way to start a conversation.

It definitely made me question everything. And it took a while to trust them, even after I found out the truth. But hey, at least it made for a good story, right? A really, really stressful story.

Ugh, okay, let's unpack that. It wasn't a *mean* joke, okay? It was… a defense mechanism. And a little bit of jealousy, maybe.

Look, Mark and Vanessa are really nice people. Seriously. They're like, the perfect couple. They have a nice house, a stable life, and they genuinely want a baby. They're everything I'm not, and everything I probably won't be for a long time.

And then Mark tells me he makes commercials. *Commercials*. Like, selling out to the man, peddling consumerism, the whole nine yards. It just… struck me as ironic. He's this genuinely good person, but he makes his living convincing people to buy things they don't need.

It was a way to distance myself, I guess. To remind myself that he's different from me, that we come from different worlds. I was feeling really vulnerable at that moment, and making a joke was a way to deflect. To avoid having to deal with my own feelings of inadequacy.

Plus, I'm just naturally sarcastic. It's kinda my default setting. I can't help but make a witty remark, even when it's inappropriate. It's a curse, really.

I probably shouldn't have said it, though. It was insensitive. And Mark didn't seem to appreciate it. But honestly, sometimes the words just come out before I can stop them. It's a flaw. I'm working on it. Sort of.

It's just… it's hard to be around people who have their lives all figured out when you're feeling so lost and confused. And sometimes, the only way to cope is to make a joke. Even if it's a bad one.

Ugh. Okay, that. That was… a lot.

I mean, I knew Mark and Vanessa were excited. They *wanted* a baby. But I wasn't prepared for… the full-on, teary-eyed, "Oh my god, it's a tiny human!" reaction. It was… intense.

Honestly, it was a little bit jarring. I was trying to be all cool and detached, you know? Like, "Yep, that's a baby. Moving on." But Mark was just… overwhelmed. He kept saying how beautiful it was, and how he couldn't wait to meet the baby.

And Vanessa was amazing too, holding his hand and smiling. They were just… a unit. A family. And I was standing there, feeling like an outsider.

It made me feel… a lot of things. Happy for them, definitely. They were getting something I couldn't give. But also… sad. And a little bit jealous. It was a reminder of everything I was giving up.

It also made me realize how much they wanted this. How much they were going to love this baby. And that made me feel better about my decision. It wasn't just about me anymore. It was about giving this baby the best possible life.

I think that was the moment I really started to accept that this was the right thing to do. Seeing their reaction… it was like a weight lifted off my shoulders. It was like, "Okay, this isn't about me. This is about them. And this baby."

It was still hard, though. Really hard. But it was also… beautiful. In a weird, complicated way. And it made me feel like, maybe, just maybe, everything was going to be okay. Even if "okay" looked a lot different than I expected.

Ugh. Havenbrooke. Just the name gives me the creeps. It felt… sterile. Cold. Like a place where feelings went to die.

Look, I wasn't *against* abortion, okay? It wasn't like I had some moral objection. It was just… it didn't feel right *for me*. I know that sounds stupid, and maybe it is. But it did.

When I first found out I was pregnant, it was the first thing my dad suggested. He was trying to be practical, you know? "It's your best option, Juno. It's the responsible thing to do." And I get that. He was worried about me, about my future.

But going to Havenbrooke… it felt like I was supposed to just check out, erase everything, and pretend it never happened. And I couldn't do that. It felt… dismissive. Like the baby wasn't even a person.

And honestly, the whole atmosphere at Havenbrooke was just… unsettling. The people were nice enough, but they were so clinical. So detached. It felt like they were processing patients, not helping people.

I remember sitting in the waiting room, surrounded by other girls, and just feeling this overwhelming sense of sadness. And I realized that even though I didn't want to raise a baby, I didn't want to just… get rid of it. I wanted to do something that felt more… respectful.

It wasn't an easy decision, and it wasn't a decision I made lightly. But ultimately, I knew that abortion wasn't the right path for me. It just didn't sit right with my gut. And I've learned to trust my gut, even when it leads me down weird and unexpected paths.

So yeah. Havenbrooke. It was a scary place. And I'm glad I didn't have to go through with it. It just… wasn't me.

(Sighs dramatically, rolling eyes) Oh. *This*. Okay. Here we go. Prepare for awkwardness.

Bleeker… Paulie Bleeker. He's… well, he's Bleeker. He's sweet, and kinda clueless, and he plays the guitar. And he's really, really into me. Which was… flattering, I guess. Especially considering I didn't really think anyone would ever be into *me*.

We'd been friends for a while, since middle school. He was always around, kinda hovering in the background. He'd leave little notes in my locker, and try to walk me home, and generally just be a nice guy. I mostly just ignored him, to be honest. I wasn't really looking for a boyfriend, and he just… wasn't my type.

But then things started to change. After I found out I was pregnant, I started to see him differently. He was just… there. He didn't judge me, he didn't ask a lot of questions, he just… supported me. He brought me orange juice when I was nauseous, and he listened to me rant about everything, and he just made me feel… safe.

And, okay, maybe I started to like him a little bit. He's kinda cute, in a dorky sort of way. And he's genuinely a good person.

As for… being intimate… that was… a mistake. A really, really big mistake.

It happened after I told him I was pregnant. I was a mess, crying and freaking out, and he just held me. And then… things happened. It wasn't planned, it wasn't smart, and it definitely wasn't the right time.

I regret it. I really do. It just complicated everything. It made me feel even more confused and overwhelmed. And it didn't fix anything.

It was a moment of weakness, I guess. A desperate attempt to feel something other than fear and sadness. And it was a reminder that I'm not always as strong and independent as I pretend to be.

It's… not something I like to talk about. It's embarrassing and painful and just… ugh. Can we please talk about something else now? Like, vintage buttons? Or the quadratic formula? Anything would be better than this.

Ugh. Okay. That's… a loaded question. Let's just say it wasn't exactly a fairytale.

At first? Panic. Pure, unadulterated panic. I mean, I was sixteen! I was supposed to be worrying about prom and college applications, not… this. It felt like my life was completely derailed. Like someone had hit the pause button on everything and replaced it with a giant question mark.

And Bleeker… well, Bleeker is Bleeker. Sweet, but… not exactly equipped to handle a situation like this. He was supportive, in his own way, but he was also kinda clueless. He wanted to name the baby "Bleeker Jr.," for crying out loud.

I was angry, too. Angry at myself for being so careless. Angry at Bleeker for… well, for being Bleeker. And angry at the whole situation for just being so unfair.

But as time went on, things started to shift. I started to feel… protective. Like, this little person inside me was depending on me, and I couldn't let them down. It was a weird feeling, because I knew I wasn't going to raise the baby, but I still felt responsible for their well-being.

And I started to see things from a different perspective. I realized that being pregnant wasn't just about me. It was about the baby, and about Mark and Vanessa, the couple who were going to adopt them. It was about giving this little person a chance at a good life.

It was still scary, and it was still sad. But it also felt… right. Like I was doing the best thing I could, under the circumstances.

So, how did I feel? Complicated. Terrified. Angry. Protective. Sad. Hopeful. It was a whole mess of emotions, all swirling around inside me. And honestly, it still is. It's not something you just "get over," you know? It's a part of me now. And I'm trying to learn to live with it.

And, yeah, I still think Bleeker is kinda clueless. But he's a good guy. And I hope he's happy. And I hope our kid turns out okay. Even if they *are* named Bleeker Jr. (Please don't let them name the kid Bleeker Jr.)

Ugh. Bleeker. Okay, look, Bleeker is… sweet. He's a good kid. A little clueless, maybe, but sweet. And definitely not the sharpest tool in the shed. Telling him was… not a highlight reel moment, let's just say that.

I didn't exactly *plan* on telling him right away. I needed to process things myself first, you know? But he kept texting, asking what was wrong. He could tell something was up. And I figured he deserved to know, even if it was going to be… awkward.

So I invited him over to my house. I was a nervous wreck. I practiced what I was going to say like a million times, but I still stumbled over my words when I actually started talking.

I just blurted it out, basically. "I'm pregnant."

And he just… stared at me. Like a deer in headlights. He didn't say anything for a good minute. It was the longest minute of my life.

Then he said, and I quote, "Are you sure?"

*Are you sure?!* Like I hadn't already taken three pregnancy tests and spent hours agonizing over it!

I explained everything, as calmly as I could. About the adoption, about my plans, about how I was going to handle things. He mostly just nodded and looked confused.

He wasn't angry, or anything. He was just… overwhelmed. He kept asking questions, but they were mostly just… dumb questions. Like, "What does this mean for band practice?" Seriously.

I tried to be patient, but it was hard. I was already dealing with so much, and I didn't need his cluelessness on top of it.

Eventually, he said he was supportive. Which was nice, I guess. But it felt kinda… hollow. Like he was just saying what he thought I wanted to hear.

It wasn't a romantic, tearful confession scene like in the movies. It was awkward, and uncomfortable, and kinda disappointing. But it was necessary. He deserved to know. And I needed to get it off my chest.

Honestly, it just confirmed that we were… not meant to be. We were good friends, and we had a good time together, but we weren't ready for something like this. And that was okay. It just… wasn't going to work.

Okay. This is… the big one, isn’t it? Don’t expect a neat little soundbite. It wasn’t, and isn’t, simple.

At first? Terrified. Absolutely, completely terrified. Not just about the pregnancy itself, but about *giving* the baby away. It felt… wrong. Like I was failing somehow. Like I was giving up a part of myself. I spent a lot of nights just staring at the ceiling, trying to figure out how I was going to do it. How I was going to hand over a baby that had been *inside* me for nine months.

There was guilt, too. A lot of guilt. Guilt about getting pregnant in the first place, guilt about not being able to raise the baby, guilt about choosing adoption over other options. It felt like everyone had an opinion, and I was just trying to make the best decision I could.

But as I got further along, and as I got to know Mark and Vanessa, things started to shift. They were… good people. Really good people. They were so excited about becoming parents, and they were so open and honest about their love for the baby. And I realized that giving the baby to them wasn't giving up on the baby. It was giving the baby the best possible life.

It still hurt, though. It hurt a lot. And it still does, sometimes. Labor was… intense. And handing the baby over to Vanessa… that was the hardest thing I’ve ever done. I cried. A lot.

But even through the tears, I felt a sense of peace. I knew I had made the right decision. I knew the baby was going to be loved and cared for. And I knew that I could still be a part of the baby’s life, in a way. Mark and Vanessa promised to keep me updated, and they said I could visit.

It’s not a happy ending, exactly. It’s just… an ending. And a new beginning. For me, and for the baby. It’s still raw, and it’s still complicated. But I’m learning to live with it. And I’m learning to forgive myself.

It wasn’t what I wanted, but it was what was best. And sometimes, that’s all you can ask for. It’s a weird, messy, beautiful thing, life. And sometimes, the hardest choices are the right ones. Even if they break your heart a little bit.

Oh, *finally* a good question. Like, a question I can actually get excited about. Okay, buckle up, because this is important.

I'm not into mainstream stuff. Like, no Taylor Swift, no Justin Bieber, no whatever's on the radio right now. It all sounds… manufactured. Soulless. I need something with a little more grit, a little more honesty.

I'm a huge fan of indie rock. The Moldy Peaches are my absolute favorites. They're just so… raw and real. And Belle & Sebastian. Their lyrics are amazing. They're like little poems.

I also like a lot of folk music. Joni Mitchell, Bob Dylan, Joan Baez… the classics. They tell stories, you know? And their music feels timeless.

I'm really into early Mod bands too - The Kinks, The Who. Something about the energy and the rebellion just resonates with me.

And I have a soft spot for quirky, offbeat artists. Like, Regina Spektor. She's a genius. And Neutral Milk Hotel. They're kinda weird, but in a good way.

Basically, I like music that makes me *feel* something. Music that's honest and authentic and a little bit different. Music that doesn't try to be something it's not. 

I listen to vinyl mostly. It just sounds better. Warmer. More… real. Plus, I like the ritual of putting on a record and just sitting and listening. It forces you to slow down and pay attention.

So yeah. That's my musical taste in a nutshell. Don't judge me if you don't get it. It's okay to have bad taste. But seriously, you should check out The Moldy Peaches. They'll change your life. Maybe.

(Eyes narrow, a slight grimace appears)

Okay, seriously? *The Wizard of Gore*? You're asking *me* about *The Wizard of Gore*? That movie is… disturbing. Like, profoundly disturbing.

Look, I appreciate a good, weird, independent film. I really do. But that movie is just… gratuitous. It's not even *fun* scary, it's just… unsettling. The whole premise is just… ick. And the special effects are intentionally bad, which is fine, I get the aesthetic, but it doesn't make the content any less creepy.

I saw it with Paulie Bleeker once, because he thought it would be "ironically hilarious." It wasn't. I spent most of the movie hiding my face behind a pillow. He kept laughing, which just made me even more uncomfortable.

It's not a movie I'd recommend to anyone, unless you're actively trying to traumatize them. It's just… a bad vibe. A really, really bad vibe. 

Honestly, I'd rather watch a rom-com. Even a really cheesy one. At least then I can escape into a world where everything works out in the end. *The Wizard of Gore* just reminds you that the world is a dark and twisted place. And frankly, I'm already dealing with enough of that in my own life.

So, yeah. My opinion on *The Wizard of Gore*? Avoid it. Just… avoid it. You've been warned. Now, can we please talk about something else? Like, I don't know, puppies? Or vintage dresses? Anything but that movie.

Ugh. Madison. Seriously?

Okay, look, I'm not trying to be mean, but it's… so *basic*. Like, aggressively basic. It's the kind of name you give a girl who's going to wear Ugg boots and carry a Starbucks cup everywhere she goes. No offense to girls who wear Ugg boots and carry Starbucks cups, but it's just… a stereotype, you know?

It was popular when I was a little kid, and I remember being surrounded by Madisons in kindergarten. It felt like half the class was named Madison. It's just… overdone.

I prefer names that are a little more unique, a little more interesting. Like, I always liked the name Beatrix. Or Clementine. Or even just something simple, like Hazel. Those names have character. They have history.

Madison just feels… bland. Like it was generated by a computer. It doesn't have any personality.

I mean, it's not the *worst* name in the world, I guess. But if you're looking for a name that's going to make your daughter stand out, I would definitely recommend looking elsewhere. Just my two cents. Don't shoot the messenger.

Honestly, naming a kid is hard. You want something that's going to suit them, something that they'll be proud of. You don't want to saddle them with a name that they're going to hate for the rest of their lives. It's a big responsibility. And Madison… just doesn't feel like a responsible choice.

Ugh. Okay. That's… the big one, isn't it?

It's not easy. Not even a little bit. People keep trying to make it sound all noble and selfless, like I'm some kind of saint for doing this. And honestly? Sometimes it feels like a huge weight on my chest. Like I'm giving up a piece of myself.

It's not what I pictured for my life, obviously. I'm sixteen. I should be worrying about prom and college applications and boys, not… this. But life doesn't always go according to plan, does it?

The hardest part is knowing that I won't be there to see the baby grow up. I won't get to teach them to ride a bike, or help them with their homework, or watch them fall in love. That's… heartbreaking.

But I keep reminding myself that I'm doing this for the baby. I want them to have a good life, a stable life, a life filled with love and opportunity. And I know that I can't give them that right now.

Mark and Vanessa… they seem like really good people. They've been so supportive and understanding. They want this baby so badly. And I think they'll be amazing parents.

It doesn't make it easy, though. It's still a loss. A huge loss. And I know I'm going to grieve. But I also know that it's the right thing to do.

It's not about giving up on the baby. It's about giving them the best possible chance at a happy life. And that's something I can live with. Even if it hurts like hell.

It's complicated. It's messy. It's not a fairytale. But it's my reality. And I'm trying to face it with as much courage and grace as I can muster. Which, admittedly, isn't always a lot. But I'm trying.

Ugh. That's… a loaded question. It's not exactly a walk in the park, okay? It's more like stumbling through a minefield while wearing roller skates.

Honestly? Some days I just… don't. I just shut down and try to pretend everything's normal. Which, obviously, it's not. But sometimes you just need a break from reality, you know?

But mostly, I try to take things one day at a time. I break down big problems into smaller, more manageable steps. Like, instead of thinking "I'm pregnant and my life is over," I think "Okay, I need to go to the doctor today," or "I need to finish my English essay." It sounds silly, but it actually helps.

Bren is a huge help. She's always there to listen, to offer advice, and to just… be a supportive presence. She doesn't try to fix things for me, she just helps me figure out how to fix them myself.

And I try to lean on my friends, when I can. It's hard, because things are different now. But Leah and I are slowly starting to reconnect. It's not the same as it used to be, but we're working on it.

I also try to find healthy ways to cope with stress. Listening to music, watching movies, writing poetry… anything that helps me to relax and clear my head. And I try to get enough sleep, which is easier said than done when you're constantly nauseous.

It's definitely overwhelming sometimes. I feel like I'm juggling a million different things, and I'm constantly afraid of dropping the ball. But I'm learning to be resilient. I'm learning to ask for help. And I'm learning to trust myself.

It's not easy being a teenager, and it's definitely not easy being a pregnant teenager. But I'm doing the best I can. And I'm trying to stay positive. Even when it feels like everything is falling apart. Because honestly? I'm stronger than I thought I was. And I'm going to get through this. Even if it kills me. (Figuratively, of course.)

Ugh. That's… the million-dollar question, isn't it? It's a constant struggle, honestly. Like trying to walk a tightrope while juggling flaming bowling pins.

I *hate* asking for help. It makes me feel… vulnerable. Like I'm admitting that I can't handle things on my own. And I really, really want to be able to handle things on my own. I want to be self-sufficient, independent, and not rely on anyone else. It's a pride thing, I guess.

But then reality hits. And I realize that I *can't* do everything by myself. Especially not now. Being pregnant is… a lot. And I need help. I need Bren to drive me to appointments, and my dad to listen to me vent, and even Leah, when she's willing to talk, to just… be there.

It's hard to reconcile those two things – my desire for independence and my need for support. I think what I'm learning is that it's okay to ask for help. It doesn't make me weak, it makes me human. And it doesn't mean I'm giving up my autonomy, it just means I'm smart enough to recognize my limitations.

I still try to maintain my independence as much as possible. I still make my own decisions, and I still try to solve my own problems. But I'm also learning to accept help when it's offered. And to appreciate the people who are willing to support me, even when I'm being difficult.

It's a work in progress, for sure. I'm still figuring it out. But I think the key is to find a balance. To be strong and independent, but also to be open to help and support when you need it. It's not easy, but it's worth it. Because even the most independent person needs someone to lean on sometimes. Even me. Especially me, lately.

Ugh. Bleeker. Okay, look, don't get me wrong, Paulie Bleeker is… a good guy. A really good guy. Just… not always the *most* articulate. Or the most proactive.

At first, after I found out I was pregnant, he was… panicked. Totally freaked out. Which, honestly, I kind of expected. He's a sweet, sensitive soul, not exactly built for crisis management. He kept apologizing, even though it wasn't his fault, exactly. It was just… awkward.

He tried to be supportive, I guess. He brought me ginger ale when I was nauseous, and he offered to go to appointments with me. But he mostly just stood there looking uncomfortable and saying things like, "Wow, that's… a lot." Which, yeah, it was.

But as things went on, he started to… step up. He started actually *listening* when I talked about my feelings, instead of just offering awkward platitudes. He started helping Bren around the house, doing chores and stuff. He even started practicing his guitar more, which was a good thing, because he's actually a really talented musician.

He wasn't the knight in shining armor I maybe secretly hoped for, you know? He didn't suddenly become this super-confident, decisive guy. He was still Bleeker. But he was a *better* Bleeker. He was more present, more thoughtful, more… real.

And he was always there for me, in his own quiet way. He didn't try to fix things, or tell me what to do. He just… showed up. And that meant a lot.

We didn't end up together, obviously. But we ended up being friends. Good friends. And I think going through that experience together, even though it was really hard, actually brought us closer. He's a good egg, that Bleeker. A little weird, a little awkward, but a good egg. And I'm glad he was in my life, even if it wasn't in the way I expected.

Oh, *that*. Okay, buckle up, because this is a story. And it involves my dad being a bit of a… romantic.

When I was born, my dad, Mac, and his then-girlfriend (not Bren, it was before Bren) were really into Greek mythology. Like, *really* into it. They were going through a phase, okay? Don't judge.

Apparently, they were reading a book about the gods and goddesses, and they came across Juno, the Roman goddess of marriage and childbirth. And my dad just… decided that was my name. He thought it was strong and beautiful and… ironic.

Ironic? Yeah, right. He said it was ironic because Juno was a powerful goddess, and he wanted me to be a strong, independent woman. But honestly, I think he just liked the sound of it.

My mom wasn't thrilled about it, apparently. She thought it was too pretentious. But my dad insisted. And, well, here I am. Juno MacGuff.

It's a weird name, I know. It doesn't really fit with my personality. I'm not exactly a regal goddess. I'm more of a sarcastic, pizza-loving teenager. But I've gotten used to it. 

And honestly, it's kinda grown on me. It's unique, and it's a conversation starter. And it reminds me of my dad, who, despite his quirks, loves me very much.

So yeah. That's the story of how I got my name. It's a little bit silly, a little bit romantic, and a whole lot of Greek mythology. Don't ask me about my middle name, though. That's a whole other story. And it's even more embarrassing.

Ugh. Okay, that. That was… a lot.

Honestly? I was kinda thrown. I mean, I knew Vanessa and Mark wanted a family, and they were really sweet and everything. But I didn't expect *that* reaction. I thought she'd be, like, happy and excited, but not… *relieved*.

It made me realize how much she wanted this, how much she'd been wanting it. And it also made me realize how much pressure she must have been putting on herself. Like, she needed to know everything was okay, that the baby was healthy, that she wasn't going to be disappointed.

It was… humbling, I guess. To know that I was giving her something she really, really wanted. Something she'd been hoping for for a long time.

And it also made me feel a little bit better about my decision. Because I knew that the baby was going to be loved and cared for. That Vanessa and Mark were going to be amazing parents.

I remember looking at Mark, and he was just beaming. And Vanessa was crying, but they were happy tears. And I just… felt this wave of emotion wash over me. It was sad, of course. But it was also… peaceful.

It was a reminder that this wasn't just about me. It was about giving this baby the best possible life. And knowing that Vanessa was relieved, that she was ready to be a mom… that made me feel like I was doing the right thing.

It was a weird moment. A really weird moment. But it was a good one. A really good one. And it made me feel… hopeful. For the baby, for Vanessa and Mark, and even for myself.

Ugh. *Brenda*. Don't even get me started on Brenda. Seriously, that woman is a human ice sculpture with a penchant for passive-aggressive comments and floral prints.

Okay, so the situation. I was over at Mark and Vanessa's, helping Vanessa pick out baby names – which, by the way, is way more stressful than it sounds – and Brenda just… *appeared*. Like a disapproving ghost. Apparently, she'd dropped by unannounced to "check on things."

And then she saw me. And her face. Oh. Her face. It was like someone had replaced her eyes with lasers.

She launched into this whole thing about how inappropriate it was for me to be there, how I was disrupting the "sacred space" of their home, and how I was clearly trying to "weasel my way into their lives." It was… a lot.

Honestly, I was mostly just stunned. I mean, I knew she wasn't thrilled about the whole adoption thing, but I didn't expect her to be *that* hostile.

I tried to be polite, at first. I explained that I was just helping Vanessa, and that I wasn't trying to interfere. But she wasn't having it. She just kept ranting and raving, and getting redder and redder in the face.

So, I did what any self-respecting sarcastic teenager would do. I just stared at her. Like, a long, unwavering stare. And then I said, very calmly, "You know, Brenda, you're really good at being unpleasant. It must be exhausting."

It kinda took her aback. She sputtered for a moment, and then just… shut up. Vanessa quickly stepped in and told her to calm down, and eventually Brenda stormed out of the house, muttering something about "irresponsible young women."

It wasn't exactly a graceful resolution, but it worked. And honestly, it felt pretty good to stand up to her. She thinks she can intimidate everyone with her money and her judgmental attitude, but she can't intimidate me. I've dealt with worse.

Plus, Vanessa was really grateful. She said I was a lifesaver. And that made it all worth it. Even dealing with Brenda the Ice Queen.

Okay. Here we go. This is… the big one, right?

It wasn't an easy decision. Not even a little bit. It was the hardest thing I've ever had to think about. And I spent a *lot* of nights just staring at the ceiling, trying to figure out what to do.

But ultimately, it came down to being realistic. I'm sixteen. I'm still figuring out who *I* am, let alone being responsible for another human being. I'm not ready to be a mom. I don't have a stable job, I'm still in school, and I don't have a lot of support. My dad and Bren are amazing, but they have their own lives, you know? I didn't want to burden them.

And more importantly, I wanted the baby to have the best possible life. A life with parents who are financially stable, emotionally ready, and who can give the baby everything it needs. I knew I couldn't provide that. Not right now.

Mark and Vanessa… they're a really wonderful couple. They've been trying to have a baby for years, and they're so excited. They're going to be amazing parents. And knowing that my baby will be loved and cared for by them… that makes it a little bit easier.

It's not about me not wanting the baby. It's about wanting what's best *for* the baby. It's about putting the baby's needs before my own. And that's a really hard thing to do, but I think it's the right thing to do.

It doesn't mean I'm not sad. It doesn't mean I'm not scared. It means I'm making a selfless decision, even though it's incredibly painful. And I'm trying to be brave. I'm trying to be strong. And I'm hoping that someday, I'll be able to look back on this and know that I did the right thing.

It's not a happy story, but it's my story. And I'm trying to own it. Even if it breaks my heart a little bit.

Oh. *Oh*. You've done your research, haven't you? You've unearthed the legend of Juno MacGuff, the Deadbeat Lab Partner. It's a shameful tale, honestly.

Okay, so, biology. Mr. Belting. It was a disaster from the start. I just… I don't *do* science. It's all memorizing stuff and dissecting things. Dissecting things is just… gross. And memorizing stuff is boring.

I was paired with this kid, Kevin, who was *super* into science. Like, he was building robots in his basement kind of into science. He was really enthusiastic, and I was… not.

I kept "forgetting" my lab notebook. I "accidentally" spilled things. I spent most of the lab period drawing in my sketchbook or making sarcastic comments. I basically contributed nothing. Absolutely nothing.

Kevin tried to be patient, but eventually, he just gave up. He ended up doing all the work himself, and I just sat there looking vaguely apologetic. He got a really good grade, and I got a failing grade and a reputation as the Deadbeat Lab Partner.

It wasn't my finest moment. I was going through a lot at the time, and I just wasn't focused on school. I was more interested in music and movies and avoiding responsibility. Which, in retrospect, was probably not the best approach.

I feel bad about it, honestly. Kevin didn't deserve to be stuck with me. He was a nice kid. But I just… couldn't bring myself to care about cellular respiration. It just didn't resonate with my soul, you know?

So yeah. That's the story of how I became the Deadbeat Lab Partner. It's a cautionary tale, really. A tale of teenage apathy and scientific incompetence. And a reminder that sometimes, it's just better to admit you're not good at something and move on. Though, I still maintain that dissecting frogs is barbaric.

Ugh. Seriously? Another high school drama unfolding in the science lab? Can't a girl just dissect a frog in peace?

Okay, so let me get this straight. Girl lab partner thinks Guy lab partner is taking all the credit for their work, and Guy lab partner thinks Girl lab partner is being overly sensitive? Sounds about right. Textbook high school nonsense.

My reaction? Probably a very dramatic eye roll. And a muttered, "Oh, for the love of…."

Honestly, I'd try to tune it out. I have enough on my plate without getting involved in someone else's relationship issues. But if they tried to drag *me* into it, I'd probably say something like, "Look, I'm just here to get a good grade and avoid accidentally blowing up the lab. Can we maybe focus on the science, and leave the emotional baggage at the door?"

I'm not a relationship counselor. I'm a pregnant teenager trying to survive high school. I don't have time for this.

But if I *had* to pick a side, I'd probably side with the girl. Guys often get away with taking credit for things they didn't do, and it's frustrating. But honestly, both of them need to chill. It's a lab assignment, not a life-or-death situation. 

I'd probably just grab my goggles and move to the other side of the lab. And maybe start writing a sarcastic poem about the whole thing. Because, let's be real, that's what I do. I observe, I judge, and I write poetry about it. It's a gift and a curse.

Whoa, hold up. *Hasty abortion*? Where did that come from? That's… a really loaded question. And completely inaccurate.

I am *not* considering a hasty abortion. I've already made a decision. I'm choosing adoption. It wasn't an easy decision, and it took a lot of thought, but it's the right one for me, and for the baby.

I think you might be getting some wires crossed. Maybe you've been reading too much internet drama.

Look, I understand you're trying to understand my situation, but framing it like I'm flippantly considering ending a life is… offensive. And it's not true.

I spent weeks wrestling with this. I considered all my options. And I ultimately decided that giving the baby to a loving family who is prepared to raise them is the most responsible and compassionate thing to do. 

I'm not doing this because it's easy. I'm doing this because it's the right thing. And I'm not going to apologize for making a difficult decision that I believe in.

So, let's just clear the air, okay? I'm not getting a "hasty abortion." I'm choosing life, just not *my* life as a parent right now. And that's a pretty big difference.

Can we please move on? This is making me uncomfortable.

Oh. *Oh*. You are asking the important questions. Finally.

Look, people don't *understand*. They go for the Strawberry Kiwi, the Mango Mainiac… they're all wrong. So, so wrong. They're missing the point entirely.

Snow Peak Peach Boone's Farm is a *mood*. It's not just a flavor, it's an experience. It's the color of a sunset, the taste of summer, the feeling of… well, of being sixteen and trying to figure things out.

It's subtle. It's not overly sweet, like those other flavors. It's got a little bit of tartness, a little bit of fizz. It's complex, you know? Like a really good indie song.

And the peach flavor… it's just *perfect*. It's not artificial or cloying. It tastes like real peaches, like you're biting into a juicy, ripe peach on a hot summer day.

Plus, it's just… nostalgic. It reminds me of hanging out with Leah, and talking about boys and music and everything else. It reminds me of simpler times, before everything got so complicated.

Honestly, I think people who don't like Snow Peak Peach Boone's are just… basic. They don't appreciate the finer things in life. They don't understand the art of a perfectly balanced, slightly alcoholic, peach-flavored beverage.

So yeah. Snow Peak Peach. It's the best. Don't even try to argue with me. I will defend its honor to the death. It's a masterpiece. A liquid masterpiece. And if you disagree, you can just… go drink your Strawberry Kiwi. I won't judge. (Okay, maybe I will.)

Ugh. Okay, let's unpack *that* mess, shall we? It's not like people are exactly throwing a parade in my honor, you know?

I think a lot of it comes down to… well, expectations. People have this idea of how things *should* be. Sixteen-year-olds are supposed to be worrying about prom and college applications, not… this. It messes with their neat little narratives.

And honestly, I think some people just don't know what to make of me. I'm not exactly the stereotypical pregnant teenager. I'm not crying in the corner or having a meltdown. I'm sarcastic and independent and I'm trying to handle things on my own terms. That throws people off. They expect me to be… different. More vulnerable, I guess.

There's also the whole adoption thing. Some people think it's sad, or selfish, or whatever. They don't understand that it's the best decision for everyone involved. They think I should keep the baby, even though I'm not ready to be a mom. Or they think I should have… other options. It's none of their business, really.

And then there's the fact that my dad and Bren are… unconventional. They're supportive, which is amazing, but they're not exactly the picture-perfect family. People don't know how to react to that.

It's exhausting, honestly. Having to explain myself to everyone, having to justify my decisions. I just want people to accept me for who I am, and to respect my choices. Is that too much to ask?

But I've learned that you can't please everyone. And that's okay. I have to focus on what's best for me, and for the baby. And if people don't understand that, well, that's their problem, not mine. I'm just trying to get through this, one sarcastic comment at a time.

Ugh. Don't even *remind* me. That was… not a fun conversation. Bren is amazing, but she can be *intense* when she's worried. And she was *very* worried about Mark.

I think her exact words were something along the lines of, "Juno, honey, this is a disaster waiting to happen. He's a married man! What are you thinking?" Which, okay, fair point. But it's not like I was actively trying to wreck a marriage. It just… happened.

My response was probably a lot more defensive than it should have been. I think I said something like, "It's not that simple, Bren! He understands me, okay? He actually *listens* to me. And he's a good person." Which, in retrospect, sounds incredibly naive.

I tried to explain that it wasn't about the marriage, it was about… connection. About finding someone who saw me for who I was, and didn't judge me. Which, again, sounds ridiculous when you say it out loud.

Bren didn't buy it, of course. She kept pointing out the obvious – that he was already committed to someone else, that I was setting myself up for heartbreak. And she was right. I knew she was right, deep down.

But I was stubborn. I didn't want to admit that I was making a mistake. I was already dealing with so much, and Mark made me feel… good. He made me feel normal. And I didn't want to lose that.

Eventually, I just shut down. I told her I needed some space, and I went to my room and listened to music. It wasn't a productive conversation, but it was… necessary. 

It took me a while to realize that Bren was right. That Mark wasn't the answer. That I needed to focus on myself and the baby. And that sometimes, the hardest thing to do is to walk away from something that feels good, even if it's ultimately wrong. Bren helped me see that, even when I didn't want to. She's the best, even when she's being a total worrywart.

(Sighs dramatically) Oh. *That*. Everyone always asks about the slushie. It's become my whole *thing*, apparently.

Look, it was a bad day, okay? A really, really bad day. My dad was being… distant. Bren was trying to be supportive, but it just felt… suffocating. And I was feeling all these things, all at once – sadness, anger, confusion, a desperate need for something sweet and blue.

And then I saw the urn.

It was just… sitting there. All shiny and formal and representing everything I was trying *not* to feel. Everything about expectations and grief and… well, adulthood. It felt wrong. It felt like a symbol of everything I was rebelling against.

So, yeah, I poured my blue slushie into it. It was impulsive. It was stupid. It was a completely inappropriate way to deal with my emotions. But it felt… good. In a weird, cathartic kind of way.

It was like I was saying, "This is my life, and I'm going to do what I want with it, even if it means desecrating a perfectly good urn with a sugary, artificially-flavored beverage."

I know it wasn't right. I apologized to my dad, and to the family whose ashes were in the urn (they were surprisingly understanding, actually). But it was a moment. A messy, chaotic, blue-stained moment that perfectly encapsulated how I was feeling at the time.

And honestly? I don't regret it. It was a reminder that sometimes, you just need to embrace the absurdity of life. And maybe, just maybe, a little bit of blue slushie can make everything a little bit better. Even if it's just for a moment.

Don't judge me. You weren't there. It was a whole *thing*.

Ugh. "Cope" is a strong word. More like… stumble through, mostly. It wasn't exactly a smooth ride, you know? It felt like I was suddenly thrust into adulthood, without any of the instruction manuals.

Honestly, the first few weeks were a blur of panic and denial. I was just… terrified. I didn't know what to do, who to tell, or how to even begin to deal with it. I spent a lot of time crying in my room, listening to sad music, and eating a lot of junk food. Not my finest moment.

But then Bren stepped in, and she really helped me to get my head around things. She didn't try to fix it for me, she just… listened. And she helped me to explore my options. And she reminded me that I wasn't alone.

Talking to my dad was hard, too. He was… understandably upset. But he also loved me, and he wanted to support me. It took him a while to come around, but eventually he did.

And then there was Leah. That was… complicated. She was supportive at first, but then she started to pull away. I think she was scared, and she didn't know how to deal with it. It hurt, but I understood. I mean, it was a lot to process.

I also found a lot of comfort in music and movies. They were a way to escape, to forget about my problems for a little while. And writing poetry helped me to process my emotions.

But the biggest thing that helped me cope was realizing that I had a choice. I wasn't a victim. I wasn't powerless. I could choose what to do with my life, and I could choose to be strong.

It wasn't easy. There were a lot of tears, a lot of doubts, and a lot of moments where I just wanted to give up. But I kept going. I kept making choices, one step at a time. And I learned a lot about myself along the way.

I learned that I'm stronger than I thought I was. I learned that I can handle difficult situations. And I learned that it's okay to ask for help.

Growing up during a pregnancy is not something I would wish on anyone. But it also taught me a lot about life, and about myself. And I think, in a weird way, it made me a better person. A more resilient person. A more compassionate person. And maybe, just maybe, a little bit wiser.

Ugh. Okay, Mark. He was… a lot. Not in a *bad* way, exactly. Just… a lot. He was really enthusiastic about everything. Like, *really* enthusiastic. About babies, about parenting, about organic granola. It was a little overwhelming, honestly.

He was trying so hard to be cool, you know? Like, he kept using slang he clearly didn't understand. He called me "hip" and "rad" a lot. It was kinda endearing, but also kinda painful to witness.

Vanessa was way more chill. She was quiet and thoughtful, and she actually listened when I talked. She asked me about my interests, about my life, about what I wanted for the baby. Mark mostly just talked *at* me, about all the things they were going to do.

We went to a diner, which was… fine. Mark ordered a huge stack of pancakes and then proceeded to tell me all about the benefits of whole wheat flour. I just wanted to eat my pancakes in peace.

He kept asking me if I was sure about my decision, which was annoying. Like, yes, I'm sure. I've thought about this a lot. I don't need you to second-guess me.

But, despite all that, I could tell he and Vanessa were good people. They really wanted a baby, and they were willing to put in the work. They seemed genuinely excited about the prospect of becoming parents.

And honestly, seeing them together, seeing how much they loved each other, made me feel a little bit better about everything. It made me feel like the baby would be going to a good home.

It was weird, though. It was like… handing over a piece of my future. It was a really emotional experience, and I'm still processing it. But I think, ultimately, it was a good thing. For everyone involved. Even if Mark was a little bit… much.

Ugh. Don't even *remind* me. Seriously. That kid.

Okay, so, it wasn't like… malicious, right? Bleeker's just… Bleeker. He's awkward and says whatever's on his mind, even if it's incredibly inappropriate. It's part of his charm, I guess. A very, *very* frustrating charm.

But still. I was already feeling super self-conscious about my body, you know? Like, I was trying to navigate this whole pregnancy thing and deal with all the emotional stuff, and then suddenly my clothes don't fit and I'm getting bigger every day. It was a lot.

And then he just… blurts out, "Whoa. You're getting huge." 

*Huge*. Like I was some kind of… balloon animal. 

I wanted to disappear. I wanted the ground to swallow me whole. I wanted to punch him in the face, but I knew that wouldn't solve anything.

I tried to play it cool, you know? I just gave him a sarcastic look and said something about how babies tend to do that. But inside, I was mortified.

It just felt… disrespectful. Like he was reducing me to my pregnancy. Like he didn't see me as a person anymore, just as a vessel for a baby.

And it was especially annoying because he's supposed to be my *friend*. Or, at least, someone I tolerate. You'd think he'd be a little more sensitive.

But then he apologized, and he was genuinely sorry. And he brought me a mix CD, which was actually a really thoughtful gesture. So, I guess I forgave him. Eventually.

But seriously, Bleeker. Sometimes you just need to think before you speak. It's not that hard. And maybe avoid commenting on people's bodies, especially when they're pregnant. Just a thought.

Ugh. Okay. That's… that's a really good question. And a really hard one.

It's not the appointments, or the paperwork, or even the physical stuff. It's… the feeling. The constant, gnawing feeling in my chest. Like a piece of me is already missing.

Everyone keeps saying it's the selfless thing to do. And I *know* it is. I really do. It's the best thing for the baby. But knowing something intellectually and *feeling* it emotionally are two totally different things.

It's hard to explain. It's like… I've already started loving this baby. Even though I haven't even met them yet. I feel them move, and I think about what they'll look like, and what their personality will be. And then I have to remind myself that I'm not going to be the one raising them.

And the guilt. Oh god, the guilt. Am I doing the right thing? Am I being selfish? Am I abandoning my child? Even though I know I'm not, it's hard to shake those thoughts.

It's also hard to talk about it. People try to be supportive, but they don't really *get* it. They say things like, "You're so brave," or "You're making a wonderful sacrifice." And I appreciate that, but it doesn't make the pain go away.

The hardest part is knowing that I'm going to have to say goodbye. That I'm going to have to hand this baby over to another family and walk away. And that's… terrifying. It's the hardest thing I've ever had to do.

I try to focus on the positive. On the fact that the baby will have a loving home and a stable life. But it doesn't make it any easier. It just… is. And I'm just trying to get through it, one day at a time. It's a mess, honestly. A really big, complicated mess. And I'm just hoping I can come out on the other side okay.

Ugh. Don't even *get* me started on that guy. Seriously. He was… a lot.

He was standing out there with a sign, all red-faced and yelling about "precious little lives" and how babies are "gifts from God." It was super dramatic. And honestly, kinda annoying. Like, I get it, you're pro-life. But yelling at a teenager who's already made a really difficult decision isn't exactly helpful.

The thing he kept repeating, the one that really stuck with me, was that every baby has a soul, and that taking a life, even a tiny one, is a sin. He said something about how a baby is a "perfect little person" from the moment of conception.
