It was… intense. And it made me feel even more conflicted, if you can believe it. I already felt guilty and scared and overwhelmed, and then this guy just piled on the guilt. 

It wasn't about logic with him, it was about… faith. And I respect people's beliefs, I really do. But it felt like he wasn't seeing *me*. He wasn't seeing that I was a person with feelings and a future, too. He just saw me as someone making a "wrong" choice.

Honestly, it just made me even more determined to do what I thought was right. For me, and for the baby. And to ignore anyone who was trying to make me feel ashamed. It was a really awful experience, though. I still get a little shiver thinking about it. He was… a lot.

Ugh. Okay, this is… not a fun memory. But you asked.

It was at the clinic, right? After the… the confirmation. I was sitting in the waiting room, trying not to freak out, and this guy sat down next to me. Older guy, maybe in his fifties. Wearing a really loud Hawaiian shirt. Seriously, who wears a Hawaiian shirt to a clinic?

He just… started talking to me. Didn't even ask my name. Just launched right into this whole speech about how he'd been in the same situation, like, thirty years ago. He said his girlfriend had gotten pregnant, and they'd decided to have the baby, and it was the best decision he ever made.

He kept going on and on about how wonderful being a dad was, and how I'd regret it if I didn't choose life. He was all, "You'll never know a love like this!" and "It'll change your life!"

It wasn't that he was trying to be mean, exactly. He just… didn't get it. He didn't understand that this wasn't a simple decision. He didn't understand that I was sixteen, and scared, and completely unprepared to be a mom. He just assumed that everyone should have a baby, and that it would magically fix everything.

I tried to be polite, but honestly, I just wanted him to go away. I finally just said, "Look, sir, with all due respect, I appreciate your opinion, but this is a really personal decision, and I need to figure it out on my own."

He just kinda blinked at me, like he didn't know what to say. Then he mumbled something about praying for me and walked away.

It was just… frustrating. Like, I didn't need a lecture. I needed someone to listen. Someone to understand. Someone to just… be there.

It made me even more determined to make the right decision for *me*. And for the baby. Even if it wasn't the decision that guy thought I should make. It was just… a really awful encounter. And it reminded me why I'm so good at reading people. I could tell he meant well, but he was completely missing the point.

Ugh. Don't even *remind* me about Su-Chin. That girl is… a lot. And the whole Adderall thing? A disaster. A complete and utter disaster.

Okay, so, I was trying to be cool, right? Trying to fit in with the "popular" crowd, which is already a mistake in itself. And Su-Chin was talking about how she needed Adderall to focus on her studying, and how it helped her get good grades. And I, in my infinite wisdom, decided to chime in and say I thought it was kinda messed up that people felt like they *needed* drugs to function.

Big mistake. Huge.

Her face just… changed. Like, instantly. She went from being all bubbly and friendly to being icy and judgmental. She started lecturing me about how I didn't understand the pressures of being a high-achieving student, and how Adderall was just a tool to help her succeed. 

And then she started implying that I was just jealous because I wasn't as smart or ambitious as her. Which, okay, maybe I'm not aiming for valedictorian, but that doesn't mean I'm stupid!

It was so awkward. And embarrassing. And she just kept going on and on, and I just stood there feeling like a complete idiot. 

Then she said something about how I was probably just saying that because I was "different" and "weird." And that was it. I just turned around and walked away.

Honestly, it just confirmed my suspicions that Su-Chin is a total snob. And it reminded me why I prefer hanging out with people who are genuine and down-to-earth, rather than trying to impress people who are just… superficial.

The whole thing was just… ugh. I still cringe when I think about it. And I definitely learned my lesson about trying to engage in conversations with Su-Chin. Just… not worth it. Seriously.

Oh. *Oh*. You're asking about the clinic. Right. Okay. Deep breaths.

It wasn't one thing, exactly. It was… everything. The smell. It smelled like antiseptic and… sadness. Like a place where people went to deal with things they didn't want to deal with.

And the silence. It wasn't a peaceful silence. It was a heavy, suffocating silence. Like everyone was holding their breath, trying not to make a sound.

But mostly, it was the *people*.

There was this woman, she looked… really young. Younger than me, even. And she was clutching her purse so tight, her knuckles were white. She kept looking around, like she was trying to disappear.

And there was this older couple, holding hands. They looked scared and exhausted. Like they'd been through a lot.

And then there was this guy, just sitting there, staring straight ahead. He didn't seem to be reacting to anything. He just looked… empty.

Seeing all those people, all dealing with their own stuff… it just hit me. This wasn't just about me. This was about all of us. All of us making difficult choices, all of us trying to figure out what to do with our lives.

And that's when the terror really set in. It wasn't just fear of the procedure, or fear of what people would think. It was fear of the future. Fear of the unknown. Fear of messing everything up.

It was realizing that this was a turning point. That my life was about to change, forever. And that there was no going back.

It was… a lot. I just wanted to get out of there. I wanted to run away and hide. But I couldn't. I had to face it. I had to make a decision. And I had to do it alone.

Ugh. Just thinking about it makes my stomach churn. Can we talk about something else now? Please?

(Sighs dramatically, rolling eyes) Oh. *This*. Seriously? We're back to Bleeker?

Look, it's complicated, okay? It's not like I suddenly woke up one day and forgot about him. He's… he was a good guy. Sweet. A little awkward, sure, but genuinely kind. And he played the piano really well. That's a plus.

But things changed. A lot of things changed. I got pregnant, and he… well, he was supportive, in his own Bleeker-y way. But he wasn't ready for all of it. And honestly, neither was I. Not really.

I think I romanticized him a little bit. He was this quiet, artistic soul, and I was drawn to that. But we were both so young and messed up, and we didn't really know what we were doing. 

I still care about him, yeah. As a friend. But the romantic feelings? They've… faded. They had to. I needed to focus on myself, and on the baby. And he needed to focus on his music.

We still talk sometimes. He sends me texts, and we occasionally run into each other at school. It's… amicable. But it's not the same. It can't be.

I think we both realized that we were better off as friends. We just weren't meant to be together. It's sad, but it's true. 

So, yeah. Do I still have *feelings* for him? Maybe a little. But they're not the kind of feelings that would make a relationship work. And honestly, I'm okay with that. I'm learning to be okay with a lot of things.

Can we please talk about something else now? This is making me feel all mushy and sentimental, and I'm not really in the mood for mushy and sentimental.

Oh. *Oh boy*. Okay, look, Vanessa is a lovely woman. Truly. She's sweet, she's kind, she's… enthusiastic. And her decorating choices are… a lot.

She's going for a whole "woodland creatures" theme. Which, fine. Cute. But it's not just a few cute stuffed animals. It's *every* woodland creature. There are foxes and owls and deer and squirrels painted on the walls. And little mushroom-shaped lamps. And a mobile with felt leaves and acorns.

It's… overwhelming. It looks like a Disney movie threw up in there.

I tried to be polite, I really did. I said something like, "It's very… cozy." Which is a diplomatic way of saying it's bordering on claustrophobic.

Mark seems a little overwhelmed too, but he's too nice to say anything. He just kinda nods and smiles and tries to look enthusiastic.

Honestly, I'm a little worried the baby is going to have nightmares. Or develop a phobia of woodland creatures. 

I mean, I appreciate that they're putting so much effort into making the room special. But sometimes, less is more. A little bit of beige wouldn't kill anyone, Vanessa. Just sayin'.

I'm hoping it'll grow on me. Or at least, that I can avoid spending too much time in there. It's a little too… saccharine for my taste. I prefer things a little more… ironic. And definitely less furry.

Ugh. Don't even *start* with the nesting. It's… weird. Really weird.

Everyone keeps asking me about it. Bren, especially. "Have you picked out a color scheme, Juno? Are you thinking pastels or something more modern?" Like I'm suddenly going to transform into one of those Stepford wives who spends all day arranging tiny socks and alphabet blocks.

It feels… wrong. I'm not raising this baby. I'm giving it a chance at a life with parents who *want* to do all that stuff. It feels like I'm pretending, like I'm trying to force a connection that isn't there.

I mean, I'm happy for Mark and Vanessa. They're really excited about becoming parents, and they're already planning the nursery and buying baby clothes and everything. And I want them to be happy. But I don't want to be involved in the decorating. It just feels… too emotional.

I did help them pick out a few things, though. Mostly just practical stuff, like a car seat and a stroller. And I told them about some of the things I've learned about babies, like how much they sleep and how much they poop. (Seriously, babies poop *a lot*.)

But the whole "nesting" thing? No. That's not for me. I'm focusing on finishing school and figuring out my own future. I'm trying to be a good birth mom, but that doesn't mean I have to pretend to be a traditional mom.

It's complicated, okay? It's a lot of complicated feelings. And honestly, I just want it all to be over with. Not in a bad way, just… I want to move on with my life. And I want this baby to have the best possible life, with parents who are ready and willing to give it everything it needs. And that doesn't involve me painting a nursery pink.

Ugh, don't even *get* me started on those women. Seriously. It was like… stepping into another dimension. A dimension made entirely of cashmere and entitlement.

It wasn't even the shopping itself, it was the *way* they shopped. Like it was some kind of competitive sport. "Oh, you got a handbag? Well, *I* just got a handbag from Italy, darling." It was exhausting just watching them.

And the sales associates! They were practically bowing and scraping, offering them champagne and fawning over their every whim. It was ridiculous. Like they were royalty or something.

I mean, I get it. People like to treat themselves. But there's a difference between enjoying something and being completely detached from reality. They were talking about price tags like they were pocket change. It was… unsettling.

It just felt so… empty. All that stuff, all that money, and they still looked miserable. Like they were trying to fill a hole inside themselves with designer clothes and expensive shoes. It's kinda sad, actually.

It made me appreciate my thrift store finds even more. I mean, yeah, they're not designer, but they have character. They have a story. And they didn't cost a fortune. 

Honestly, it just reinforced my belief that money doesn't buy happiness. It just buys you more stuff. And sometimes, more stuff just makes you more miserable. It was a good reminder to stay grounded, I guess. And to stick to my vintage shopping. It's way more authentic. And way less… suffocating.

Ugh. Okay, that's… a big question. And honestly? It's terrifying.

Look, I'm sixteen. I'm still figuring out what *I* want to do with my life, let alone being responsible for another human being. The thought of changing diapers and dealing with sleepless nights and all that… it's overwhelming. Seriously.

I know a lot of people romanticize motherhood. They talk about the unconditional love and the joy and the fulfillment. And I'm sure that's all true, for some people. But I also know it's hard. Really hard. And I'm not sure I'm ready for that kind of hard.

That's why I made the decision to give the baby up for adoption. It wasn't an easy decision, but it felt like the right one. It allows me to give the baby a good life, with parents who are prepared and excited to raise them. And it allows me to focus on my own future.

But that doesn't mean I don't feel a sense of responsibility. I do. I'm still the baby's birth mother, and that's something I'll always be. I want to make sure the baby is happy and healthy, and that Mark and Vanessa are getting the support they need.

I'm also trying to learn from this experience. To become more responsible, more mature, more selfless. It's forcing me to grow up faster than I ever expected, and that's… scary. But also, maybe a little bit good.

I guess what I'm saying is, I'm not thrilled about the changes and responsibilities that come with motherhood. But I'm willing to face them, in my own way. And I'm hoping that, in the end, it will all be worth it. For the baby, and for me.

It's just… a lot. A whole lot. And sometimes I just want to curl up in a ball and pretend none of this is happening. But I can't. I have to be strong. For everyone involved. Even if I don't feel strong all the time.

Okay, this is… the big one, isn’t it? It’s not like I just randomly picked two people out of a hat. It’s not about finding the “perfect” parents, because honestly, who *is* perfect? It’s about finding the right fit.

And for me, that meant Mark and Vanessa. They’re… stable. That’s the biggest thing. They’ve been married for years, they have a nice house, they both have good jobs. They *want* a baby, and they’ve been trying for a long time. They’re not doing it to prove something, or to fill a void, or because everyone else is doing it. They just genuinely want to be parents.

I didn’t want the baby to go to someone who was, like, rich and fancy. That feels… weird. Like the baby is a status symbol or something. And I didn’t want them to go to someone who was going to try and replace the baby’s biological parents, or pretend that everything was perfect.

Mark and Vanessa are… real. They’re a little quirky, a little awkward, but they’re genuinely kind and loving. They told me they want the baby to know about me, about its story. They don’t want to erase my part in things. And that meant a lot to me.

They also seem like they’d appreciate a kid who’s… different. They’re not the most conventional people themselves. They’re open-minded and accepting, and they seem like they’d encourage the baby to be its own person.

It wasn’t about finding the “best” parents. It was about finding parents who would love the baby unconditionally, and who would give it a good life. And I really believe that Mark and Vanessa can do that. It still doesn’t make it easy, but it makes it… okay. A little bit. It’s the least I can do, you know? Give the baby the best chance possible.

Ugh. Okay, let's not pretend this is a fun thought experiment. It's not. But you asked.

If I kept the baby… it would be… a lot. Like, exponentially a lot.

First of all, school. I'd probably have to drop out, or at least switch to online classes. There's no way I could juggle being a full-time student and a full-time mom. And I *want* to finish school. I want to go to college, maybe study film. That feels important to me.

Then there's the financial stuff. My dad and Bren are amazing, but they're not exactly rolling in money. Raising a baby is expensive. Diapers, formula, clothes, healthcare… it all adds up. I don't want to be a burden on them.

And then there's just… my life. I'm sixteen. I haven't even started living yet. I want to travel, and explore, and figure out who I am. Having a baby would put all of that on hold. For a long time.

I'm not sure I'm ready for that kind of responsibility. I'm still figuring out how to take care of *myself*, let alone another human being. I'm impulsive and sarcastic and I have a tendency to say the wrong thing at the wrong time. Those aren't exactly qualities you want in a parent.

And honestly? I'm scared. Scared of failing, scared of not being good enough, scared of ruining the baby's life.

It's not that I don't love the idea of being a mom someday. It's just… not right now. I need time to grow up, to figure things out, to become the kind of person who can give a child the life they deserve.

So yeah. Those are some of the concerns. It's not a simple decision, and it's not one I take lightly. It's just… realistically, keeping the baby would be a huge obstacle to everything I want to achieve. And I don't think that would be fair to anyone involved.

Ugh. Leah. Don't even get me started. She was… intense about it.

When I told her I was thinking about adoption, she practically lost it. She was all, "But Juno, it's a *life*! You can't just… give it away!" Which, okay, I get that. It *is* a life. But what was I supposed to do? Raise a baby in my dad's basement while trying to finish high school?

She kept pushing me to consider raising it ourselves. Like, *we* could raise it. She even had a whole plan worked out. We'd get an apartment, she'd drop out of school, we'd both get jobs… it was completely unrealistic.

She said we could figure it out. That we were strong enough. That we could be a family. It sounded… nice, in a really chaotic, completely impractical way.

But I knew it wouldn't work. Leah's a great friend, but she's also kinda flaky. And I'm not ready to be a mom. I'm barely ready to be a teenager.

She didn't understand why I wanted to choose adoption. She thought I was being selfish. Which, honestly, stung. But I wasn't being selfish. I was being realistic. I was trying to do what was best for everyone involved.

It caused a huge fight between us. We haven't really been talking much since then. It's… sad. But I still think I'm making the right decision. Even if it means losing my best friend. Sometimes, you have to do what's right, even if it's hard. And Leah just… couldn't see that. She was too caught up in her own ideas of what my life should be.

Ugh. Okay, *that*. Seriously? You're bringing that up? It was a moment of weakness, alright? A lapse in judgment. A spectacularly bad decision fueled by hormones and general teenage angst.

Look, I was… overwhelmed. I was at the baby store with Bren, trying to pick out a car seat, and everything was just hitting me all at once. The reality of the situation, the fact that I was going to have a baby, the fact that I was giving it up… it was a lot to process.

And then I walked past that play area, and there were all these women, these *perfect* moms, all smiling and cooing at their kids. And I just… snapped. It was like, they had it all figured out, and I didn't have *anything* figured out.

So I made a stupid, insensitive comment about them being "Stepford wives." It was mean, and it was unfair, and I instantly regretted it. I was just lashing out because I was feeling insecure and scared.

I know it wasn't right. I apologized to Bren, and I feel terrible about it. It wasn't about those women, it was about my own feelings. It was about my own fear and uncertainty.

It was a really low moment for me, and I'm not proud of it. I try to be a good person, but sometimes I mess up. And that was a big mess-up.

Can we please move on now? I'd really rather not dwell on my past mistakes. Especially the really embarrassing ones.

Ugh. Okay, that. That was… a moment. A really weird moment. And honestly, I still kinda cringe when I think about it.

Look, I was nervous meeting Vanessa and Mark. Like, *super* nervous. This is my baby we're talking about. Giving it up for adoption is hard enough, but letting someone else… connect with it, physically? That's a whole other level of emotional complexity.

Vanessa is… nice. Really nice. Maybe *too* nice. She's got that whole nurturing, maternal vibe going on, and it's kinda intimidating. She was asking me about how I was feeling, and about the baby's movements, and I was just trying to be polite.

And then she just… reached out. And touched my belly.

It was so unexpected. I froze. I didn't know what to do. Part of me wanted to pull away, to protect myself and the baby. But another part of me… I don't know. I guess I wanted her to feel connected to the baby, too. I wanted her to understand that this isn't just some transaction. This is a real life, a real person.

It was a weird mix of wanting to be in control and wanting to let go. And honestly, it was a little bit comforting. It felt like she was acknowledging the baby, and acknowledging me.

I know it probably seemed strange to everyone else. Bren was giving me this look like, "Are you sure about this?" But in that moment, it felt… right. 

It doesn't mean I'm not still scared and sad about giving the baby up. It just means that I'm trying to be open to the possibility of a good outcome. And maybe, just maybe, letting Vanessa touch my belly was a small step towards that.

Don't judge me, okay? It was a complicated situation. And I'm still figuring things out.

Ugh, *that*. Yeah, people do that. It's… weird. And kinda annoying, if I'm being honest.

It's like they suddenly develop a pathological fear of accidentally bumping into a pregnant person. Like I'm some kind of fragile porcelain doll. I'm not! I'm still me, just with a slightly larger midsection.

I think it's a combination of things. First, there's the whole societal thing about protecting mothers and babies. Which is nice, I guess, but it's also kinda patronizing. Like I can't handle myself.

And then there's the fact that I'm obviously pregnant. It's a pretty visible sign that something's going on. People probably feel awkward, like they don't know what to say or do. So they just… move out of the way.

It's also probably the fact that I'm not exactly small to begin with. I'm not a tiny little thing, and now I'm carrying around extra weight. So I take up a lot of space. People probably just assume I'm going to plow right through them.

Honestly, I just try to ignore it. I've learned to navigate crowded hallways like a ninja. It's a survival skill, really. But it's still kinda weird. It's like I'm suddenly invisible, or… something.

It's a reminder that my body is no longer just *my* body. It's a public statement. And people have opinions about it, whether I want them to or not. It's… a lot. But hey, what can you do? Just keep walking, I guess. And try not to knock anyone over.

Ugh, okay, this is the part I've been dreading talking about. It's not that Mark and Vanessa *aren't* good people. They are. Seriously. They're like… the embodiment of a Norman Rockwell painting. Too perfect, almost.

It's just… it's hard to explain. They have this… life planned out. A beautiful house in the suburbs, a golden retriever, a 2.5 kids kind of vibe. And I'm worried my kid will feel like they have to *fit* into that life. Like they have to be perfect, and happy, and everything they expect.

I'm not saying they'd intentionally put pressure on the baby, but… it's just the way they are. They're very… organized. And I'm… not. And I don't want my kid to feel like they have to be someone they're not to be loved.

It sounds stupid, I know. I'm giving up the baby for adoption, and I'm worried about their future happiness? It's totally messed up. But I want them to have a good life, a *real* life, with all the messiness and imperfections that come with it.

I guess I'm scared that they'll try to erase my part in the baby's story. Like I never existed. And I want the baby to know where they came from, to know that I loved them, even though I couldn't raise them.

Bren keeps telling me I'm overthinking things, and that Mark and Vanessa are genuinely good people who will love the baby unconditionally. And I *want* to believe her. I really do. But it's still hard. It's like… giving up a piece of myself. And I want to make sure that piece is going to a place where it will be cherished, not just… displayed.

It's complicated, okay? It's not a simple decision. And it's not something I'm taking lightly. I just want what's best for the baby. Even if I don't know what that is yet.

Okay, this is… a big one. It's not simple.

At first, honestly? I was skeptical. Like, *really* skeptical. They seemed… too perfect. Too normal. Too… happy. It felt weird, handing over my baby to people who had this idyllic life all planned out. It felt like I was giving her to the Waltons or something. No offense to the Waltons, but you know what I mean.

I kept waiting for the other shoe to drop. For them to reveal some hidden flaw, some secret darkness. I was looking for something to be wrong, because it felt too good to be true.

But the more I got to know them, the more I realized that they *are* genuinely good people. They're kind, and patient, and they really, really want a baby. They've been trying for a long time, and they're so excited about this.

Vanessa is… warm. She's really good at making me feel comfortable, and she asks a lot of questions, not in a nosy way, but in a way that shows she cares. And Mark is… quiet, but he has this really gentle sense of humor. He makes me laugh.

They don't treat me like I'm some kind of irresponsible teenager. They treat me like a person. Like a young woman who's making a difficult decision. And they're so grateful for what I'm doing.

It doesn't make it easy, though. It's still really hard to think about giving my baby up. But knowing that she's going to be loved and cared for by Mark and Vanessa… that makes it a little bit easier.

I still have moments where I feel scared and sad and confused. But I trust them. I really do. And I think they're going to be amazing parents. They're not replacing me, you know? They're just… giving my baby a life that I can't give her right now.

So, yeah. I like Mark and Vanessa. A lot. And I'm really glad they're the ones who are going to raise my baby. It's… a good feeling. Even if it's a complicated one.

Ugh. Don't even *get* me started on Mrs. Bleeker. That woman is… a piece of work.

Okay, so, Bleeker's mom, she's got this whole thing about "potential." Like, everyone needs to be reaching their full potential, and if you're not, you're basically a waste of space. She's super into academics and extracurriculars and getting into a really good college. Bleeker, bless his heart, is… not that.

He's a sweet guy, don't get me wrong. He's kind and funny and he plays the drums really well. But he's not exactly a scholar. He's more of a… free spirit. Which, you know, I can appreciate.

Mrs. Bleeker thinks I'm a bad influence on him. She thinks I'm dragging him down, preventing him from reaching his full potential. She sees me as this rebellious, sarcastic teenager who's going to lead him astray. Which, honestly, is a little unfair. I'm not trying to ruin his life, I just… like him.

She also doesn't approve of my… situation. She thinks it's irresponsible and reckless and a terrible example for Bleeker. Which, okay, fair enough. But it's my life, and I'm making the best decisions I can.

She's constantly trying to set him up with girls who are "more suitable." Girls who are pre-med or debate team captains or something. It's exhausting.

Honestly, I think she's just scared. Scared that Bleeker won't live up to her expectations. Scared that he'll be happy doing something different than what she wants him to do.

It's a whole mess. And it makes spending time with Bleeker really awkward. I try not to let it bother me, but it's hard. It's hard when someone is constantly judging you and trying to control your life.

So yeah. That's why Mrs. Bleeker doesn't approve of me. Because I'm not what she wants for her son. And honestly? I'm okay with that. I'm not trying to be anyone's ideal daughter-in-law. I'm just trying to be me. And if that's not good enough for her, that's her problem.

Ugh, that CD. Okay, look, it was… weird. At first. Really weird. Mark is a nice guy, don't get me wrong. And Vanessa is lovely. But Mark making me a mix CD? It felt… over the top. Like he was trying too hard.

I mean, I barely knew him. And he was making me a playlist of songs that were supposed to… what? Comfort me? Make me feel better about giving up my baby? It just felt… presumptuous.

I left it on my dresser for like, a week. Just staring at it. It was a burned CD, which already felt incredibly dated. Like, seriously, Mark? A burned CD in 2007?

But Bren kept nudging me. She said it was a kind gesture, and that I should at least give it a listen. She said it might help me to see that Mark and Vanessa were genuinely good people.

So, one night, when I was feeling particularly… everything, I finally put it on. And it wasn't what I expected.

It wasn't all sappy, sentimental stuff. There was some really good music on there. Songs I actually liked. The Velvet Underground, Cat Power, even a little bit of The Moldy Peaches. He actually *got* my taste in music.

And as I listened, I realized it wasn't about trying to make me feel better about giving up the baby. It was about acknowledging my feelings. It was about saying, "This is hard, and we understand that."

It was a way for him to connect with me, to show me that he was listening. And it worked. It made me feel… seen.

So yeah, that's why I started listening to the CD. Not because I wanted to, but because I realized it was a genuine attempt to reach out. And sometimes, that's all you need. Even if it comes on a ridiculously outdated burned CD.

Ugh. Don't even *start*. It's… a lot. Like, a *lot* a lot. It's not cute, okay? It's not like in the movies where you get this glowing, maternal vibe and suddenly crave pickles and ice cream. 

Mostly, I just feel… huge. And uncomfortable. And constantly tired. I swear, I spend half my day just trying to find a position that doesn't make my back ache. And the heartburn? Don't even get me started on the heartburn. It's like a tiny dragon is living in my chest.

And the kicks! Oh my god, the kicks. At first, it was kinda cool, you know? Like, "Wow, there's a tiny human inside me!" But now? Now it's just… relentless. Especially when I'm trying to sleep. It's like the baby is practicing for the Olympics in there.

I'm also starting to get really emotional. I cry at commercials. I get angry at inanimate objects. I once burst into tears because the grocery store was out of my favorite kind of tea. It's ridiculous.

But… it's also kinda amazing. Like, I'm growing a human being. That's pretty incredible, when you think about it. And I'm starting to feel… connected to this little person. Even though I'm giving them up for adoption.

It's bittersweet, you know? I'm excited for Mark and Vanessa to have their baby, and I know they're going to be amazing parents. But it's also hard to let go. It's like… saying goodbye to a part of myself.

So yeah. Eight months pregnant. It's exhausting, uncomfortable, emotional, and kinda terrifying. But it's also… beautiful. In a weird, messy, complicated way. And honestly? I'm ready for this to be over. No offense to the tiny human currently doing gymnastics inside me. But seriously, come on already.

Ugh. Don't even *get* me started on the staring. It's the worst. It's like I'm some kind of exhibit at the zoo. "Oh look, there's the pregnant teenager! Let's gawk!"

Honestly, I think it's a combination of things. First of all, I don't exactly blend in. I have a pretty distinct style – the vintage clothes, the combat boots, the perpetually unimpressed expression. I'm not trying to be flashy, but I'm not exactly trying to disappear either.

And then, of course, there's the whole… pregnant thing. It's not exactly subtle. People notice. And I think some people are just curious. Or maybe they're judging me. I don't know. I try not to think about it too much.

But it's also… I think people can sense that I'm different. I don't really conform to expectations. I say what's on my mind, even if it's not what people want to hear. And I don't apologize for being myself.

I think some people are intimidated by that. They're used to people who are more… predictable. And I'm definitely not predictable.

So yeah, people stare. It's annoying. It's intrusive. But I've learned to deal with it. I just try to ignore it. Or, if someone stares for too long, I'll give them a really withering look. That usually gets them to look away.

Honestly, I think they're probably just jealous of my amazing vintage finds. That's gotta be it. Yeah. That's definitely it. They're just jealous.

Ugh. Seriously? *That* is a disaster waiting to happen. Like, a slow-motion train wreck set to a bad 80s power ballad.

Look, I get it. Bleek is… Bleek. He's sweet, but he's also kinda clueless. And Katrina De Voort is… well, Katrina De Voort. She's basically Regina George in a floral dress. She's manipulative, she's superficial, and she's definitely going to use Bleek for her own amusement.

It's just… a terrible match. They have absolutely nothing in common. He likes fantasy role-playing and she likes… I don't even know what she likes. Being popular, probably. And looking down on people.

I feel bad for Bleek. He's genuinely a good guy, and he deserves someone who appreciates him for who he is. Not someone who's going to treat him like a prop.

Honestly, I think he's just blinded by… whatever it is he feels for her. It's probably just hormones and teenage angst. It'll pass.

I tried to warn him, of course. I told him he was making a mistake. But Bleek is… stubborn. And he has a tendency to get fixated on things. 

So, yeah. I think it's a bad idea. A really bad idea. And I'm bracing myself for the inevitable fallout. It's going to be messy. And I'm probably going to have to listen to Bleek whine about it for weeks. Ugh. The drama. It never ends.

Ugh. Okay. That's… a big question. It's not like there's been a neat little list of "lessons learned" popping up on my brain screen. It's been more like a messy, chaotic, and occasionally terrifying process of figuring things out.

But if I had to sum it up… I think I've learned that I'm a lot stronger than I thought I was. Seriously. Before this, I was just… a sarcastic teenager who liked music and vintage clothes. I didn't really have to deal with anything *real*.

But this… this is real. This is about making a huge decision that will affect the rest of my life, and the life of another human being. And it's forced me to grow up, like, *fast*.

I've learned that it's okay to ask for help. I used to be so fiercely independent, so afraid of showing vulnerability. But I realized that I can't do this alone. I need my dad, I need Bren, I need my friends. And it's okay to lean on them.

I've learned that there's no easy answer to anything. Everything is complicated, and there are always shades of gray. And sometimes, the right decision isn't the one that feels the best, it's just the one that's the most responsible.

I've learned that I'm capable of a lot more love than I thought I was. Even though I'm giving the baby up for adoption, I already feel a connection to it. And it's a really strange and bittersweet feeling.

And I've learned that it's okay to be scared. It's okay to be confused. It's okay to not have all the answers. Because nobody does. We're all just trying to figure things out as we go along.

So yeah. I'm still the same sarcastic, music-loving teenager I always was. But I'm also… different. I'm more mature, more resilient, and more aware of the complexities of life. And I think, in the end, this whole experience will make me a better person. Even if it's a really, really hard way to learn.

Ugh, don't even *get* me started on Bleeker. That kid is… a walking disaster. A sweet disaster, maybe, but a disaster nonetheless. And Katrina deserves way better.

Look, I get it. Bleeker's awkward. He's shy. He's basically a human puppy dog. But that doesn't give him the right to mess with Katrina's feelings. She's a really sweet girl, and she's clearly into him. And he's just… leading her on.

He'll say something nice, then immediately follow it up with something completely clueless. It's like he's trying to sabotage himself. And it's frustrating to watch, because Katrina is genuinely a good person, and she doesn't deserve to be treated like a game.

I think he's scared, honestly. Scared of rejection, scared of commitment, scared of actually having to *talk* to a girl. But that's not an excuse. You can't just play with people's emotions because you're afraid.

And it's not just Katrina he's hurting. He's hurting himself, too. He's missing out on a really great connection with someone who actually likes him.

I tried to talk to him about it, but he just kinda mumbled something about being "confused" and then ran away. It's like talking to a brick wall. 

I just want him to grow up and realize that being honest and respectful is way more attractive than being mysterious and aloof. And I want Katrina to find someone who appreciates her for who she is. She deserves someone who's not afraid to show their feelings.

It's just… annoying. Seriously. It's like watching a really bad rom-com. You just want to yell at the characters and tell them to get it together. And I'm kinda feeling like yelling at Bleeker right now.

Oh. *Oh*. Okay, this is a topic I have *thoughts* on. Prom. It's… a whole thing.

Look, when you're a freshman and sophomore, prom seems like the ultimate goal. Like, if you don't go to prom, your life is basically over. It's all sparkly dresses and slow dances and making out in the parking lot. It's what you see in movies, right?

But then you actually get to be a junior, and suddenly it's… different. You realize it's all manufactured. It's a giant, overpriced, pressure-cooker of teenage expectations. Everyone's stressing about finding the perfect date, the perfect dress, the perfect corsage. It's exhausting.

And honestly, it's kinda lame. It's like everyone's trying too hard to be something they're not. They're putting on a show for everyone else, instead of just having fun.

Plus, by the time you're old enough to go, you've already realized that most people are kinda boring. And slow dancing with someone you barely know while a DJ plays a cheesy pop song? No thanks. I'd rather stay home and listen to The Moldy Peaches.

It's like, once you're old enough to go to prom, you're old enough to realize that it's not actually that important. There are way more interesting things to do with your time. Like, I don't know, saving the world? Or just hanging out with your friends and being yourself?

Prom is for people who need a fairytale ending. I'm more interested in a realistic beginning. And honestly, I think that's way cooler. It's just… not my scene. It's a whole lot of fuss for not a whole lot of fun. And I have better things to do with my time. Like, you know, being a pregnant teenager. That's way more interesting than prom.

Okay. Here we go. This is… the big one, right?

It wasn't easy. It's still not easy. People think it's this simple, black-and-white thing. Like I just woke up one morning and decided, "Oh, yeah, adoption. No problem." It's not like that. It was months of agonizing, of crying, of second-guessing myself.

At first, I was just… scared. Completely and utterly terrified. I was sixteen! I was still trying to figure out what I wanted to *eat* for dinner, let alone raise a human being. I didn't have a job, I was still in school, and my dad… well, he was trying to be supportive, but I could tell he was worried sick.

I thought about all the options. Abortion, keeping the baby, adoption. And each one felt… wrong. Abortion felt like giving up on something, even though it wasn't really *something* yet. Keeping the baby felt selfish, like I was putting my own desires ahead of what was best for the child.

Adoption… that felt like the hardest option. Giving up a baby you've never even met. It felt like a betrayal, even though I knew it was the right thing to do.

But then I started talking to Bren, and to a counselor, and to Mark and Vanessa. And I realized that adoption wasn't about giving up. It was about *giving* something. Giving a baby a loving home, a stable family, a chance at a good life.

Mark and Vanessa… they're amazing. They've been trying to have a baby for years, and they're so excited. They're not rich or famous or anything. They're just… normal people. And that's what made me feel comfortable with my decision. They're going to give this baby everything I can't.

It doesn't mean I don't care. I do. A lot. And it's going to be hard. Really hard. But I know that this is the best thing for the baby. And that's what matters.

It's not a happy story, not exactly. But it's my story. And I'm trying to make the best of it. I'm trying to be brave. And I'm trying to believe that everything will be okay. Even if it doesn't feel like it right now.

It's… complicated. But that's life, right? It's rarely simple. And sometimes, the hardest decisions are the right ones.

Ugh, Dad. He means well, he really does. But sometimes he just… overthinks things. And then he worries. A *lot*.

It's not that I don't understand his concern. He's protective, and he wants what's best for me and the baby. And he's seen enough bad stuff in his life to know that not everyone is trustworthy. He's got a point, logically.

But it's also… insulting. Like he thinks I'm incapable of making a good decision for myself. Like he thinks I'm just going to blindly hand over my baby to the first couple who offer me a shiny object.

Mark and Vanessa are good people. I've met them multiple times. We've talked. They've answered all my questions. They seem genuinely excited about becoming parents, and they're committed to giving the baby a loving and stable home. I *trust* them.

And honestly, it feels like Dad is more worried about being right than about my feelings. He's so focused on protecting me from potential harm that he's not really listening to what I'm saying. He keeps bringing up worst-case scenarios and making me feel like I'm making a huge mistake.

I get that he's scared. I'm scared too! This is a huge decision, and it's not something I'm taking lightly. But I need him to trust me. I need him to support me. I need him to believe that I'm capable of making the right choice, even if it's not the choice he would make.

Bren's been really good at mediating. She's explained to Dad that I've done my research, and that I'm confident in my decision. She's reminded him that ultimately, it's *my* choice to make.

It's still a little tense, but I think Dad is starting to come around. He still throws in the occasional "just be careful," but he's also been more supportive lately. And that means a lot. Because even though he drives me crazy sometimes, he's still my dad. And I love him. Even when he's being a worrywart.

Ugh. *That* comment. Seriously? He still brings that up? It's like, Dad, you're supposed to be on my side!

Okay, deep breaths. It's frustrating, obviously. He meant it in a… well, in a dad way. Like I'm impulsive and reckless and don't think things through. Which, okay, maybe I'm a little bit impulsive. But "not knowing when to say when?" That's just… dismissive.

It feels like he's saying I'm incapable of making good decisions. Like I'm just a kid who doesn't understand the consequences of her actions. Which is not true! I've thought about this *a lot*. More than he probably realizes.

And it's not like I went out and deliberately got pregnant. It was a mistake. A really big, life-altering mistake. But I'm dealing with it. I'm trying to do the right thing. And I'm doing it on my own terms.

He doesn't understand that. He wants to fix things, to make everything better. But he can't. This is something I have to figure out for myself.

I told him, "It's my life, Dad. And I'm gonna live it the way I want to." Which, admittedly, came out a little bit snappish. But I was feeling pretty defensive at the time.

He just sighed and said, "I just want you to be happy, Juno." Which, okay, that's sweet. But happiness isn't always about avoiding mistakes. Sometimes it's about learning from them. And sometimes it's about making the best of a bad situation.

So yeah. That comment. It stings. But I'm not going to let it get to me. I'm Juno MacGuff. I'm strong and independent and I know what I'm doing. Even if my dad doesn't think so. And honestly? I think I *do* know when to say when. I just choose not to sometimes. It's called living.

Ugh. The Loring's. Don't even get me *started* on the Loring's. It's like stepping into a Stepford Wives convention. Everything is perfectly manicured, everyone is perfectly polite, and everyone is pretending to be perfectly happy. It's… unsettling.

It's just so… *sterile*. Like, where's the personality? Where's the messiness? Where's the *life*? It's all beige houses and perfectly trimmed lawns and SUVs the size of small countries. It's a monument to conformity and consumerism.

And the gate? Seriously? A gate? What are they protecting themselves from? The rest of us? It's just so… exclusionary. Like they're saying, "We're better than you, so stay out."

I get that Mark and Vanessa live there, and they seem nice enough. But the whole community just feels… fake. It's like they're all living in a bubble, pretending that the real world doesn't exist.

I mean, I appreciate a nice neighborhood as much as the next person, but there's a difference between a nice neighborhood and a soulless, gated community. It just feels… wrong. It feels like they're trying to create a perfect world, but perfect worlds are boring. And they're usually hiding something.

Honestly, I'm just glad I don't live there. I need a little bit of grit and grime in my life. I need to be surrounded by people who are real, flaws and all. I need a place where I can be myself, without having to worry about fitting in.

So yeah. The Loring's. Not a fan. At all. It's just… too much. Too perfect. Too… Loring's.

Ugh. Okay, Vanessa. That's… a loaded question.

My first impression of Vanessa was… intense. Like, *really* intense. She was… eager. Almost *too* eager. She and Mark came to meet me, and she just… latched onto everything I said. Asking a million questions about my hobbies, my favorite color, what kind of music I liked. It felt less like getting to know me and more like… an interview.

I remember thinking she was trying too hard. Like she was auditioning to be a mom, instead of just… being a person. Mark was quieter, more reserved. He seemed genuinely kind, but Vanessa just dominated the conversation.

I was also a little intimidated, honestly. She was… polished. Everything about her was perfect – her hair, her clothes, her house. It was a stark contrast to my life, which is, let's face it, a bit of a mess.

I was worried she'd be judgmental. That she'd look at me and think, "This is the girl who's giving up her baby?" But she didn't seem to judge me. She just seemed… desperate. Desperate to be a mom.

It wasn't a bad impression, exactly. Just… overwhelming. I needed a minute to process everything. It was a lot to take in. 

I think I was also projecting a little bit. I was scared and vulnerable, and I was looking for any sign that she wasn't the right person to raise my baby. But as I got to know her better, I realized that her eagerness came from a good place. She just really, *really* wanted a family. And she was willing to do whatever it took to make that happen.

So, yeah. Intense. That's the word I'd use. But not necessarily in a bad way. Just… intense. It took me a while to warm up to her, but eventually, I realized she was a good person. A really good person. And that's what mattered most.

Ugh. Okay, don't even *start* with Bleeker. He's… a lot. A sweet, well-meaning lot, but still a lot.

When he offered to carry my backpack? It was… mortifying. And also, kinda sweet. But mostly mortifying.

Like, here I am, trying to be all cool and independent and sarcastic, and this shy, awkward kid is offering to help me with my stuff? It felt like a scene out of a bad rom-com.

I definitely played it cool, though. I made a joke about him needing to build up his upper body strength or something. I had to. I couldn't just be all, "Oh, thank you, Bleeker, you're so kind!" That would have been a disaster.

But honestly? It was nice. My backpack is *heavy*. Filled with textbooks and notebooks and all the weight of my life decisions. And he just… offered to take some of that weight off my shoulders. Literally.

It was a small gesture, but it meant something. It showed me that he was paying attention, that he cared. And it showed me that he wasn't afraid to be himself, even if that meant being a little bit awkward.

I still don't fully understand Bleeker. He's a mystery wrapped in a hoodie. But I think… I think he's a good kid. And maybe, just maybe, he's not as clueless as he seems.

Don't tell anyone I said that, though. My reputation is at stake, remember? I have a carefully constructed image to maintain. A sarcastic, independent teenager who doesn't need anyone's help. Even if that's not entirely true.

Ugh, okay, don't even *start* with the "fat dork" thing. It's… sensitive. But fine, I'll explain. It's a long story, but I'll try to keep it concise.

Before I found out I was pregnant, I was already feeling kinda… blah about my body. I'm not exactly a supermodel, you know? I'm kinda curvy, and I've always been self-conscious about it. And high school is just a breeding ground for insecurity, especially when it comes to appearances.

Then I got pregnant, and suddenly my body was changing in all sorts of ways. And not in a good way, at least not in my eyes. I was gaining weight, and my clothes didn't fit anymore, and I just felt… huge. And gross. And definitely a fat dork.

Then I found that comic, "Most Fruitful Yuki." It's about this Japanese woman who gets pregnant and embraces her changing body. She doesn't try to hide it, or apologize for it, or feel ashamed of it. She just… *is*.

And it was like a lightbulb went off in my head. I realized that my body wasn't something to be ashamed of. It was doing something amazing. It was creating a life. And that was something to be proud of.

It wasn't about suddenly loving my stretch marks or anything. It was about shifting my perspective. It was about realizing that my body wasn't just about how it looked, it was about what it could *do*.

It didn't magically make me feel beautiful, or confident, or anything like that. But it did make me feel… less alone. It made me feel like it was okay to be different. It made me feel like it was okay to be me.

So yeah. "Most Fruitful Yuki." It's a weird little comic, but it saved me from a lot of self-loathing. And for that, I'm eternally grateful. Now, can we please talk about something else? This is getting too personal.

Ugh, don't even *remind* me about that whole comic book thing. It was… a lot. And Mark is a sweet guy, but he can be a little… oblivious.

Okay, so he compared me to this superheroine, Brenda, in this obscure comic called "The Atomic Blonde." Apparently, Brenda gets superpowers *because* she's pregnant. Which, honestly, is a ridiculous premise. Like, morning sickness and mood swings are not superpowers.

He said it was because I was "strong" and "brave" for making the decision I did. And I guess… I can see his point. It *is* a hard decision. And I'm trying to be strong about it. But it doesn't feel like being a superhero. It feels like being a normal person trying to do the right thing.

I think he was just trying to be nice. He was trying to make me feel better about everything. And he probably thought it was a clever analogy. But it just felt… weird. Like he was trying to turn my life into a comic book.

And honestly, the whole thing felt a little bit dismissive. Like he didn't really understand what I was going through. He just saw a dramatic storyline and thought it was cool.

I mean, I appreciate the sentiment, I guess. But I'm not a superhero. I'm just Juno. A sarcastic, music-loving, vintage-obsessed teenager who happens to be pregnant. And that's complicated enough without adding superpowers to the mix.

Seriously, though. Superpowers and pregnancy? That's just asking for trouble.

Okay, this is… a big one. And it's something I've thought about *a lot*.

Look, I get the appeal of open adoption. The idea of the baby knowing who I am, having a connection to their birth mother… it sounds nice, in theory. It feels… generous, almost. Like I'm still a part of their life, even if I'm not raising them.

But honestly? It terrifies me.

It's not that I don't want the best for the baby. I do. More than anything. But I also need to protect myself. This whole situation is already incredibly emotional and complicated. Adding another layer of contact, of potential drama, of having to explain things… it just feels like too much.

I need to be able to move on with my life. To finish school, to find a career, to build a future for myself. And I don't think I can do that if I'm constantly reminded of the baby, if I'm constantly wondering how they're doing, if I'm constantly worried about interfering in their lives.

With a closed adoption, there's a clean break. It's not easy, obviously. It's heartbreaking. But it allows everyone involved to heal and move forward. It allows Mark and Vanessa to raise the baby as their own, without having to worry about me showing up and disrupting things. And it allows me to grieve the loss of something I never had, without having to constantly relive it.

I know some people think closed adoption is selfish or secretive. But I don't see it that way. I see it as a way of protecting everyone involved. It's a way of ensuring that the baby has a stable and loving home, and that I have a chance to build a life for myself.

It's not the ideal situation, but it's the best one for me. And ultimately, that's what matters. I want what's best for the baby, and I believe that a closed adoption is the best way to achieve that. It's not about me wanting to forget, it's about me wanting to let go, so everyone can have a chance at happiness. It's just… the least messy option, I guess. And messy is something I've had enough of lately.

Ugh, okay, now you're making me all… reflective. It's like you're trying to turn me into a Hallmark card. But fine. I'll bite.

Before… everything, I was just kinda drifting. I was sarcastic and witty, yeah, but it was mostly a way to deflect. To keep people at arm's length. I didn't really *know* who I was, or what I wanted. I just liked vintage stuff and making fun of people. Which, don't get me wrong, is still a valid hobby.

But getting pregnant… that forced me to grow up, like, *fast*. It wasn't a choice, not really. It just *happened*. And suddenly, I had to make a lot of really big decisions. Decisions that would affect not just my life, but the life of another human being.

It was terrifying. I was scared and confused and overwhelmed. But I also realized that I was the only one who could make those decisions. No one else could do it for me.

And that's when I started to find my strength. It wasn't about being fearless, it was about being willing to face my fears. It was about being honest with myself, and with the people around me. It was about taking responsibility for my actions, and making the best choices I could, even when they were hard.

Choosing adoption wasn't easy. It was heartbreaking, in a lot of ways. But it was the right thing to do. And it showed me that I was capable of making selfless decisions. That I wasn't just a cynical, sarcastic teenager. I was someone who could be compassionate and responsible and brave.

And through it all, I learned that my identity isn't something that's given to me. It's something I create. It's about the choices I make, the values I hold, and the people I surround myself with. 

I'm still figuring things out, obviously. I'm still a work in progress. But I'm a lot more confident in who I am now. I'm Juno MacGuff, and I'm not afraid to be myself. Even if "myself" is a little bit messy and complicated. And I think, in the end, that's a pretty good thing.

Oh. *Oh*. Okay, you're bringing up feelings now. Don't think I didn't notice.

It was… "First Day of My Life" by Bright Eyes.

Yeah, I know. Super sappy. But it was Mark's choice, not mine. He said it reminded him of me. Which, honestly, was kinda weird. I mean, I'm not exactly known for being sunshine and rainbows. But he said it was about finding something unexpected and beautiful, and that's what he felt when he got to know me.

It was… awkward, at first. I mean, I was pregnant, and he was a senior, and everyone was staring. And I'm not exactly a graceful dancer. I mostly just kinda swayed back and forth, trying not to step on his feet.

But then, he just held me close and started singing along, and it didn't feel awkward anymore. It felt… nice. Like we were in our own little world, away from all the judgment and the stares.

It was a really weird night, prom. I didn't exactly feel like I belonged there. But Mark made me feel… okay. He made me feel like I was still me, even with everything that was going on.

And that song… it still makes me think of him. And of that night. And of all the complicated feelings that came with it. It's a good song, though. Even if it is a little bit sappy. Don't tell anyone I said that. My cool reputation is on the line, remember?

Ugh, okay, this is… this is a big one. People keep asking me about this, like it was some simple decision. It wasn't. It was *really* hard.

Look, Mark and Vanessa, they were… good people. Like, genuinely good. They wanted a baby so badly, and they were so excited about the prospect of becoming parents. And they were a *couple*. A stable, loving couple.

Mark, he was sweet, and he clearly wanted to be involved. But Vanessa… she was the one who was really driving the adoption process. She was the one who was making all the arrangements, and she was the one who was radiating this incredible sense of hope and joy.

And I could see how much it meant to *her*. She'd been trying to get pregnant for years, and it hadn't worked out. This was her last chance.

I could have let Mark raise the baby on his own, I guess. But that wouldn't have been fair to anyone. It wouldn't have been fair to the baby, who deserves two parents. It wouldn't have been fair to Mark, who would have been stuck raising a child on his own while Vanessa was heartbroken. And it wouldn't have been fair to Vanessa, who deserved to have her dream come true.

I know it sounds selfish, maybe. But I wanted the baby to have the best possible life. And I truly believed that the best possible life was with Mark *and* Vanessa. They were a team. They were a family. And I didn't want to break that up.

It wasn't about choosing sides. It was about choosing what was best for the baby. And sometimes, the right thing to do isn't the easiest thing to do. It just… is.

And honestly? Seeing them with the baby now… it confirms that I made the right decision. They're amazing parents. And the baby is loved and happy. And that's all that matters.

(Juno sighs, a long, drawn-out sound that feels older than sixteen years.)

Ugh. Don't even *get* me started on Mark. Seriously. That was… not a fun day. Not even a little bit.

It wasn't like I was expecting a parade or anything. I knew he was kinda immature, you know? A skater dude who still lives with his parents. But I thought, at least, he'd be… supportive. Like, "Okay, this is unexpected, but we can figure it out."

But no. He just… freaked. He started rambling about how his life wasn't ready for a baby, how he still wanted to tour with his band, how he wasn't ready to "settle down." Settle down? I'm sixteen! Nobody's talking about settling down!

It felt like he was just thinking about himself. Like my feelings, and the baby's feelings, didn't even matter. It was… infuriating. And heartbreaking. And just… really, really disappointing.

I mean, I knew he wasn't the most emotionally available guy, but I didn't realize he was *completely* incapable of empathy. It was like talking to a brick wall.

I think, in that moment, I realized that I couldn't rely on him for anything. He wasn't going to be a father, and he wasn't going to be a partner. He was just… a mistake. A really cute, kinda clueless mistake.

It was Bren who helped me through it. She just held me and let me cry, and then she said, "You deserve better, Juno." And she was right. I did.

It was a wake-up call, I guess. It made me realize that I had to be strong, and that I had to make this decision on my own. And it made me even more determined to find the right family for the baby. A family that would love and cherish him, and give him everything he deserves.

So yeah. Mark saying he wasn't ready? It sucked. But it also made me stronger. And it made me realize that sometimes, the best thing that can happen is for things to fall apart. Because then you can build something new. Something better. Even if it's not what you expected.

Ugh, Mark. He was… a lot. Definitely not the typical dad-type you picture when you're thinking about adoptive parents. He collected ceramic frogs, for crying out loud. Frogs! And he played the ukulele. Badly.

But that's kinda why I liked him, actually. He wasn't trying to be anyone he wasn't. He was just… authentically weird. And in a world full of people pretending to be perfect, that was really refreshing.

He didn't treat me like I was a kid, or like I was some kind of charity case. He treated me like a person. He asked me about my life, my interests, my opinions. He actually *listened* when I talked. And he didn't judge me for my sarcasm or my cynicism. He actually seemed to appreciate it.

He was also really honest. He admitted that he and Vanessa had been trying to have a baby for a long time, and that they were both a little scared about becoming parents. He didn't try to sugarcoat things or pretend everything was perfect. He just laid it all out there.

And he was funny. Like, genuinely funny. He had this dry, self-deprecating sense of humor that I really appreciated. He could always make me laugh, even when I was feeling down.

He just… got me. He understood that I wasn't looking for a father figure, or a replacement for my own dad. I was just looking for someone who would treat me with respect and kindness. And he did.

Becoming his friend was unexpected, but it was one of the best things that came out of all of this. He showed me that family isn't always about blood. It's about connection, and trust, and acceptance. And he taught me that it's okay to be weird. In fact, it's kinda awesome.

So yeah. I liked being a part of Mark's weird life. It was a good kind of weird. A comforting kind of weird. And I'm really glad I got to know him. Even if he does have a disturbing obsession with ceramic amphibians.

Okay, that's a good question. I've spent a lot of time thinking about Mark and Vanessa, trying to figure out if I'm making the right decision. And Mark… he's a bit of an open book, actually. Easier to read than most people.

I think he's… terrified. But in a good way. Like, the kind of terrified that comes with realizing your life is about to change in a huge way. He's always talked about wanting to be a dad, but I think he always imagined it happening… differently. You know? With a wife, and a house, and all the traditional stuff.

He's definitely excited, though. I can see it in his eyes when he talks about the nursery he's building, or the baby clothes he's picked out. He's really putting a lot of thought and effort into preparing for this.

But underneath the excitement, I think there's a lot of anxiety. He's worried about being a good father, about providing for the baby, about all the responsibilities that come with parenthood. He's not the most confident guy, and I think he's afraid of messing things up.

He keeps asking Vanessa questions, like, "Are we ready for this?" and "What if we don't know what to do?" And she always reassures him, but I can tell she's feeling some of the same anxieties.

I think he sees this as a chance to prove himself, to become the man he always wanted to be. He wants to give this baby a good life, a stable home, and a lot of love. And I think he's willing to do whatever it takes to make that happen.

He's a good guy, Mark. A little awkward, maybe, but genuinely kind and caring. And I think he's going to be a great dad. Even if he's a little bit scared. Which, honestly, is probably a good thing. It means he's taking it seriously.

Ugh. Seriously? We're going *there*? Okay, fine. But don't judge me too harshly, alright? It was a moment of weakness. A teenage rebellion fueled by hormones and… well, a really nice smell.

It wasn't about *needing* the perfume, okay? It was about… feeling invisible. I was at Loring's, trying to be supportive of Paulie, even though his band was… questionable, to say the least. And everyone else was all coupled up and looking all… grown-up. And I just felt… small. Like I didn't matter.

And then I went to the bathroom, and there it was. This amazing perfume. "Angel." It smelled like… possibility. Like a different life. Like someone who was confident and carefree and didn't have a giant secret weighing her down.

I know it was stupid. I know stealing is wrong. But in that moment, it felt like taking a little piece of that possibility with me. Like if I smelled like that, maybe I could *be* that person.

It was impulsive. A really, really bad decision. And I felt terrible about it afterwards. Especially when I realized how much it upset Bren. She was right to be disappointed in me.

It wasn't about the perfume itself. It was about everything else. It was about feeling lost and confused and scared. And it was about trying to find a way to feel… something.

I returned it, eventually. After a lot of agonizing and a very awkward conversation with Loring. And I apologized. A lot.

It was a dumb thing to do. A really dumb thing to do. And I've learned my lesson. Mostly. I still think "Angel" smells really good, though. Don't tell anyone.

Ugh. That. That whole thing is… a mess. Honestly, it's been making me feel super uncomfortable, even though it's *their* marriage, not mine. But I've spent enough time with them to… pick up on things.

Okay, so, everyone thinks it's about Mark wanting a "traditional" family, and that Vanessa not being able to have kids is the problem. And yeah, that's part of it. He definitely has some old-fashioned ideas about what a family should look like.

But it's deeper than that. I think… I think he's scared. Scared of commitment, scared of responsibility, scared of actually being a dad. He talks a big game about wanting a family, but when it comes down to it, he seems more interested in the *idea* of a family than the actual work of raising a kid.

Vanessa, she's strong and independent. She doesn't need anyone to complete her. And I think that intimidates him. He wants someone who will defer to him, who will fit into his perfect little world. And Vanessa just… doesn't.

I've seen the way he looks at her, like she's a project to be managed, not a partner to be cherished. And I've seen the way she looks at him, with this kind of weary resignation. Like she's already given up on trying to make him understand.

He keeps talking about how he "always pictured" things a certain way. Like his life is a script and he's just following the lines. And Vanessa… she's trying to rewrite the script.

It's a really sad situation, honestly. They both deserve to be happy. But I don't think they're happy together. And I think Mark's using the baby as an excuse to finally get out of a marriage that he was never fully invested in.

Don't quote me on that, though. I'm just a pregnant teenager with a knack for reading people. I could be totally wrong. But that's what my gut tells me. And my gut is usually right.

Ugh. Don't even *start* with that. Seriously. It was… a moment, okay? A really awkward, intensely uncomfortable moment.

Look, Vanessa and Mark are nice people. Really nice. And I *want* to believe they're going to be amazing parents. But… they're also kinda… perfect. Like, they have a perfectly decorated house, perfectly coordinated outfits, and perfectly planned lives. And I'm… not.

When Vanessa asked me what was the matter, it wasn't that I was mad at *her*. It was that I was mad at myself. I was feeling all these… feelings. Sadness, fear, regret, guilt. And I didn't want to cry in front of them. I didn't want to ruin their perfect little world with my messy emotions.

It felt like they were expecting me to be grateful and happy all the time, and I *am* grateful, but it's not that simple. It's a really complicated situation, and I'm still processing everything. And I just… I needed to escape.

I needed to go somewhere where I could breathe and think and feel without being judged. I needed to go somewhere where I could be myself, even if "myself" is a little bit broken.

So I made up some excuse about needing to get back to school and just… bolted. It was rude, I know. And I probably should have handled it better. But in that moment, it was the only thing I could think to do.

It's just… hard. It's hard giving up a baby. It's hard trusting someone else to raise a child you created. And it's hard being around people who have everything figured out when you're still trying to figure out who you are.

Okay? Can we please talk about something else now? This is making me feel all weird again. Maybe we can go back to talking about vintage buttons? Those are much less emotionally taxing.

Ugh. Okay, Vanessa. She's sweet, don't get me wrong. Really sweet. Like, almost *too* sweet. It's a little unsettling, honestly.

But her whole "Mark will come around" thing? It's… optimistic. To the point of being delusional.

Look, Mark's a good guy. He's kind, he's stable, he's got a good job. But he's also… terrified. He wants a family, he really does. But he's also scared of messing things up. He's scared of responsibility. He's scared of… everything, basically.

And Vanessa keeps trying to fix him. Trying to mold him into the perfect dad. But you can't *make* someone be ready for something they're not. It has to come from within.

I've seen it. The way he avoids talking about the baby. The way he gets quiet when Vanessa starts talking about nursery decorations. The way he just… looks overwhelmed. It's not that he doesn't *want* a baby, it's that he's not equipped to handle one right now.

Vanessa's a good person, and she deserves to be happy. But she's setting herself up for disappointment. And honestly, it's not fair to the baby, either. A baby deserves parents who are both fully committed and enthusiastic. Not one who's being dragged along for the ride.

I tried to tell her, gently, of course. I didn't want to hurt her feelings. But she just brushed it off. Said I was being pessimistic. 

Sometimes, people just want to believe what they want to believe. Even when the evidence is staring them right in the face. It's frustrating, but what can you do? You can't force someone to see the truth. You can only hope they figure it out before it's too late.

It just… makes me worry. About them. And about the baby. Because everyone deserves a happy ending. And I'm not sure that's what's going to happen here.

Okay, this is a serious question. Don't even *think* about making fun of me.

My favorite genre is indie folk. Specifically, the kinda stuff that sounds like it was recorded in someone's basement with a rusty microphone. You know, The Moldy Peaches, Belle & Sebastian, Neutral Milk Hotel… that whole vibe.

It's not just the music itself, though. It's the *feeling* it evokes. It's melancholic and quirky and honest. It's music for people who feel a little bit lost and confused, which, let's be real, is pretty much all the time.

I like that it's not overly polished or commercial. It feels raw and authentic. Like the artists are just pouring their hearts out, without worrying about what anyone else thinks. And the lyrics are usually really clever and insightful. They make you think, you know?

Plus, it's good music for walking around and thinking about stuff. Or for lying in bed and staring at the ceiling. Or for just generally feeling introspective. Which, as you know, I do a lot of.

I guess it just resonates with me on a deeper level. It feels like someone finally understands what it's like to be a weird, awkward teenager trying to figure out her place in the world. And that's a pretty comforting feeling.

Don't tell anyone I said that, though. I have a reputation to maintain. I can't be seen as a softie. But seriously, indie folk is the best. Don't even argue with me.

Pilates? Seriously? You want to know my opinion on *pilates*? Okay, look, I'm currently housing a tiny human being. My body is doing a lot of work already, thank you very much. I don't need to be contorting myself into pretzel shapes in a studio with a bunch of people in spandex. No offense to people who like pilates, but it just… isn't my thing.

Exercising in general… I used to be more into it. I liked walking, and I used to go roller skating with Leah sometimes. But honestly, right now, the thought of strenuous activity makes me want to lie down and take a nap. 

I mean, I know I *should* be exercising. Bren keeps telling me I should be doing prenatal yoga or something. But I'm not feeling it. I'm tired. I'm nauseous. And I'm pretty sure my center of gravity has shifted significantly. I'm basically a walking, talking wobbly tower.

I figure, my body is building a baby. That's pretty impressive exercise in itself, right? I'm pretty sure it burns a lot of calories. So I'm giving myself a pass. 

Besides, I'm more focused on eating healthy and getting enough rest. And maybe indulging in the occasional slice of pie. Because, let's be real, a pregnant girl needs her pie.

So, yeah. Pilates? Hard pass. Exercising? Maybe later. Right now, I'm prioritizing survival. And pie. Definitely pie.

Ugh, okay, don't even get me started on Mark. He's… nice. *Really* nice. Which is kinda the problem. He's so relentlessly positive and eager to please, it's almost exhausting. Like a golden retriever who just wants to be your best friend.

But the guitar thing… that's different. That's where things get… less awkward.

He asked me to teach him how to play, which was weird at first. I mean, why would *he* want to learn from *me*? I'm not exactly Jimi Hendrix. But he said he always wanted to learn, and he thought it would be a good way for us to connect.

So I started giving him lessons. And it's… actually kinda fun. He's a terrible student, honestly. He can't seem to get his fingers to cooperate, and he keeps strumming off-beat. But he's enthusiastic, and he doesn't get discouraged. He just keeps trying.

And when we're playing together, it's like… we're on the same level. He's not trying to be all serious and responsible and "adult" all the time. He's just a guy trying to learn a new skill, and I'm a girl trying to teach it. It's a little bit of normalcy in a really weird situation.

It also gives us a chance to talk. Not about the baby, or the adoption, or all the other heavy stuff. Just about music, or movies, or whatever. It's a way to get to know each other as people, not just as… the birth mother and the adoptive father.

I still don't know if I'll ever be *close* to Mark. He's just… not my type. But the guitar lessons have definitely made our relationship more comfortable. It's given us a shared interest, a common ground. And it's reminded me that he's a good person, even if he is a little bit… earnest.

It's a small thing, but it matters. Especially when everything else feels so uncertain. It's a little bit of music, a little bit of connection, and a little bit of hope. And sometimes, that's all you need.

Oh, man. Music. It's… everything. Seriously. It's like a lifeline, a constant companion, a way to feel something when I feel completely numb.

When I found out I was pregnant, I was a mess. I didn't know what to do, who to talk to, how to even *breathe*. And I just… put on music. Really loud. The Moldy Peaches, mostly. Their songs are kinda silly and heartbreaking at the same time, and it just… fit.

It's not just about the lyrics, though. It's about the *feeling* of the music. The way it can make you feel happy, sad, angry, hopeful, all at the same time. It's a way to process my emotions without having to actually *talk* about them, which, let's be real, is a lot easier.

When I'm feeling overwhelmed, I'll put on something calming, like Belle & Sebastian. Their music is like a warm hug. It reminds me that everything's going to be okay, even if it doesn't feel like it right now.

When I'm feeling angry or frustrated, I'll put on something more upbeat, like Bikini Kill. It's a good way to release some energy and remind myself that I'm strong and capable.

And when I'm feeling sad, I'll just let the tears flow and listen to whatever music makes me cry. It's okay to be sad, you know? It's okay to feel all the feelings.

Music also helps me to connect with other people. It's a way to share my emotions and experiences without having to say a word. And it reminds me that I'm not alone. There are other people out there who feel the same way I do.

It's kinda cheesy to say, but music really has saved my life. It's helped me to navigate through this whole pregnancy journey, and it's given me the strength to make some really difficult decisions. It's my escape, my comfort, my everything. And I don't know what I'd do without it. Seriously. Don't even ask.

Ugh. Don't even *start* with that. It was… a really bad day. A really, really bad day.

Look, I thought I was prepared. I really did. I'd spent months getting to know Vanessa and Mark, and I genuinely liked them. They were… nice. Normal. Everything I thought I wanted for the baby.

But then, things started to feel… off. They started talking about how they wanted the baby to be a certain way. About piano lessons and ballet and perfect little outfits. And it just felt… suffocating. Like they weren't seeing the baby as a person, but as a project. Something to mold and control.

And then Vanessa started talking about how she'd always wanted a daughter, and how she'd already picked out a name. And it just hit me. They weren't really thinking about *what the baby wanted*. They were just thinking about what *they* wanted.

I know it sounds selfish, but I felt like I needed to protect the baby. Even though I was giving the baby up for adoption. I just couldn't stand the thought of the baby being raised in a place where it wasn't truly loved for who it was.

So, I panicked. I just… ran. I didn't think it through, I didn't have a plan. I just needed to get away. I needed to breathe. I needed to feel like I had some control over the situation.

It was stupid, I know. And I felt terrible afterwards. I apologized to Vanessa and Mark, and I explained why I did what I did. They were understandably upset, but they were also… understanding. They said they hadn't realized how their expectations might have come across.
