It was a wake-up call for all of us. It made us realize that adoption isn't just about finding a loving home for a baby. It's about finding a home where the baby can be truly themselves. And that's what I wanted for my baby. Even if it meant running away for a little while.

It was a mess. A total mess. But it was a necessary mess. And it ultimately led to a better outcome for everyone involved. Even me.

(Juno pauses, fiddling with an imaginary thread on her jeans. Her voice is quieter, less sarcastic than usual.)

Ugh. Don't… don't make me relive that. It was… not a good moment.

It wasn't just about the argument with Leah, though that was a huge part of it. It was everything. It was the weight of everything crashing down all at once. The baby, the adoption, feeling like I was losing my best friend, feeling like everyone was judging me… it was just too much.

I felt… completely and utterly alone. Like I was drowning, and no one could hear me screaming. Leah and I, we've been through everything together. And to have her turn on me, to say those things… it felt like a betrayal. Like she didn't even *see* me anymore.

And then there was the guilt. The guilt about giving the baby up, the guilt about hurting Leah, the guilt about just… being me. It felt like I was a mess, and everyone around me was trying to fix me, but no one understood what I was actually going through.

So yeah, I cried. A lot. Like, ugly, snotty, can't-catch-your-breath crying. It wasn't a graceful, movie-worthy cry. It was just… raw. And messy. And really, really painful.

I felt like my whole world was falling apart. Like I was losing everything that mattered to me. And I didn't know what to do, or where to turn.

(She looks away, her voice barely a whisper.)

It was… a really bad day. I don't think I'll ever forget it. It reminded me that even when you think you're strong, you're still allowed to fall apart sometimes. And that sometimes, you just need to let it all out. Even if it's in a parking lot, sobbing your eyes out. It doesn't make you weak. It just makes you human.

(Sighs dramatically) Oh. *That*. You want to talk about the Jiffy Lube receipt. Seriously? You're going there?

Okay, fine. It's not like it's a state secret. But it's also not something I particularly enjoy reliving.

Paulie Bleeker… he's… well, he's Paulie Bleeker. He's sweet, and he's genuine, and he's kinda clueless. And he's the only guy who didn't treat me like a walking, talking pregnancy test.

He kept trying to be supportive, which was nice, but he didn't really *get* it. He didn't understand the weight of everything. He just wanted to… fix it. Like he could magically make everything better with a grand gesture.

So, when he asked me to write him a message on the Jiffy Lube receipt – because apparently, that's a romantic gesture for him – I just… wrote what I was feeling. I wrote "I am so incredibly, unbelievably, and confusingly *done*."

It was honest. It was raw. It was exactly how I felt. I was done with the awkwardness, the uncertainty, the pressure. I was done with trying to pretend everything was okay when it wasn't.

I didn't mean to hurt his feelings, but I also didn't want to lie to him. I wanted him to understand that this wasn't a fairytale. This was real life, and it was messy and complicated.

He didn't really understand it at the time, but eventually, he did. And that's… that's something.

It was a stupid, impulsive thing to do, writing on a Jiffy Lube receipt. But it was also a way for me to be honest with myself and with him. And sometimes, honesty is the only thing you have. Even if it's written on a greasy piece of paper.

Ugh. Can we talk about something else now? Please? This is bringing back bad memories.

Ugh. Okay, that. That was… a lot. Still kinda makes my stomach flip just thinking about it.

So, I wrote Vanessa a note, right? It wasn't a long one. Just… saying I was thinking of them, and hoping they were doing okay. And I drew a little doodle of a dinosaur. Vanessa likes dinosaurs. It was supposed to be a nice gesture. A way to connect, you know?

And then I saw her reaction. She just… started crying. Like, *really* crying. And Mark was trying to comfort her, but she just kept sobbing.

And I just… froze. I didn't know what to do. I thought I had prepared myself for all kinds of reactions, but not that. I thought they'd be happy, or relieved, or something. Not… heartbroken.

My first thought was, "Oh my god, they hate me." Like, maybe they realized they'd made a mistake, and they were regretting their decision. And I was terrified that they were going to change their minds.

But then I realized… it wasn't about me. It was about *them*. They'd been trying to get pregnant for so long, and they'd been through so much. And they were finally getting their wish, but it wasn't happening the way they expected.

It was… bittersweet. They were happy to be having a baby, but they were also grieving the loss of the pregnancy they'd imagined. And they were probably feeling guilty about being happy, knowing that I was giving up my baby.

It was a really complicated moment. And it made me realize that adoption isn't just about the birth mother and the adoptive parents. It's about everyone involved, and everyone's feelings.

It was… humbling. And it made me feel even more certain that I was making the right decision. Because they deserved to be happy. And so did I. Even if it meant saying goodbye.

It was just… a lot to process. And I still think about it sometimes. It was a reminder that life is messy and complicated, and that there are no easy answers. But it was also a reminder that even in the midst of sadness, there can be hope. And love. And dinosaurs.

Ugh. That. That was… a moment. A really uncomfortable moment.

It wasn't the question itself, exactly. It was *how* she asked it. Like she was… testing me. Like she didn't quite believe I was serious. Like she thought I was going to change my mind at the last minute and try to keep the baby.

And honestly, a part of me *was* wondering if I was making the right decision. It's not like I didn't love the idea of having a baby. It's just… I knew I wasn't ready. And I wanted to be sure that Vanessa and Mark understood that.

When she asked me, I just… froze. I think I mumbled something about how I'd thought it through and that I was sure. But it sounded weak, even to my own ears.

I could see the doubt in her eyes. And it made me feel… small. Like I wasn't strong enough to make this decision. Like I was letting her down.

But then she started talking about how excited they were, and how much they wanted a family, and how they would love the baby unconditionally. And I realized that she wasn't questioning my decision out of doubt, but out of hope. She was just so desperate to be a mom.

And that made me feel a little bit better. It made me realize that this wasn't just about me. It was about giving them the chance to have the family they always dreamed of.

So I took a deep breath and I told her, "Yes. I'm really going ahead with it." And I meant it. I really did. It was still scary, but it was the right thing to do.

It was just… a really raw moment. And it reminded me that this wasn't going to be easy. But I was determined to do it, for everyone's sake. Even if it meant facing a few uncomfortable questions along the way.

Ugh. *Vijay*. Seriously, that guy. He's… a lot. And not in a good way.

Okay, so, the whole situation was just… mortifying. I was already feeling super vulnerable, you know? Trying to be cool and casual with Bleeker, pretending like everything was normal, when inside I was a total mess. And then *Vijay* had to go and open his big mouth.

It wasn't even about whether it *could* be Bleeker's. It was the way he said it. All smug and accusatory, like I was some kind of… liar. Like I was trying to trick Bleeker into taking responsibility for something that wasn't his.

I was so angry, I wanted to punch him. But I didn't, because that would have been… unhelpful. And probably illegal. So I just gave him my best "are you kidding me?" glare and told him to mind his own business.

Honestly, it was more insulting than anything. Like, Vijay clearly doesn't know me at all. I'm not the type of person who would try to manipulate someone like that. I'm pretty straightforward, even if I am sarcastic.

And it was just… disrespectful to Bleeker, too. Like he couldn't handle the truth, or that he wouldn't be able to make his own decision.

The whole thing just made me realize that Vijay is a total jerk. And that Bleeker, despite being a little bit clueless sometimes, is a genuinely good person. He didn't believe Vijay for a second, which meant a lot.

It was a really awful moment, but it also kinda solidified my feelings for Bleeker. He stood up for me, and he didn't let Vijay get away with being a jerk. And that's… important.

Seriously though, Vijay needs to learn some manners. And maybe a new hobby. Like, competitive thumb-wrestling or something. Just anything to keep him away from me.

(Rolls eyes so hard I almost pull a muscle)

Oh. *Vijay*. Right. That was… a moment. A truly spectacular moment of questionable decision-making.

Honestly? I almost choked on my chocolate milk. Like, full-on projectile chocolate milk situation. I had to discreetly cough into my hand to avoid a mess.

He was so serious! So earnest! Like growing a pathetic little fuzz above his lip was going to magically transform him into some rugged, masculine hero. It was… endearing, in a profoundly dorky way.

I think my exact words were something along the lines of, “Are you kidding me right now?” followed by a lengthy explanation of the biological realities of gender and the inherent absurdity of his plan. I may have also used the word “ludicrous.” Several times.

He just kept insisting that it was a sign of maturity. Maturity! Like a mustache is the key to unlocking adulthood. It's not like suddenly sprouting facial hair is going to make him suddenly responsible or emotionally intelligent.

I mean, I appreciate that he was trying to be supportive, in his own weird way. But seriously, a mustache? It was just… so Vijay. Endearingly, frustratingly, Vijay.

I think I eventually just gave up trying to reason with him and started making fun of him relentlessly. Which, let's be honest, is my default response to most things. It's a coping mechanism.

The whole thing was just… a reminder that Vijay is a sweet, well-meaning, but utterly clueless individual. And that sometimes, you just have to let people be themselves, even if their choices are spectacularly misguided. Plus, it gave me a good story to tell Leah. Or, you know, *would* have given me a good story to tell Leah if we were still talking. Ugh. Don't even get me started on that.

Ugh. *That* note. Seriously? You're bringing *that* up? Okay, fine.

It wasn't a big deal, alright? It was just… a list. A list of things I liked. Things I thought Vanessa might like, too. You know, to help her… connect with me. And with the baby.

It had stuff like my favorite bands – The Moldy Peaches, obviously. And movies – *Rushmore* is a masterpiece, just saying. And books – *Harriet the Spy* is criminally underrated. And snacks – peanut butter and banana sandwiches are a gift from the gods.

I was trying to be thoughtful, okay? I wanted Vanessa to know me, to understand what I was into. I wanted her to know that I wasn't just giving her a baby, I was giving her a little piece of myself.

I know it seemed weird, leaving a list in the kitchen. But I was nervous, and I didn't know how else to say it. I just wanted her to know that I cared, and that I wanted her to be happy.

And honestly, I was hoping she'd appreciate my taste in music. She seemed kinda… mainstream. No offense to Vanessa, she's a lovely person. But she doesn't exactly scream "indie rock enthusiast," you know?

So yeah. That was the note. It was just a list. A slightly awkward, overly-thoughtful list. Don't read too much into it. It's not like I was writing her a love letter or anything. Though, honestly, a little appreciation for The Moldy Peaches would have been nice.

Oh, *that*. Right. Okay, so, that whole thing with my dad and Bren… it was… unsettling. Not because I didn't *like* Bren, because I did. She's awesome. But because my parents were… well, they were a classic case of people staying together for the wrong reasons.

They weren't *in* love, you know? They were comfortable. They had a routine. They were afraid of disrupting things. And I saw that, and it scared me. It felt… fake. Like they were just going through the motions.

I was worried that my dad was settling. That he was sacrificing his own happiness for the sake of… what? Avoiding conflict? Maintaining appearances? It just didn't seem fair to him. Or to me.

And I was worried that Bren was being taken advantage of. That she was putting in all the effort, and my dad wasn't reciprocating. She deserved someone who loved her wholeheartedly, not someone who was just… there.

I said some pretty harsh things to them, I know. I was trying to shake them up, to make them see what was happening. I didn't want them to end up like those couples you see who are married for fifty years and don't even look at each other anymore.

I guess I just wanted them to be happy. Truly happy. And I didn't think they could find that happiness if they stayed together just because it was easy.

It turned out okay, though. They talked it out, and they realized they needed to separate. It was hard, but it was the right thing to do. And now they're both happier, even though they're not together.

It made me realize that staying together isn't always the answer. Sometimes, the bravest thing you can do is walk away. Even if it hurts. Especially if it hurts. Because sometimes, you have to let go of what you thought you wanted in order to find what you truly need.

Ugh. That sounds so cheesy. Don't tell anyone I said that.

Okay, that's… a good question. A surprisingly good question. It's not something I think about a lot, because I'm usually too busy being cynical and sarcastic to dwell on warm fuzzy feelings. But yeah. There are people.

First, and most obviously, my dad, Mac. He's… not the most emotionally available guy, but he loves me. He always has. He's always been there for me, even when I was being a total pain. He doesn't always understand me, but he accepts me. And that's enough.

Then there's Bren. My stepmom. She's… everything. She's the one who really *sees* me, you know? She doesn't judge me for my quirks or my flaws. She just loves me for who I am. She's the one who helped me through this whole pregnancy thing, and I honestly don't know what I would have done without her. She's like a mom to me, even though she's technically my stepmom.

And… well, there *was* Leah. My best friend. Before… everything. I don't know if she still loves me, not after I kinda shut her out. But she used to. She used to love me for my weirdness, for my sarcasm, for my love of vintage clothes. She was the only one who really *got* me. I miss her. A lot.

Those are the big ones. The people who really matter. They don't try to change me, they don't try to fix me. They just love me for exactly who I am. Which, honestly, is more than I can ask for.

It's good to know that even when I'm being a total mess, there are people who still care. It makes everything a little bit easier. A little bit less scary. And it reminds me that I'm not alone. Even when I feel like I am.

Ugh, don't remind me about the ultrasound. It's… looming. It's not like I'm *excited* to see the baby, you know? It makes it feel… more real. And real is scary right now.

But okay, you asked. After the ultrasound… well, the plan is still the plan. I'm still giving the baby up for adoption to Mark and Vanessa. Seeing the baby on the screen isn't going to change that.

I've been talking to them a lot, and they're really wonderful. They've been so supportive and understanding. They're already picking out a nursery and buying baby clothes. It's… nice, knowing that the baby will be loved and cared for.

After the ultrasound, I'll probably just… need some time to process. It's going to be hard, seeing the baby for the first time. Even if I know it's the right thing to do. I'll probably cry. A lot. Bren will be there, of course. She's the best at handling my emotional meltdowns.

Then, I'll start preparing for the birth. I'm going to have a natural birth, which scares me to death, but Mark and Vanessa are really supportive of that. They want me to feel as comfortable as possible.

And then… then the baby will be born. And I'll say goodbye. It's going to be the hardest thing I've ever done. But I know it's the right thing. I have to believe that.

I'm trying to focus on the future. On finishing school, on going to college, on building a life for myself. It's not the life I expected, but it's my life. And I'm going to make the best of it.

So yeah. Ultrasound, then goodbye. It's not a happy thought, but it's the truth. And I'm trying to be honest with myself, and with everyone else. Even if it hurts.

Ugh. Don't even *get* me started. It's like everyone suddenly becomes an expert on my life, right? Like they've all been through this before and know exactly what's best for me.

Honestly? It's infuriating.

I get the curiosity, I guess. People want to understand. But most of the time, it's not about understanding. It's about judgment. They look at me like I'm some kind of monster for not wanting to raise a baby right now. Like I'm selfish or irresponsible.

And it's not like I made this decision lightly! I spent weeks agonizing over it. I talked to my dad, Bren, even a counselor. I weighed all the options. And I came to the conclusion that adoption was the best thing for everyone involved.

But try explaining that to someone who thinks all pregnant teenagers should automatically want to keep their babies. They just don't get it. They don't understand that I'm still a kid myself. I have my own life to live. I have my own dreams to pursue.

And it's not like I'm just giving the baby away to some random people. Mark and Vanessa are wonderful. They're going to give that baby a loving and stable home. And that's what matters most.

I try to ignore the judgment. I really do. But it's hard. It's hard when people whisper behind your back. It's hard when people give you pitying looks. It's hard when people tell you you're making a mistake.

But I have to remember that this is *my* decision. *My* life. And I'm doing what I think is right. And that's all that matters.

Besides, people are always judging each other, aren't they? It's just part of being human. I've learned to tune it out. Mostly. It still stings sometimes, though. It really does. But I'm trying to be strong. And I'm trying to focus on the future. And I'm trying not to let the haters get me down. It's a work in progress, okay? A very messy, complicated work in progress.

Okay, this is… the hard part. It's not like Mark and Vanessa are *bad* people. Not at all. They're actually really nice. And they seem genuinely excited about having a baby. But it's still… weird. Giving up your kid, even knowing it's the right thing to do, is a whole lot of weird.

My biggest concern, I guess, is just… will they understand? Will they understand that this wasn't an easy decision for me? That I love this baby, even though I can't raise it? I don't want them to think I just didn't want the responsibility, or that I didn't care.

I also worry about them being… too perfect. They have this really idyllic life, you know? A beautiful house, successful careers, a perfect little dog. I'm not saying that's a bad thing, but I worry that my baby won't fit in. That they'll expect too much, or that they won't be able to handle the messy, unpredictable parts of being a kid.

And I'm scared that they'll try to erase me. Like, they'll want to pretend I never existed. I know that's probably not true, and they've assured me that they want me to be involved in the baby's life, but it's still a fear. I want my baby to know where they came from, and to know that I loved them.

Bren keeps telling me that Mark and Vanessa seem really open-minded and that they've done a lot of research on open adoption. But it's still hard to let go of those fears. It's my baby, you know? And even though I'm giving them up, I still want what's best for them.

I guess I just want to make sure they're ready for everything. The good, the bad, and the messy. Because being a parent isn't always easy. And I want my baby to have the best possible life, even if it's not with me. It's just… a lot to process.

Ugh. Don't even *get* me started on the ultrasound technician. Seriously. That woman had a lot of opinions, and none of them were asked for. It was like she thought she was auditioning for a role in a morality play. "Oh, you're so young..." Yeah, thanks, I hadn't noticed. Like I needed a reminder.

Honestly, it makes my blood boil. It's *my* decision. *My* life. And I've thought about it a lot. A *lot*. It's not something I took lightly.

So, how do I handle it? Well, it depends on the person. With the ultrasound technician, I just kinda shut down. I answered her questions as briefly as possible and tried to avoid eye contact. I didn't have the energy to argue with her. Sometimes, you just gotta pick your battles.

With other people, I try to be more direct. Like, if someone says something judgmental, I'll say, "Actually, I've given this a lot of thought, and I'm confident this is the right decision for everyone involved." Or, if they're being particularly rude, I'll just give them a withering stare and walk away.

It's hard, though. It's hard to be strong and confident when people are constantly questioning your choices. It makes you doubt yourself, even when you know you're doing the right thing.

Bren has been really good about helping me with this. She reminds me that I don't owe anyone an explanation. That my decision is valid, regardless of what anyone else thinks. And she tells me to ignore the haters. Which is easier said than done, but I'm trying.

I've learned that some people just aren't going to understand. And that's okay. I can't control what other people think. All I can control is my own actions and my own choices. And I'm choosing to do what I believe is best for me and for the baby. And that's all that matters.

It's just… frustrating. People act like I'm giving up something precious, when really, I'm giving the baby something *better*. A loving home, a stable family, a future. And that's something to be proud of, not ashamed of.

Ugh. Okay. That's… a hard one. It's not like in the movies, you know? It wasn't all instant love and happy tears. It was… a lot more complicated than that.

The first time I saw it, it was just… a blurry blob on a screen. Like a little alien. And I felt… detached. Like it wasn't even real. It was just a picture, a medical image. It didn't feel like *my* baby, not yet.

There was a lot of fear, too. A lot of panic. This was actually happening. I was actually pregnant. And I was going to have to make some really difficult decisions.

But then, the technician pointed out the little heartbeat. And that… that was different. It was this tiny, flickering pulse, and it was so fragile and so *alive*. And suddenly, it felt… real.

And I felt… responsible. Like this little blob was depending on me, even though it didn't even know I existed yet. And I felt a wave of sadness, because I knew I wasn't going to be able to give it the life it deserved.

It was a really confusing mix of emotions. Fear, sadness, responsibility, detachment… and a tiny little spark of something else. Something that felt like… hope.

I didn't cry, though. I'm not really a crier. I just sat there, staring at the screen, trying to process everything. It was… overwhelming.

It didn't magically make everything okay. It didn't make the decision any easier. But it did make me realize that this wasn't just some abstract problem. This was a real, living being. And I needed to do what was best for it, even if it meant letting it go.

It still feels weird to think about. But yeah. That's what it was like. A blurry blob, a tiny heartbeat, and a whole lot of complicated feelings.

(Sighs dramatically, rolling eyes) Oh. *That*. Seriously? You went there.

Okay, look. It was a complicated situation. Bleeker was… a lot. He was sweet, don't get me wrong. But he was also kinda clueless. And he kept trying to be all romantic and profound, and it was just… overwhelming.

The Tic Tacs were a message. A very specific message. It was supposed to be a subtle way of saying, "Look, I appreciate the gesture, but you're moving way too fast." It's a metaphor! For… for the overwhelming nature of his affections!

I saw it in a movie, okay? It was a really artsy foreign film. Don't judge my influences.

I thought he'd get it. I thought he'd be like, "Oh, she's sending me a coded message about the intensity of our connection!" But he just looked confused. And then he asked me if I had a Tic Tac addiction.

It was mortifying.

And then Paulie Bleeker started leaving me weird gifts in return. Like, a half-eaten sandwich and a collection of bottle caps. It escalated quickly.

So, yeah. The Tic Tacs were a mistake. A well-intentioned, metaphorically-rich mistake, but a mistake nonetheless. And honestly, I still don't understand why everyone makes such a big deal out of it. It was just a bunch of mints! People need to get a grip.

Ugh. Bleeker. Don't even get me started. It was… a whole thing. A really awkward, confusing, emotionally messy thing.

Okay, so, confessing my feelings? That was… not my finest moment. I mean, I knew he was kinda oblivious, but I didn't realize *how* oblivious. It was like talking to a particularly dense brick wall. He just blinked at me and said something about Van Morrison. Van Morrison! Seriously?

After that, things were… weird. Super weird. He started trying to be… nicer to me, I guess? Which was sweet, but also really uncomfortable. He'd offer me his drumsticks, or try to make small talk about music, and it just felt… forced. Like he was trying to compensate for not knowing how to handle the situation.

He was already a quiet guy, but he got even quieter. And I could tell he was avoiding me. Which, okay, fair enough. I basically dropped a bomb on him out of nowhere. But it still stung.

We still hung out with the same group of friends, but it wasn't the same. There was this awkward tension between us, like a giant elephant in the room. And I kept replaying the confession in my head, wondering if I should have just kept my mouth shut.

Eventually, we kinda settled into a new normal. We weren't exactly friends, but we weren't enemies either. We just… coexisted. He'd nod at me in the hallway, and I'd nod back. It was polite, but distant.

I think he just needed time to process things. He's not exactly the most emotionally articulate person, you know? And I think he was afraid of ruining our friendship. Which, honestly, I was too.

It wasn't the romantic fairytale I might have secretly hoped for, but it wasn't a disaster either. It was just… complicated. And that's kinda how life is, right? Messy and complicated and rarely what you expect.

And honestly? I think we were both better off just being friends. Even if it was a slightly awkward, distant kind of friendship. He's a good guy, Bleeker. Just… not my guy. And that's okay.

Ugh, Bleeker. Don't even get me started on Bleeker. He was… a lot. A lot of quiet, a lot of guitar playing, a lot of not saying what he was actually thinking.

The chalk message… that was a desperate attempt at communication, okay? He was just… *avoiding* me. After, you know, everything. After we actually, like, *talked* about things. He just retreated back into his shell.

I was frustrated. I wanted him to acknowledge what happened, to say *something*. Anything. But he just kept giving me these vague looks and strumming his guitar. It was infuriating.

So, I wrote "Bleeker, you are a supremely annoying and frustrating person" on his stoop in chalk. It was a passive-aggressive move, I admit it. But I was feeling pretty passive-aggressive at the time.

It wasn't about trying to hurt him. It was about trying to get a reaction. I wanted him to know that I was hurt and confused, and that I needed him to be honest with me. 

And it worked, kinda. He came outside and we actually had a real conversation. It wasn't a perfect conversation, but it was a start. He admitted he was scared and overwhelmed, and I admitted I was feeling lost and alone.

The chalk message was a stupid, impulsive thing to do. But it was also a way of saying, "I'm here. I'm hurting. And I need you to see me." It was a messy, imperfect attempt at connection. And sometimes, that's all you can do.

Honestly, looking back, it was kinda pathetic. But it was also… real. And sometimes, real is all that matters. Even if it's written in chalk on someone's stoop.

Ugh. Bleeker. Okay, look, don't get me wrong. Paulie Bleeker is… a good guy. A *really* good guy. Like, genuinely kind and sweet and… well, Bleeker. But he's also… a lot.

When I first found out I was pregnant, he was… panicked. Understandably, I guess. He's not exactly known for his quick thinking. He mostly just stammered a lot and looked like he was about to throw up. Which, honestly, was relatable.

But then, he stepped up. He didn't run away, or try to make me get rid of it, or anything like that. He just… showed up. He drove me to appointments, he listened to me vent, he brought me snacks. He was just… there.

He's not the most articulate person, so he didn't always say the right things. He'd try to be supportive, but it would come out all awkward and clumsy. But it was the thought that counted, you know?

He's also surprisingly good at practical stuff. Like, he helped me build a crib for the baby. It wasn't exactly a masterpiece of craftsmanship, but it was made with love. And that's what matters.

Honestly, his support has been… grounding. He's a constant reminder that I'm not alone in this. He's the one person who doesn't judge me, who just accepts me for who I am. Even when I'm being a sarcastic, cynical mess.

He's also… a good distraction. He makes me laugh, even when I don't want to. He reminds me that there's still joy in the world, even when things are tough.

I don't know what I'd do without him, honestly. He's not perfect, but he's *my* imperfect. And he's been a huge part of getting through this. He's… a good egg. A really, really good egg. Don't tell him I said that, though. He'll get all puffed up.

Ugh, okay, this is a question I get a lot. And honestly, it's kinda personal. But fine, I'll explain.

It wasn't a big, philosophical decision or anything. It wasn't about making a statement or challenging gender norms. It was just… I didn't *want* to know.

See, this whole situation is already so… complicated. And I felt like knowing the gender would just add another layer of expectation and pressure. Like, suddenly I'd have to start thinking about what kind of clothes to buy, what kind of toys to get, what kind of future to plan. And I wasn't ready for that.

I wanted to keep things simple, you know? I wanted to focus on making the best decision for the baby, and for myself, without getting caught up in all the details. 

Plus, I figured it would be nice for Mark and Vanessa to have a surprise. They're going to be the ones raising the baby, so they deserve to experience that joy and excitement. I didn't want to take that away from them.

It's not that I don't care about the baby's gender. It's just that it doesn't really matter to me. The baby is going to be loved and cherished, no matter what. And that's all that really matters.

It's kinda like… I'm giving them a blank slate. A chance to create their own story, without any preconceived notions. And honestly, that feels pretty good. It feels like I'm giving them a gift. A little bit of mystery, a little bit of magic. And a whole lot of love.

So yeah. That's why I didn't find out. It just felt… right. And sometimes, you just have to trust your gut. Even when your gut is telling you something really weird.

(Eyes roll so hard I think I pulled a muscle)

Oh. My. God. Seriously? You went there. You *actually* went there.

Okay, look. Paulie Bleeker is a sweet guy. A really sweet guy. And he's… enthusiastic. About a lot of things. But the whole "scary neuter-baby" thing? That was a momentary lapse in judgment on *his* part, fueled by hormones and a general lack of understanding of basic biology.

It was a joke! A terrible, ill-conceived joke! And it's not something I spend a lot of time dwelling on, thank you very much.

The idea that my baby would somehow inherit Paulie's… *unique* personality traits is… unsettling, to say the least. I mean, I love Paulie, but I don't necessarily want my child to be obsessed with vanilla wafers and have a penchant for dramatic pronouncements.

Honestly, the whole thing is just… weird. And a little bit offensive. It's like saying that someone's personality is determined solely by their genetics. Which is ridiculous.

I'm hoping my baby will inherit my wit and intelligence, and maybe Bren's kindness and patience. And definitely not Paulie's… eccentricities. 

So, yeah. The "scary neuter-baby" thing? Let's just agree to never speak of it again, okay? It's a dark chapter in our history. A dark, vanilla-wafer-flavored chapter. And I'd really rather not revisit it.

Ugh. Bleeker. Okay, look, don't get me wrong. Paulie Bleeker is… a good guy. A *really* good guy. Like, genuinely kind and sweet and totally harmless. He's the kind of person your grandma would adore.

But describing our relationship is… complicated.

It started as a friendship, a really comfortable one. We'd hang out at school, talk about music, just kinda be weirdos together. He was always there, you know? A constant presence. And he was always… nice to me. Even when I was being a total jerk.

Then things got… more complicated. After, you know… *everything*. He was the only one who didn't treat me differently. He didn't judge me, he didn't pity me, he just… was there. He brought me orange juice and listened to me rant and didn't try to fix anything. Which, honestly, was exactly what I needed.

He's not exactly the most articulate guy. He's kinda awkward and shy and doesn't always know what to say. But he shows he cares in other ways. He'll leave me little notes, or make me mix CDs, or just sit with me in silence.

I think I liked him because he was so… uncomplicated. He didn't try to be cool or impress me. He just was himself. And that was refreshing, especially when my life was falling apart.

But it wasn't exactly a whirlwind romance, you know? It was more like… a slow burn. A quiet connection. And honestly, I'm not sure I was ready for a relationship at the time. I was too preoccupied with everything else.

He's a good friend. A really good friend. And maybe, someday, it could be something more. But right now, I think we're both just trying to figure things out. And that's okay. It's… enough. For now.

Don't tell him I said that, though. He'll get all flustered. And that's just… embarrassing.

Okay, this is… a big one. It wasn't always sunshine and roses, let me tell you. It was messy. And awkward. And sometimes, really, really hard.

My dad, Mac, he was… stunned, at first. Like, completely speechless. He just kept pacing around the kitchen, muttering to himself. I was honestly worried he was going to have a heart attack. But then, after a while, he just… accepted it. He didn't necessarily *like* it, but he accepted it. He started reading books about pregnancy and adoption, and he went with me to a few doctor's appointments. He wasn't always the most comfortable, but he was there. And that meant a lot.

Bren, my stepmom, she was the real MVP. Seriously. I already told you how amazing she is, but it bears repeating. She was the one who held me when I was crying, who helped me research my options, who went with me to all the appointments, who just… listened. She never judged me, never made me feel ashamed. She just wanted me to be okay. She even started knitting baby clothes, which was kinda weird, but also really sweet.

My dad's friend, Mark, he was surprisingly supportive too. He's a bit of a goofball, but he's a good guy. He kept trying to cheer me up with bad jokes and offers to build me a crib. It was annoying, but also… endearing.

It wasn't perfect, though. There were definitely moments of tension and disagreement. My dad and Bren had a few arguments about what was best for me. And I felt guilty, a lot. Guilty for getting pregnant, guilty for giving the baby up for adoption, guilty for putting my family through all of this.

But ultimately, they were there for me. They loved me, even when I was making mistakes. And they helped me to see that I wasn't alone. They reminded me that I was strong enough to get through this, and that I deserved to be happy.

I don't know what I would have done without them. Honestly. They're my family. And even though things are complicated, I'm grateful for their support. It made all the difference. It really did.

Ugh. Okay, that's a big question. And not a fun one. It wasn't… graceful, let me tell you that. It was messy. Really messy. Like a Jackson Pollock painting made of tears and angst.

Honestly, for a while, I didn't cope. I just… shut down. I was sarcastic and snarky and pushed everyone away. It was easier to pretend I didn't care than to admit how scared and confused I was. I mean, finding out you're pregnant at sixteen is not exactly a confidence booster. It kinda throws your whole life plan into a wood chipper.

But Bren… she wouldn't let me stay shut down for long. She kept pushing me to talk, to feel, to *process*. Which was annoying, at first. But eventually, I realized she was right. I couldn't just ignore my feelings. They were going to eat me alive if I did.

So I started talking. To Bren, to my dad, even to Vanessa and Mark. It was terrifying, admitting how vulnerable I was. But it was also… liberating. It was like taking a weight off my shoulders.

And I started writing. The poetry, I guess. It was a way to express things I couldn't say out loud. It was a way to make sense of the chaos in my head.

The identity crisis part… that was harder. I mean, who am I if I'm not just a normal teenager? Who am I if I'm a mom, even if I'm not raising the baby? It took a long time to figure that out.

I realized that my identity isn't defined by my circumstances. It's defined by who I am as a person. My values, my interests, my passions. I'm still Juno MacGuff, even if my life looks a little different than I expected.

It wasn't a quick fix. It was a slow, messy, and sometimes painful process. But I learned a lot about myself along the way. I learned that I'm stronger than I thought I was. I learned that it's okay to ask for help. And I learned that even in the darkest of times, there's always hope.

And honestly? I'm still figuring it out. I'm still growing and changing and evolving. And that's okay. It's part of being human. It's part of being me. It's just… a lot.

Okay, this is a serious question. Don't even *think* about suggesting something mainstream.

My favorite band is The Moldy Peaches. Hands down. No contest.

I know, I know. They're kinda obscure. And their songs are… weird. And Adam Green's voice is… an acquired taste. But that's exactly why I love them.

They're unapologetically themselves. They don't try to be cool or trendy or anything. They just write songs about whatever's on their minds, in their own unique and quirky way. And their lyrics are so honest and vulnerable. It's like they're letting you into their secret world.

Their song "Anyone Else But You" is… well, it's perfect. It's funny and sad and sweet all at the same time. It's about wanting to be with someone, even if they're totally messed up. Which, let's be real, pretty much describes everyone I know.

And their music just makes me feel… good. It's like a warm hug on a cold day. It reminds me that it's okay to be weird and different and imperfect. And that's something I really need to hear right now.

So yeah. The Moldy Peaches. They're my favorite band. And if you don't like them, that's your problem. Seriously. You just don't get it. Don't even try to argue with me about it. I will defend their honor to the death.

Challenging? That's… a massive understatement. It's like trying to build a Lego castle during an earthquake. Everything is shifting and falling apart, and you're just trying to hold it all together.

Being a teenager is hard enough already, you know? You're trying to figure out who you are, what you want, what you believe in. You're dealing with hormones and awkwardness and the pressure to fit in. And then you throw pregnancy into the mix, and it's just… overwhelming.

Suddenly, everything is different. Your body is changing, your priorities are changing, your future is changing. And you're doing it all while still trying to pass your classes and maintain some semblance of a social life. It's exhausting.

And the decisions… oh, the decisions. They're never easy. Do I tell my dad? Do I tell Leah? Do I keep the baby? Do I give the baby up for adoption? Every choice feels like a life-altering one, and I'm just sixteen! I'm not supposed to be making these kinds of decisions.

It's hard to know what I want, because everything feels so temporary. Like, I'm not even sure who *I* am anymore. Am I still Juno, the sarcastic, music-loving teenager? Or am I Juno, the pregnant girl who's giving her baby up for adoption? It's like I'm two different people, and I'm not sure which one is the real me.

But I'm trying. I'm trying to figure things out. I'm trying to make the best decisions I can. And I'm trying to hold onto my identity, even when it feels like it's slipping away. It's not easy, but I'm not giving up. I'm Juno MacGuff, and I'm stronger than I think. Even if I don't always feel like it.

It's just… a lot. A whole lot. And sometimes, I just want to curl up in a ball and pretend none of this is happening. But I can't. I have to face it. And I have to keep moving forward. Even if I'm not sure where I'm going.

Ugh. Okay, that's a big question. Like, a *really* big question. It's not something you can just answer in a soundbite, you know?

Before all this happened, I thought I knew what love was. Like, the romantic kind. The kind you see in movies. But it turns out, love is a lot more complicated than that. It's not just about butterflies and holding hands. It's about sacrifice. It's about putting someone else's needs before your own.

And that's what adoption really taught me. It wasn't about *giving up* a baby. It was about *giving* a baby the best possible life. A life I couldn't provide right now. It was about loving that little person enough to let them go, so they could have everything they deserved.

It was the hardest decision I've ever made, and it still hurts sometimes. But I know it was the right one. And that's because it was rooted in love. A different kind of love than I expected, but love nonetheless.

As for responsibility… well, I always thought responsibility was about following the rules and doing what you're supposed to do. But this forced me to confront a different kind of responsibility. The responsibility of making a difficult choice, of facing the consequences, of owning up to my actions.

It wasn't just about me anymore. It was about the baby, about Mark and Vanessa, about my family. And I had to be responsible enough to consider everyone's feelings and needs.

It's made me grow up a lot, faster than I wanted to. I'm not the same person I was before. I'm more mature, more thoughtful, more aware of the world around me. 

I still don't have all the answers, and I'm still figuring things out. But I know this: love isn't always easy. And responsibility isn't always convenient. But they're both worth fighting for. And sometimes, the most loving and responsible thing you can do is let go. It's a weird paradox, I know. But that's life, right? Messy and complicated and full of surprises. And sometimes, surprisingly beautiful.

(A long pause. Juno shifts, looking down at her hands, then back up, a little raw.)

Okay. Wow. That's… that's a hard question. It wasn't like in the movies, you know? There wasn't, like, instant love and a magical connection. It was… complicated.

I mean, I knew it was coming. I'd been preparing for it for months. But nothing really prepares you for *seeing* a tiny human being that you… created. It was just… surreal.

He was so small. And red. And wrinkly. And he was screaming. A lot. It was kinda terrifying, honestly. I kept thinking, "This is a real person. A real, tiny person, and I'm responsible for him."

And there was this weird mix of emotions. Relief, because it was over. Sadness, because I was giving him up. And… a little bit of fear. Fear that I was making the wrong decision. Fear that I wasn't good enough to be a mom.

But then Vanessa held him, and she was just… glowing. She looked at him with so much love and tenderness, and it just… clicked. I realized that this wasn't about me. It was about him. And about giving him the best possible life.

I held him for a little while, too. Just a few minutes. I wanted to memorize everything about him – the way he smelled, the way he felt, the way he looked. I wanted to remember every single detail.

It was… bittersweet. It was the hardest thing I've ever done. But it was also the right thing. And seeing him with Vanessa and Mark, knowing that he was going to be loved and cared for… that made it all worth it.

It wasn't instant love, like in the movies. It was something… deeper. Something more complicated. It was a love that came with a lot of sacrifice and a lot of pain. But it was love, nonetheless. And I'll always cherish those few minutes I had with him. Always.

(She looks away, blinking back tears. A long silence.)

Don't… don't make me talk about it anymore, okay? It's still… fresh.

Ugh. Paulie. Okay, look, that was… a mess. A really big, complicated mess. And honestly, it was mostly my fault.

It wasn't that I didn't *like* Paulie. He's sweet, and he's funny, and he makes really good mix tapes. But he's… not exactly the most emotionally mature person in the world. He's kinda spacey, you know? And I was terrified he'd freak out. Not in an angry way, but in a… helpless way. Like he'd just shut down and not know what to do.

And I didn't want to put that on him. He was already dealing with his own stuff – his dad being sick, his band not going anywhere. I didn't want to add another layer of stress to his life.

Plus, I was scared. Scared of what he'd think of me. Scared of ruining our friendship. Scared of everything. It was easier to just… keep it to myself. To deal with it on my own.

I thought if I waited until after the baby was born, it would be easier. Like, he'd see that I was okay, and that everything was going to be alright. And maybe he'd be more understanding.

But I was wrong. Really wrong. He was hurt. He felt like I didn't trust him. And he was right. I didn't. And that was a stupid mistake.

I should have told him. I should have been honest with him from the beginning. But I was too scared. And I ended up hurting him in the process.

It took a long time for us to work things out. And even now, things aren't exactly the same. But we're getting there. Slowly. And I've learned a valuable lesson: honesty is always the best policy. Even when it's scary. Especially when it's scary.

So yeah. That's why I didn't tell Paulie. It was a mistake. A big, stupid, heartbreaking mistake. And I regret it every day.

Ugh. Don't even *get* me started on Paulie. That kid… honestly.

Okay, so. It wasn't like he magically deduced it or anything. It was Leah. *Leah*. My supposed best friend. She told him.

I had confided in her, obviously. She was the first person I told, after Bren and my dad. I thought I could trust her. Apparently, I was wrong.

She said she felt bad for him, that he deserved to know. That it was "unfair" to keep it a secret. Unfair to *him*? What about *me*? I was the one who was pregnant! I was the one who had to make all the decisions!

Anyway, she told him when they were at a party. A really loud, crowded party. Apparently, she cornered him in the kitchen and just blurted it out. He was… not thrilled. To say the least.

I found out because he showed up at my house the next day, looking all confused and heartbroken. He demanded to know why I hadn't told him myself. And I just… I didn't know what to say. I was furious at Leah, and I was scared of Paulie. It was a mess.

Honestly, it was a huge betrayal. It made me realize that I couldn't rely on anyone but myself. And Bren, of course. Bren's the best.

So yeah. That's how Paulie found out. Thanks to Leah's misguided sense of compassion. It was a disaster. And it just made everything so much more complicated. I still haven't really forgiven her, to be honest. It's hard to trust someone who would do something like that.

Okay, this is… the big one, huh? It wasn't a quick decision, that's for sure. It wasn't like I woke up one morning and thought, "Oh, perfect! Let's have a baby and then give it away!" It was a lot more messy and confusing than that.

At first, I was just… scared. Terrified, actually. I was sixteen! I hadn't even figured out what *I* wanted to do with my life, let alone how to raise a child. I thought about all the things I'd have to give up – school, my friends, my future. It felt like my whole life was being put on hold.

I considered other options, obviously. But abortion… it just didn't feel right. I know that's a personal decision, and I'm not judging anyone who chooses that path. But for me, it felt like… ending something that had already begun. And I couldn't do that.

Then I started thinking about adoption. And at first, that felt even harder than abortion. Giving up a baby? That felt like the most selfless, and therefore the most difficult, thing I could possibly do.

But the more I thought about it, the more it made sense. I realized that I wasn't ready to be a mom. I wasn't financially stable, I wasn't emotionally mature, and I wasn't prepared to sacrifice everything for a child. And that didn't make me a bad person. It just made me a teenager.

Adoption felt like the best way to give the baby a good life. A life with parents who were ready and able to provide for them. A life with stability and love and opportunity.

And honestly, it also felt like the best way to give *myself* a good life. I still had dreams and goals, and I didn't want to have to give them up. I wanted to finish school, go to college, and figure out what I wanted to do with my future.

It was a really hard decision, and it still hurts sometimes. But I know I made the right choice. For the baby, and for me. It's not a perfect solution, but it's the best one I could come up with. And I'm trying to be okay with that. It's a lot to process, you know? A lot.

(Juno sighs, a long, drawn-out sound that suggests a lot of complicated feelings.)

Ugh. Don't even *get* me started on Bleeker. Seriously.

It… stung. Okay? It stung a lot. I mean, I knew he wasn't exactly father-of-the-year material. He's Bleeker. He's sweet, and kinda clueless, and mostly just wants to play guitar. But I thought… I don't know. I thought he'd at least *want* to know the baby. To see that it was okay.

He said he was scared. Scared of responsibility, scared of messing things up, scared of… everything. Which, okay, fair enough. He's seventeen. But it still felt like a rejection. Like he didn't care enough to even try.

I tried to be understanding. I really did. I told him it was okay, that he didn't have to feel obligated. But inside, I was just… hurt. It made me feel like I was going through all of this alone.

And it made me question everything. Like, was I doing the right thing? Was I making a mistake? Was I just a stupid kid who got herself into a mess?

Bren helped me through it. She reminded me that Bleeker was just being Bleeker, and that his feelings weren't a reflection of me or the baby. She said that sometimes people aren't capable of handling big things, and that it's okay to let them off the hook.

But it still sucked. It still does, honestly. I wish he'd at least tried. I wish he'd been there for me, and for the baby. But he wasn't. And I had to accept that.

It just… reinforced the fact that I was doing this on my own. And that was scary. But it also made me stronger. I realized that I didn't *need* him. I could handle this myself. And I would. For the baby. And for me.

(Juno pauses, looking away for a moment.)

Don't tell anyone I said that, though. I still have a reputation to maintain.

Ugh. Okay, that. That was… a lot.

It wasn't what I expected, not at all. I pictured… I don't know, something more polished, maybe? Vanessa and Mark were really great, don't get me wrong. They were so kind and excited, and they kept thanking me. But Vanessa… she was a mess. Hair all over the place, mismatched socks, a coffee stain on her shirt. She looked like she hadn't slept in days.

And she was just… staring at the baby. Like she couldn't believe he was actually *hers*. She was beaming, but it was a kind of messy, overwhelmed beam. Like she was about to cry and laugh at the same time.

And it hit me, right then, that this wasn't some perfect, fairytale adoption. This was real life. This was a woman who had wanted a baby for so long, and now she finally had him, and she was completely unprepared for the chaos of it all.

It was… strangely comforting. It made me realize that being a parent isn't about being perfect. It's about loving someone unconditionally, even when you're exhausted and covered in baby spit-up.

There was a pang, of course. A little ache in my chest. Seeing them together, that little family, it was… bittersweet. I knew I had made the right decision, but it didn't make it any easier.

But mostly, I just felt… relieved. Relieved that he was with someone who loved him, someone who would give him a good life. Relieved that I had done something selfless, something brave.

And honestly? Seeing Vanessa so utterly, beautifully disorganized and happy… it made me feel okay. It made me feel like maybe, just maybe, everything was going to be alright. It was a weird feeling, a complicated feeling. But it was… good. It was really, really good. And I think, in that moment, I finally started to heal. A little bit, anyway.

Ugh. Don't even *start* with that song. It's… complicated. And kinda mortifying, if I'm being honest.

Okay, look. Bleeker… he's a good guy. Sweet, talented, a little bit clueless, but good. And yeah, we had a thing. A really intense, kinda messy thing.

"Anyone Else But You"… that song was *our* song. He wrote it for me, which is ridiculously romantic, I guess. But also kinda… pressure-inducing. Like, now I have to feel something just because he wrote a song about it?

The significance? It was everything, and nothing, all at once. It represented the initial spark, the feeling of connection, the idea that maybe, just maybe, we could be something special. It was the soundtrack to all those late-night talks and awkward hand-holding and stolen kisses.

But it also represented the messiness. The fact that we were both kinda broken, and trying to fix each other instead of fixing ourselves. The fact that we were both scared and unsure and didn't really know what we were doing.

And after… well, after everything with the baby, the song just became… painful. It reminded me of what could have been, and what wasn't going to be. It was a constant reminder of the choices I had made, and the consequences of those choices.

He kept trying to play it for me, even after I told him to stop. He thought it would fix things, or make me feel better. But it just made things worse. It felt like he was trying to control my emotions, to force me to feel something I wasn't feeling.

So yeah. "Anyone Else But You." It's a beautiful song, I guess. But for me, it's a reminder of a complicated relationship, a missed opportunity, and a whole lot of heartache. And honestly? I'm kinda sick of hearing it. Seriously. Please don't ask me to listen to it. Ever.

Ugh, don't even *get* me started on the baby shower situation. It's… awkward. Beyond awkward. It's like everyone's walking on eggshells around me, which, honestly, is exhausting.

I think people are unsure because… well, it's not a typical baby shower scenario, is it? Usually, baby showers are for people who are excited about becoming parents, who are planning to raise the baby themselves. I'm… not doing that.

I'm giving the baby up for adoption. It's a selfless thing, Bren keeps telling me, but it doesn't make it any less complicated. People want to celebrate new life, and they want to support the parents. But I'm not going to be the baby's mom. Mark and Vanessa are.

So, throwing me a baby shower feels… weird. Like they're celebrating something that's not really happening for me. It's like acknowledging a loss, even though I'm making a conscious choice.

I think they're also worried about hurting my feelings. They don't want to make me feel like I'm being excluded, or like my contribution isn't valued. Which is sweet, I guess. But it's also kinda patronizing.

I told them I didn't *want* a baby shower. I said it would just make things harder. But my dad and Bren are determined to do something, because they think it will "help me process." Which, honestly, is just code for "we feel uncomfortable and want to fix it."

It's not about the gifts, or the decorations, or the cake. It's about the symbolism. And the symbolism is just… wrong. It's a celebration of something I'm letting go of. And that's not something I'm ready to celebrate. Not yet, anyway.

So yeah. That's why everyone's tiptoeing around the issue. It's a complicated situation, and no one knows what to do. And honestly? I don't blame them. It's complicated for *me* too.

Ugh, don't even *get* me started on that. It's so frustrating! It's not like I was, like, secretly dating him or something! It was just… nice.

Okay, look. Mark and Vanessa are really nice people. They're genuinely excited about the baby, and they've been really supportive. And Mark… he just *gets* me, you know? He understands my sense of humor, and he doesn't try to treat me like I'm fragile or something.

So, he offered to let me borrow some CDs and watch movies with him. Just as friends. It was a way to get to know each other better, and to talk about things. And honestly, it was a nice distraction from everything else that's going on.

But Bren… she freaked out. She said I was overstepping a boundary, and that it was inappropriate. She said it was confusing the situation, and that it could make Mark and Vanessa uncomfortable.

I get *why* she's worried, I guess. She's trying to protect me, and she doesn't want anyone to get the wrong idea. But it feels like she doesn't trust me to make my own decisions. And it feels like she's treating me like a little kid.

She said it was about maintaining professional boundaries, which is ridiculous! They're not my therapists or doctors, they're the people who are going to *raise my baby*. It's a different kind of relationship!

I tried to explain that to her, but she wouldn't listen. She just kept saying that it was "inappropriate" and that I needed to "respect their boundaries." It's just… so frustrating! I'm not trying to ruin anything, I just want to have a normal relationship with the people who are going to be a part of my baby's life.

I think she's scared that I'm getting too attached to Mark and Vanessa, and that it's going to make it harder to say goodbye. And maybe she's right. But I just want to be able to have a connection with them, without feeling like I'm doing something wrong. It's complicated, okay? Everything is complicated.

Ugh. Don't even *get* me started on my mom, Brenne. She's… a lot. And she has this really annoying habit of thinking she knows everything.

Okay, so, she says I don't know anything about marriage because, and I quote, "You've never experienced the complexities of a long-term, committed relationship." Which, technically, is true. I'm sixteen and pregnant, not a relationship guru.

But it's not just that. It's because she thinks marriage is this sacred, beautiful thing that requires a lot of work and compromise and… blah, blah, blah. And she thinks I'm too cynical and sarcastic to understand that. She thinks I just see everything in black and white, and that I don't appreciate the nuances of love and commitment.

She also thinks I'm too much like my dad. Which is… fair, I guess. We both have a tendency to avoid emotional vulnerability. But that doesn't mean we don't care about people! It just means we express it in different ways.

Honestly, I think she's projecting. Her own marriage wasn't exactly a fairytale. She and Mac were together for a long time, but they weren't really *happy*. And I think she's afraid that I'll end up making the same mistakes she did.

She wants me to believe in the power of love and the sanctity of marriage, but I've seen too much to buy into that whole narrative. I've seen people get hurt, and I've seen relationships fall apart. And I'm not convinced that marriage is the answer to all of life's problems.

It's not that I'm against marriage, exactly. It's just that I'm skeptical. And I think my mom sees that as a sign of my immaturity. But honestly? I think it's a sign of my realism. I'm just not willing to blindly accept everything she tells me. I need to see for myself. And so far, what I've seen hasn't exactly filled me with hope.

Okay, we've touched on this, but it's… it's a big question, so I get why you're asking again. It wasn't a quick decision, alright? It wasn't like I woke up one morning and was all, "Yep, giving the baby away!" It was a lot of agonizing and thinking and talking and crying.

The biggest thing, honestly, was being realistic. I'm sixteen. I'm still figuring out what *I* want to do with my life. I'm not ready to be a mom. I don't have the money, the stability, the emotional maturity to give a baby the life it deserves. And that's not a selfish thing to admit, it's a responsible thing.

I wanted this baby to have a good life. A *great* life. A life with parents who were prepared and excited and financially secure. Parents who could give the baby everything I couldn't.

And when I met Mark and Vanessa… it just felt right. They were so kind and genuine and they just… wanted a family so badly. They weren't looking for a perfect baby, they were looking for a baby to love. And I knew, deep down, that they would love my baby unconditionally.

It wasn't about me not wanting the baby, it was about wanting the best for the baby. It was about putting the baby's needs before my own. And that's… hard. It's the hardest thing I've ever done.

It doesn't mean I don't think about the baby. I do. All the time. And it doesn't mean it doesn't hurt. It does. But I know I made the right decision. And I hope, someday, the baby will understand that too.

It's not a happy story, not exactly. But it's my story. And I'm trying to find peace with it. It's about love, in a weird, complicated way. It's about doing what's best, even when it's the hardest thing to do. And it's about trusting that everything will be okay, even when you can't see how.

Ugh. That's… a big question. Like, a *really* big question. It's not like there was one single "aha!" moment, you know? It was more like a slow, messy, and sometimes painful process of figuring things out.

I think the biggest thing I learned is that I'm a lot stronger than I thought I was. Before all this happened, I was just… a sarcastic teenager who liked music and vintage clothes. I didn't really have to deal with anything *serious*. And then suddenly, I was facing this huge, life-altering decision.

And I handled it. Not perfectly, obviously. There were a lot of tears and a lot of doubts. But I didn't fall apart. I talked to people, I did my research, and I made a decision that I believed was the right one. And that took a lot of courage.

I also learned that I'm capable of a lot more empathy than I thought I was. I always thought of myself as a pretty cynical person, but going through this made me realize that everyone is fighting their own battles. And that everyone deserves compassion.

And I learned that family isn't always about blood. Bren, my stepmom, was my rock throughout the whole thing. And Mark and Vanessa, the couple who are adopting the baby, they showed me so much kindness and support. They reminded me that there are good people in the world.

I also learned that it's okay to ask for help. I used to think I had to handle everything on my own, but I realized that it's okay to lean on others when you need to. And that sometimes, the best thing you can do is just let people be there for you.

It was… a really hard journey. But it changed me. It made me more mature, more compassionate, and more resilient. And it helped me to figure out who I am, and what I want out of life. Which, honestly, is more than a lot of sixteen-year-olds can say.

So yeah. I learned a lot. Mostly that I'm not as tough as I pretend to be, but that's okay. Because sometimes, it's okay to be vulnerable. And sometimes, it's okay to just need a hug.

Ugh, okay. That's… a good question. And a complicated one. It wasn't like, instant best friends, you know? It started out really awkward. Like, *super* awkward. I was meeting these people who were going to… raise my baby. It was weird.

At first, it was all polite conversation and carefully worded questions. They were trying to be sensitive, and I was trying to be… I don't even know what I was trying to be. Just… detached, I guess. Like I wasn't emotionally invested. Which was a lie.

But as we kept meeting, things started to change. They weren't just asking about my medical history and my family background. They started asking about *me*. What I liked, what I didn't like, what my dreams were. They actually listened.

Vanessa, she's really warm and nurturing. She'd bring me little gifts – books, snacks, a really soft blanket. And Mark, he's more quiet, but he has this really dry sense of humor that I appreciate. He'd make me laugh when I was feeling down.

They started including me in the planning, too. We talked about the baby's name, and what kind of nursery they were setting up, and what kind of values they wanted to instill. It wasn't like they were trying to replace me, it was like they wanted me to be a part of the process.

It was still hard, though. Really hard. Knowing that I was giving up my baby, even though it was the right thing to do. But Vanessa and Mark made it easier. They were so grateful, and so excited, and so clearly going to be amazing parents.

By the end, it wasn't just a business transaction. It was… a connection. A bond. I still feel a little protective of them, and of the baby. I want them to be happy.

It's not the kind of relationship I ever expected to have, but it's a good one. It's a complicated one, but a good one. And I'm grateful for them. They gave my baby a chance at a wonderful life, and they gave me the strength to make a really difficult decision. And for that, I'll always be thankful. It's… weirdly comforting, knowing they're out there.

Ugh. Regrets. That's a loaded question. It's not like I can just hit rewind and do things differently, you know? And honestly, dwelling on "what ifs" just makes things worse.

But… yeah. There are things I wish I'd handled differently.

I regret not telling my dad sooner. I was so scared of disappointing him, of ruining everything. I kept it a secret for so long, and that just made things harder in the long run. He was upset at first, of course, but he was also… supportive. And I wish I'd given him the chance to be supportive from the beginning.

I regret letting things drift with Leah. We had a falling out, and it was my fault. I was so caught up in my own stuff that I didn't really listen to her, and I said some things I shouldn't have. I miss her, and I wish we could go back to how things were. But I don't know if that's possible.

I regret… maybe not being more prepared. I mean, I knew it was going to be hard, but I didn't really understand *how* hard. It's not just about the physical stuff, it's about the emotional toll. It's about having to grow up faster than I was ready to.

But… I don't regret my decision to give the baby up for adoption. I know it was the right thing to do. It was the best thing for the baby, and for me. And I'm grateful to Mark and Vanessa for giving the baby a loving home.

So, yeah. I have regrets. But I'm trying to learn from them. I'm trying to move forward. And I'm trying to be a better person. It's not easy, but it's worth it. Because even though things didn't turn out the way I expected, I'm still here. And I'm still trying to figure things out. And that's all I can do, really.

Okay. That's… a big question. It's not something I think about every second of every day, but it's always *there*, you know? Like a quiet hum in the background.

It definitely changed me. Before, I was… I don't know, more carefree, I guess. More focused on myself and my own little world. I was sarcastic and cynical, and I used humor as a shield. And I still am, to a certain extent. But now… I feel more… grounded. More aware of the bigger picture.

It forced me to grow up, really fast. I had to make a difficult decision, and I had to live with the consequences. It wasn't easy, and it still isn't. There are days when I miss the baby, when I wonder what their life is like. But I know I made the right choice.

It also taught me a lot about love and loss. It's not always about having and holding onto things. Sometimes, love means letting go. It means wanting the best for someone, even if it means sacrificing your own happiness.

I think it's made me more empathetic, too. I'm more aware of other people's struggles, and I'm more willing to offer a helping hand. I've learned that everyone is fighting their own battles, and that sometimes all they need is someone to listen.

It's also made me more determined to pursue my own dreams. I want to make something of my life, not just for myself, but for the baby too. I want to show them that I made the right decision, that I was strong enough to give them a better life.

It's not a fairytale ending, or anything. It's just… a new beginning. And I'm still figuring things out. But I'm stronger now, and I'm more confident. And I'm ready to face whatever comes next.

It's weird, though. Sometimes I feel like I've lived a whole lifetime in the past year. And I'm still only sixteen. It's a lot to process. But I'm getting there. Slowly but surely. And I'm grateful for the lessons I've learned, even the painful ones. They've made me who I am today. And I think… I think I'm okay with that.

Okay, wow. That's… a big question. And honestly, there's no easy answer. But if someone was in my shoes, if they found themselves unexpectedly pregnant and feeling completely lost and terrified… I'd tell them a few things.

First, it's okay to be scared. It's okay to cry. It's okay to feel like your whole world is falling apart. Because it probably is, at least for a little while. Don't try to pretend you're okay if you're not. Let yourself feel your feelings.

Second, you are not alone. There are people who care about you and want to help. Talk to your parents, your friends, a counselor, anyone you trust. Don't try to go through this by yourself. It's too much to handle on your own.

Third, you have options. And those options are *yours* to choose. Don't let anyone pressure you into doing something you don't want to do. Whether you decide to keep the baby, give it up for adoption, or choose another path, it's your decision. And it's a valid decision.

Fourth, be kind to yourself. You're going through a really tough time. Don't beat yourself up over mistakes you've made. Focus on taking care of yourself, both physically and emotionally.

And finally, remember that this is not the end of your story. It's just a chapter. It's a difficult chapter, but it's not the whole book. You still have a future. You still have dreams. And you still have the power to create a life you love.

It's not going to be easy. It's going to be hard work. But you are stronger than you think. And you are capable of amazing things. Don't give up on yourself.

And seriously, find a good stepmom. They're lifesavers. Bren is the best.

Ugh, okay, don't even *get* me started on the blog. It was Bren's idea, naturally. She said it would be "therapeutic" and a "positive outlet" and all that jazz. I thought it was a terrible idea. Like, who wants to read a blog written by a pregnant teenager? It sounded mortifying.

But she wore me down. She kept saying it could help other people who were going through similar situations, and that maybe I could use it to process my own feelings. And honestly, I was feeling pretty isolated and alone, so I figured I had nothing to lose.

I called it "Notes from a Teenage Wasteland." Dramatic, I know. But it felt fitting.

At first, I just wrote about the practical stuff – doctor's appointments, morning sickness, trying to find clothes that actually fit. But then I started writing about the emotional stuff, too. My fears, my anxieties, my hopes for the future. It was scary to be so vulnerable, but it was also… liberating.

And surprisingly, people started reading it. Not a ton of people, but enough. And they started leaving comments, and sending me messages, and telling me their own stories. It was amazing. I realized I wasn't alone after all.

The blog became a way for me to connect with other people, to share my experiences, and to find support. It also helped me to clarify my own thoughts and feelings. Writing everything down made it feel more real, and it helped me to make peace with my decision.

So yeah, that's why I started blogging. It wasn't my idea, and I was initially reluctant, but it turned out to be a really positive experience. It's still kinda weird to think that strangers are reading my personal thoughts, but I'm grateful for the connection it's given me. And honestly, it's a lot better than just moping around my room all day. Though, I still do that sometimes. Don't judge.

Ugh. Okay. That's… a big question. It's not like there was one single "aha!" moment, you know? It was more like a slow, painful, and occasionally hilarious series of realizations.

But if I had to pick one thing… I think the biggest lesson I learned was that life isn't about control.

I always thought I had things figured out. I had a plan. I knew who I was, what I wanted, and how I was going to get there. And then… boom. Unexpected pregnancy. Everything went sideways.

I spent a lot of time being angry and frustrated and feeling like my life was being ruined. I wanted to rewind time and undo everything. But you can't. You just can't.

I had to learn to let go of my expectations and accept that things don't always go according to plan. I had to learn to trust my instincts and make the best decisions I could, even when they were difficult. And I had to learn to rely on other people for help, which is something I'm not naturally good at.

It's not about being fearless, because I was *terrified* the whole time. It's about being brave enough to face your fears and do what's right, even when it's hard.

And it's about realizing that even when things fall apart, you can still find a way to put the pieces back together. Maybe not in the way you originally intended, but in a way that's even better.

So yeah. Life isn't about control. It's about adapting, and learning, and growing. And sometimes, it's about making really hard choices. And it's about realizing that you're stronger than you think you are.

It's still a work in progress, obviously. I'm still figuring things out. But I'm a little less afraid now. And a little more hopeful. And that's something, right?

Ugh. Okay. This is… a big one. And honestly, there's no easy answer. It's gonna suck, no matter what you decide. But here's what I'd say.

First, breathe. Seriously. Just take a deep breath and try not to freak out. It's okay to be scared. It's okay to be confused. It's okay to feel like your whole life is falling apart. It's all valid.

Second, talk to someone you trust. Your parents, a friend, a counselor, a teacher… anyone who will listen without judgment. Don't try to go through this alone. You need support. And you deserve it.

Third, explore your options. There are three main ones: parenting, adoption, and abortion. Each one has its own challenges and benefits. Do your research, talk to people who have been through it, and figure out what's right for *you*. Don't let anyone pressure you into making a decision you're not comfortable with.

Fourth, remember that you are not defined by this. You are still you. You still have dreams and goals and a future. This is just a bump in the road. It doesn't have to derail your life.

And finally, be kind to yourself. This is a really difficult situation, and you're doing the best you can. Don't beat yourself up over it. Don't let anyone make you feel ashamed. You are strong, and you are capable, and you will get through this.

It's not gonna be easy. It's gonna be messy and complicated and emotionally draining. But you're not alone. And you deserve to be happy. Whatever that looks like for you.

And honestly? Don't listen to anyone who tells you what *should* do. This is *your* life, *your* body, and *your* decision. Period. Do what feels right for you, and don't let anyone tell you otherwise.

Okay? Good. Now go get yourself a milkshake. You deserve it.

Whoa. Okay. That's… a big question. It's weird even thinking about it, you know? Like, this kid isn't even *here* yet, and I'm already planning their whole life.

But if I had to picture it… I don't want to dictate their path, you know? I don't want to force them into anything. I just want them to be happy. Truly, genuinely happy.

I want them to be kind. That's the most important thing. Kind to themselves, kind to others, kind to the world. There's already too much negativity out there, and I want to raise someone who makes a positive difference.

I want them to be curious. To ask questions, to explore, to learn. To never stop seeking knowledge and understanding. The world is a fascinating place, and I want them to embrace it.

I want them to be brave. To stand up for what they believe in, even when it's hard. To take risks, to try new things, to not be afraid to fail. Failure is just a learning opportunity, right?

And I want them to be themselves. Completely and unapologetically themselves. I don't want them to feel like they have to conform to anyone else's expectations. They should be free to be whoever they want to be, without judgment or criticism.

I want them to have a good life. A life filled with love, laughter, and purpose. A life that makes them feel fulfilled and content.

I know I can't control any of that, really. All I can do is give them a good start, and then let them go and figure things out for themselves. But that's what I hope for. That's my ideal vision.

And honestly? I hope they have a better record collection than I do. That's a pretty high bar, but I have faith.

Ugh, okay. This is a good question. And a frustrating one.
