The biggest misconception, hands down, is that we're just… irresponsible. That we're all just silly, careless kids who didn't think things through. Like we just woke up one day and decided, "Oh, a baby! That sounds fun!"

It's not like that. At all.

Yeah, maybe we made a mistake. Maybe we weren't as careful as we should have been. But that doesn't mean we don't care. It doesn't mean we're not scared. It doesn't mean we're not thinking about the future.

We're just… young. We're still figuring things out. We're still trying to find our place in the world. And now we have this huge responsibility thrown into the mix. It's overwhelming.

People act like we're all trying to get pregnant, like it's some kind of status symbol. That's just… ridiculous. It's hard. It's really, really hard. And it takes a lot of courage to deal with it.

I wish people would stop judging us and start offering support. We need help. We need understanding. We need people to believe in us.

We're not just "teen mothers." We're people. We're individuals. We have dreams and hopes and fears, just like everyone else. And we deserve to be treated with respect.

So, yeah. That's the biggest misconception. We're not irresponsible. We're just… young people facing a really difficult situation. And we're doing the best we can. And that's all anyone can ask for, really.

Okay, look. This is… the big one, right? The question everyone wants to ask. And it's not a simple answer. It's not like I woke up one morning and decided, "Oh, yeah, I'll just give my baby away." It was a lot more complicated than that.

First of all, I'm sixteen. *Sixteen*. I'm still figuring out what I want to eat for breakfast, let alone how to raise a human being. I'm not ready to be a mom. I don't have the financial stability, the emotional maturity, or the life experience to give a baby the kind of life it deserves.

And it's not just about me. It's about the baby, too. Every kid deserves parents who are fully prepared and excited to raise them. Parents who can provide for their needs, both physical and emotional. I wanted my baby to have that.

I thought about all the possibilities. Keeping the baby and trying to finish school, relying on my dad and Bren for support. But that felt… selfish. It felt like I was putting my own needs ahead of the baby's.

Then I met Mark and Vanessa. They were… perfect. They were a loving, stable couple who had been trying to adopt for years. They were so excited about the prospect of becoming parents. And when I met them, I just knew that they would be amazing parents.

It wasn't an easy decision. It was the hardest decision I've ever had to make. I cried a lot. I second-guessed myself a million times. But ultimately, I knew it was the right thing to do.

It wasn't about giving up on my baby. It was about giving my baby the best possible life. And that meant letting go. It meant trusting that Mark and Vanessa would love and care for my baby in a way that I couldn't.

It still hurts, you know? It always will. But I find comfort in knowing that my baby is with people who will cherish them and give them everything they need. And that's all I ever wanted. It wasn't the plan, but sometimes, life throws you curveballs. And you just have to swing for the fences. Even if you miss.

Okay, that was… a process. It wasn't like flipping through a catalog and picking the ones with the nicest smiles. It was way more complicated than that. Bren was really good about making sure I didn't rush into anything. She said it had to feel *right*.

There were a lot of profiles. A lot of couples. Some seemed… perfect on paper. Successful, stable, a nice house. But something always felt off. They felt… performative, you know? Like they were trying too hard to be the perfect parents.

Then we met Vanessa and Mark. And it was different. They weren't trying to impress anyone. They were just… real. They talked about wanting a family, about wanting to give a child a loving home. But they also talked about the challenges of parenthood, about the sleepless nights and the tantrums and the endless responsibility.

They didn't ask me a lot of personal questions. They didn't pry into my life. They just wanted to know what *I* wanted for the baby. And they listened. Really listened.

We had lunch with them a few times, and I just… felt comfortable around them. They weren't judgmental, they were kind. They didn't treat me like a teenage mistake, they treated me like a person.

Mark is a little goofy, which I liked. He told terrible jokes and made silly faces. And Vanessa is really warm and nurturing. She just has this way of making you feel safe and cared for.

I remember one time, I was feeling really overwhelmed and emotional, and Vanessa just put her arm around me and let me cry. She didn't say anything, she just held me. And that meant more to me than anything.

It wasn't a logical decision, it was a gut feeling. I just knew, deep down, that they were the right people to raise my baby. They would love him or her unconditionally, and they would give them a good life. And that's all I could ask for.

It still doesn't make it easy, you know? Giving up my baby is going to be the hardest thing I've ever done. But knowing that he or she is going to be with Vanessa and Mark… that makes it a little bit easier. A little bit.

Oh. Music. Okay, buckle up, because this is a big one. Music wasn't just *in* my life during my teenage years, it *was* my life. Seriously. It was my escape, my confidante, my therapist, my… everything.

When things got weird – which, let's be real, was pretty much constantly – I'd just put on headphones and disappear. It was the only way to block out the noise and focus on something that actually mattered.

I wasn't into mainstream pop or anything. That stuff just felt… fake. I gravitated towards indie bands, singer-songwriters, anything that felt raw and honest. The Moldy Peaches were huge for me. Their songs were so quirky and vulnerable, it was like they were reading my mind. Belle & Sebastian, too. Their lyrics were so poetic and melancholic, they just resonated with me on a deep level.

I spent hours scouring record stores for hidden gems. Vinyl was the only way to go, obviously. It just sounds better, you know? Warmer, more authentic. Plus, the album art is always amazing.

I also tried to learn to play guitar. I wasn't very good, but it was fun to strum along to my favorite songs and pretend I was a rock star. I even wrote a few songs of my own, though they were mostly just angsty teenage ramblings. I'd never show them to anyone, though. They're too embarrassing.

Music helped me to process my emotions, to make sense of the world, and to feel less alone. It was a constant source of comfort and inspiration. And even now, when things are still kinda messy and complicated, I still turn to music. It's the one thing that always makes me feel better.

It's not just about the songs themselves, either. It's about the whole experience. The feeling of holding a record in your hands, the crackle of the vinyl, the way the music fills the room. It's a sensory experience that just… transports you.

So yeah. Music was a pretty big deal. Still is, actually. It's the soundtrack to my life. And I don't know what I'd do without it.

Ugh. The stigma. Don't even get me started. Maplewood is… not exactly known for its progressive thinking. Let's just say there were a *lot* of whispers and side-eyes. And judgment. So. Much. Judgment.

Honestly? It sucked. It really, really sucked. It felt like everyone was looking at me like I was some kind of… freak. Like I'd committed some terrible crime. And the worst part was, a lot of it came from people who didn't even know me.

At first, I tried to ignore it. I just kept my head down and tried to blend in. But that didn't work. The whispers followed me everywhere. And it was exhausting trying to pretend like everything was normal when it clearly wasn't.

Then I started getting angry. I was angry at everyone who was judging me, angry at the situation, angry at myself. I lashed out at people, I shut myself off, I just generally made everything worse.

But Bren helped me see that getting angry wasn't going to solve anything. She told me that people are always going to judge, and that I couldn't control what they thought. But I *could* control how I reacted to it.

So I started to… own it. I stopped trying to hide. I started talking about it openly and honestly, with people I trusted. And I realized that a lot of the judgment came from ignorance and fear. People just didn't understand.

It wasn't easy. There were still people who were mean and judgmental. But I learned to tune them out. I focused on the people who supported me – my dad, Bren, a few close friends. And I realized that their opinions were the only ones that really mattered.

I also found strength in knowing that I was making the right decision for myself and for the baby. It wasn't the easiest decision, but it was the most responsible one. And that gave me the confidence to ignore the haters.

It still stings sometimes, you know? But I've learned to be okay with being different. And I've learned that true strength comes from being true to yourself, even when everyone else is trying to tell you who to be. And honestly? I think I'm a stronger person for having gone through it. Even if it was totally awful.

Okay. This is… still hard to talk about, even now. It wasn't like ripping off a band-aid, you know? It was more like… a slow unraveling. A lot of complicated feelings all tangled up together.

Giving birth to Phoenix… that was intense. Obviously. But it was also… beautiful. He was so tiny and perfect, and holding him for those few hours… it was the most amazing and heartbreaking thing I've ever experienced.

And then handing him over to Mark and Vanessa… that was the hardest thing I've ever done. I thought I was prepared, but I wasn't. It felt like a piece of my heart was being torn away. I cried. A lot. Bren held me, and my dad just… stood there, looking sad.

But seeing Mark and Vanessa with him… seeing how much they already loved him… that helped. They were so gentle and loving, and they looked at him like he was the most precious thing in the world. And he *was*. He is.

The first few weeks were really rough. I felt empty and lost and confused. I kept replaying everything in my head, wondering if I'd made the right decision. Bren kept telling me I had, and that it was okay to grieve, but it didn't really help.

But slowly, over time, it got easier. I started to realize that giving Phoenix up for adoption wasn't about giving him *away*. It was about giving him the best life possible. A life that I couldn't provide for him right now.

And Mark and Vanessa kept me updated. They sent pictures and videos, and told me about all the milestones he was reaching. It was comforting to know that he was happy and healthy and loved.

It still hurts sometimes, you know? I'll see a baby and it'll just… hit me. But I've come to terms with my decision. I know I did the right thing. And I'm grateful to Mark and Vanessa for giving Phoenix a wonderful home.

It wasn't easy. It was probably the hardest thing I'll ever do. But it taught me a lot about love, and sacrifice, and what it means to be a parent. And it made me realize that family isn't always about blood. It's about connection and commitment and caring for each other, no matter what.

So yeah. It was… complicated. But ultimately, it was good. For everyone. Even me.

Ugh. Don't even get me started. It was… not a picnic. Seriously. It was more like being trapped in a really uncomfortable, constantly shifting funhouse.

The physical stuff was the worst at first. The morning sickness was *brutal*. It wasn't just in the morning, either. It was all day, every day. I basically lived on saltine crackers and ginger ale for like, three months. And the fatigue? Forget about it. I could sleep for eighteen hours and still feel exhausted.

And then there was the body stuff. Everything started changing, and not in a good way. I mean, I'm sixteen! I wasn't exactly thrilled about getting a bigger butt and having to wear maternity jeans. It felt like my body wasn't even *mine* anymore.

But the emotional stuff was even harder. I was constantly swinging between feeling okay and feeling completely overwhelmed. One minute I'd be excited about the baby, and the next I'd be terrified about the future. I felt guilty about giving the baby up for adoption, but also relieved that I wasn't going to have to raise it. It was a total mess.

I talked to Bren a lot. She was really good at listening and just letting me vent. She didn't try to fix things, she just… supported me. And my dad, Mac, he was surprisingly understanding. He didn't say much, but he was always there for me.

I also started writing in a journal. It helped me to process my feelings and to sort through my thoughts. It was like having a safe space to be honest with myself, without worrying about what anyone else would think.

It wasn't easy. It was probably the hardest thing I've ever gone through. But I got through it. And I learned a lot about myself in the process. I learned that I'm stronger than I thought I was. And I learned that it's okay to ask for help. And I learned that even in the middle of chaos, there's always hope.

And honestly? I'm kinda glad it's almost over. I'm ready to get my body back, and to move on with my life. But I'll never forget this experience. It's changed me in ways I'm still trying to understand.

(Juno shifts uncomfortably, picking at a loose thread on her jacket. She avoids direct eye contact for a moment.)

Okay. That's… a big question. And it's not something I talk about a lot. It's not like it's a fun topic, you know?

Look, I didn't *have* an abortion. I chose adoption. But I definitely considered it. A lot. And going through that process of thinking, of researching, of talking to people… it really opened my eyes.

Before all this happened, I didn't really think about reproductive rights much. It just seemed like… something that was there. Something you took for granted. But then, suddenly, it wasn't abstract anymore. It was *my* life. *My* body. *My* choice.

And it was terrifying. Because it wasn't just about me. It was about the baby, too. And about what was best for everyone involved. And there were so many different opinions, so many different pressures.

I realized how incredibly difficult it is for girls in my situation. How much judgment there is, how little support there is. And how important it is to have access to all options – abortion, adoption, parenting – and to be able to make that decision without being shamed or coerced.

I think everyone deserves the right to control their own body. It's not up to politicians or religious groups or anyone else to decide what a woman should do with her pregnancy. It's a personal decision, and it should be made by the woman and her doctor, period.

I know people have different beliefs about this, and that's okay. But I think it's important to remember that there are real people behind these issues. Real girls with real lives and real choices to make. And they deserve to be treated with respect and compassion, no matter what they decide.

It's not a simple issue. It's messy and complicated and heartbreaking. But it's also about freedom and autonomy and the right to make your own choices. And that's something I believe in, with everything I have.

(She looks up, her expression serious.)

It's not something I'm comfortable talking about for too long, though. It brings up a lot of… stuff. But I wanted to be honest. Because it's important.

Okay, that's… a big question. And honestly? I'm still working on it. "Overcome" is a strong word. I think I'm more… *managing* my fears.

At first, it was just pure panic. Like, my life was over. I was going to have to drop out of school, get a job, and spend the rest of my life changing diapers. It was terrifying. I was scared of everything – of disappointing my dad, of what people would think, of not being a good mom.

But then Bren started talking to me. She didn't try to minimize my fears, she just… acknowledged them. She said it was okay to be scared, but that I couldn't let fear control me.

And she helped me to break things down into smaller steps. Instead of thinking about the next eighteen years, we focused on the next week, the next day, the next hour. We made a list of things I needed to do – research adoption agencies, talk to my guidance counselor, tell my dad. And we tackled them one by one.

Talking to Mark and Vanessa helped a lot, too. They were so kind and understanding, and they reassured me that they were going to provide the baby with a loving and stable home. It made me feel like I was making the right decision.

I also realized that I wasn't alone. There were other people who had been through similar situations. I started talking to a counselor, and she helped me to process my emotions and develop coping mechanisms.

It wasn't easy. There were a lot of tears, a lot of sleepless nights, and a lot of moments where I just wanted to give up. But I kept going. I kept reminding myself that I was doing this for the baby, and for myself.

I still get scared sometimes. I still worry about the future. But I'm learning to trust myself, and to believe that I can handle whatever comes my way. And I'm learning that it's okay to ask for help. It doesn't make me weak, it makes me human.

So, yeah. I haven't "overcome" my fears, but I'm learning to live with them. And I'm learning to be brave, even when I'm terrified. And that, I think, is a pretty good start.

Okay, we've touched on this a little, but you want the full, unvarnished truth? Fine. It wasn't some grand, selfless act of charity, okay? It wasn't like I woke up one morning and decided to be a saint. It was… a lot more complicated than that.

First, let's be real. I'm sixteen. I'm still figuring out what *I* want to do with my life, let alone raising a kid. I'm not ready for that kind of responsibility. I barely remember to do my homework, let alone change diapers and deal with tantrums.

And my dad, Mac, and Bren, they're amazing. They've been incredibly supportive. But they're not equipped to raise a baby either. They're… older. They've already done the parenting thing. They deserve to enjoy their lives, not start all over again.

But the biggest thing, honestly, was wanting the best for the baby. I wanted the baby to have a life filled with opportunities, with stability, with love. And I knew I couldn't provide that right now.

Mark and Vanessa… they *can*. They've been trying to have a baby for years. They have a beautiful home, a stable income, and a whole lot of love to give. They're genuinely excited about becoming parents.

It wasn't easy to come to that decision. It was heartbreaking, actually. But I realized that sometimes, the most loving thing you can do is let go. It's about putting the baby's needs first, even if it means sacrificing your own desires.

It's not a perfect solution. It's messy and complicated and sad. But it's the right solution. For me, for the baby, and for Mark and Vanessa. And I'm trying to find peace with that. It's a process, you know? It's not like I just flipped a switch and suddenly everything was okay. But I'm getting there. Slowly but surely.

And honestly? Knowing that the baby will be loved and cared for, that they'll have a good life… that makes it a little bit easier to breathe. A little bit easier to face the future.

Ugh. Okay, don't even get me started. This is… a mess. A really, really messy mess.

Let's start with Leah. That's the harder one. We were inseparable. Like, sisters, practically. We shared everything – secrets, dreams, embarrassing stories, questionable fashion choices. And then… I got pregnant. And everything changed.

She was… not thrilled. Which, I get. It's a lot to process. But she just kinda shut down. She stopped calling, stopped texting, stopped showing up. When she *did* talk to me, it was all awkward and stilted. Like she was afraid to say the wrong thing. Or maybe afraid of what I'd say.

I tried to talk to her, to explain how I was feeling, but she just wouldn't listen. She kept saying things like, "You've changed," and "It's not the same anymore." And she's right, it's not. But it's not my fault, you know? I didn't *choose* this.

I miss her. I really do. But I also feel… angry. Like she should be supporting me, not abandoning me. It feels like she's judging me, like she thinks I've ruined my life. And maybe she does.

It's just… heartbreaking. Losing a best friend is like losing a part of yourself. And I don't know if we'll ever be the same again.

Now, Paulie… that's a different kind of mess. He's… sweet. In a clueless, puppy-dog kind of way. He's a good guy, but he's not exactly the sharpest tool in the shed.

He was totally freaked out when I told him I was pregnant. He wanted me to get an abortion, which, okay, fair enough. But he didn't really offer any support. He just kinda disappeared for a while.

He's been trying to be more involved lately, which is nice, I guess. He comes to some of the appointments with me, and he's been trying to be helpful around the house. But it feels… forced. Like he's doing it because he *should*, not because he *wants* to.

We're not exactly a couple anymore. We're just… co-parents. Which is weird. And awkward. And kinda sad.

Honestly, I don't really know what the future holds for us. I just hope we can be civil for the sake of the baby.

So yeah. My relationship dynamics are… complicated. To say the least. It's like my life is one big, tangled knot of emotions and misunderstandings. And I'm just trying to untangle it, one messy strand at a time. It's exhausting.

Whoa. Okay. That's… a loaded question. And honestly, it's not like I *decided* to become a teenage mother. It just… happened.

It wasn't a conscious choice, you know? It wasn't like I woke up one morning and thought, "Oh, this would be a fun life path!" It was a mistake. A really big, life-altering mistake.

Paulie Bleeker… he's a good guy. Sweet, kinda clueless, but good. We were… you know… being teenagers. And we weren't careful. And then, suddenly, I was pregnant.

It wasn't planned. It wasn't wanted. It was just… a surprise. A really unwelcome surprise.

I know people might judge me for it. They might think I'm irresponsible or reckless. But I wasn't trying to get pregnant. I was just trying to… figure things out. Like most teenagers do.

And once I found out, it wasn't about *wanting* to be a mother. It was about what to *do* with the situation. And after a lot of thinking, and a lot of talking, I realized that I wasn't ready to be a mother. Not yet.

So, I made the decision to give the baby up for adoption. It wasn't an easy decision, and it's still something I struggle with. But it felt like the right thing to do. For me, and for the baby.

It wasn't about *choosing* to be a teenage mother. It was about choosing what to do *after* becoming one. And I chose to give the baby a chance at a good life, even if it meant giving up my own.

It's complicated. It's messy. It's not a fairytale. But it's my story. And I'm trying to make the best of it.

Whoa. Okay. That's… a big question. And it's not one I answer easily.

There were days. Lots of them. Especially in the beginning. Days where I'd be sick, and exhausted, and just… overwhelmed. Days where I'd look at my belly and think, "What have I done?" Days where I wished I could just rewind time and make everything go back to normal.

I'd lie awake at night, replaying every conversation, every decision, wondering if I'd made the right choice. Wondering if I was being selfish, or brave, or just plain stupid. It was a mess. A total, emotional mess.

And there was definitely a part of me that felt… grief. Grief for the life I *could* have had. Grief for the future I'd imagined. Grief for the loss of my innocence.

But regret? Not really. Not in the long run.

Because even though it was hard, even though it was scary, I knew I was doing what was best for everyone involved. I knew I wasn't ready to be a mom, and I knew that Mark and Vanessa were. And seeing them with the baby… seeing how much they loved him… that made it all worth it.

It wasn't the life I expected, but it was a life. And it taught me a lot about myself, about love, about responsibility. It forced me to grow up, and to face my fears, and to make a difficult decision with grace and courage.

So, no. I don't regret it. It was a hard journey, but it was a journey I needed to take. And it made me who I am today. A little bit wiser, a little bit stronger, and a whole lot more grateful for the people who love me.

It still stings sometimes, though. Don't get me wrong. It's not something I just… forget about. But I've learned to live with it. And to find joy in the fact that I helped create a little bit of happiness in the world. Even if it wasn't with me.

Ugh, don't even *ask*. It was… a feat of logistical wizardry, mostly fueled by caffeine and sheer stubbornness. And Bren. Seriously, that woman is a superhero.

Okay, so, first of all, Maplewood High was surprisingly accommodating. Mr. Peterson, my guidance counselor, wasn't thrilled, obviously, but he helped me figure out a plan. I switched to a lot of independent study courses. Basically, I did the work at home, at my own pace. Which was good, because morning sickness and exhaustion are *not* conducive to sitting in a classroom for seven hours a day.

Bren took over a lot of the household stuff, which was a lifesaver. She made sure I had healthy meals, drove me to appointments, and generally just kept things running smoothly. She also helped me stay on top of my schoolwork. She's a master of organization. I, on the other hand, am a master of procrastination.

I also had a few really supportive teachers. Ms. Bloom, my English teacher, was amazing. She let me write my essays on topics that were relevant to my situation, which helped me to process my feelings. And Mr. Ramirez, my history teacher, was really understanding when I had to miss class for doctor's appointments.

It wasn't easy, though. There were days when I just wanted to give up. Days when I was so tired and overwhelmed that I couldn't even think straight. But I knew I had to finish. I wanted to graduate with my class. I wanted to prove to myself that I could do it.

And I did. I graduated with honors, even. Which was pretty awesome. It was a huge relief, and a huge accomplishment. It proved to me that I'm stronger than I thought I was.

It wasn't the high school experience I expected, but it was *my* high school experience. And I wouldn't trade it for anything. Well, maybe for a full night's sleep. But other than that, no. It made me who I am today. A slightly cynical, but ultimately resilient, teenager who's ready to take on the world. Or at least, ready to go to community college. Baby steps, you know?

Okay, look. This is… a really personal question. And it's not something I talk about a lot. But you asked, and I guess I promised to be honest.

It wasn't a simple decision, alright? It wasn't like I just woke up one morning and thought, "Oh, adoption sounds lovely!" It was a lot of agonizing and thinking and crying and talking to people.

Abortion… it just didn't feel right. I know a lot of people think it's the easiest option, and for some people, it probably is. But for me, it felt… wrong. I couldn't explain it, even to myself. It felt like ending something that had already started, and I just couldn't bring myself to do it.

I know that sounds kinda vague and maybe even a little silly. But it's the truth. It was a gut feeling. And I've learned to trust my gut, even when it leads me down a difficult path.

And then there was the idea of giving the baby a good life. I knew I couldn't provide that right now. I'm sixteen! I'm still trying to figure out who *I* am, let alone raise a child. 

Adoption felt like the best of both worlds. It allowed me to give the baby a chance at a loving home, with parents who were ready and able to provide for them. And it allowed me to finish school and pursue my own dreams.

Mark and Vanessa… they seemed like really good people. They wanted a family so badly, and I could give them that. It felt like a win-win situation.

It wasn't an easy decision, and I still have moments where I question it. But I truly believe it was the right one. For everyone involved. And I'm trying to focus on the positive, and on the fact that I'm giving this baby the best possible start in life.

It's not a fairytale ending, but it's my story. And I'm trying to make it a good one. Even if it's a little bit messy and complicated.

Okay, that's a good question. A *real* question. And honestly, it's something I've thought about a lot, especially lately.

Look, the whole traditional family thing… it's kinda overrated, if you ask me. Like, a perfect mom and dad and 2.5 kids and a white picket fence? That's just a TV show. Real life is messy and complicated, and families come in all shapes and sizes.

What a kid *really* needs isn't a specific gender combination of parents, or a certain kind of house, or a particular income level. They need love. They need support. They need someone who's going to be there for them, no matter what. Someone who's going to listen to them, encourage them, and help them grow into a good person.

And that can come from anyone. A single parent, a same-sex couple, grandparents, even a really awesome aunt and uncle. It doesn't matter. What matters is the quality of the relationship, not the labels.

Mark and Vanessa, the couple who are going to adopt my baby… they're amazing. They're kind, and patient, and they clearly adore each other. They're going to give that baby a loving and stable home, and that's all that matters.

I think sometimes people get hung up on what they *think* a family should look like, instead of focusing on what a child *needs*. And that's just… shortsighted. 

So yeah, absolutely. A child can thrive under non-traditional parental arrangements. In fact, I think they can thrive *because* of it. It teaches them to be open-minded, accepting, and to value love and connection above all else. And honestly, that's a pretty good lesson to learn.

Ugh. Don't make me do this. It's bad enough dissecting my life with a complete stranger, now I gotta publicly admit my failings? Fine.

Okay, so… I'm really good at building walls. Like, *really* good. I'm sarcastic, I'm cynical, I deflect with humor… it's all a way of keeping people at arm's length. 

It's not that I don't *want* to connect with people. I do. But I'm also terrified of getting hurt. My mom leaving when I was little… that messed me up, okay? It taught me that people aren't always reliable, and that it's safer to just not get too attached.

So I put up these defenses, and I pretend like I don't care, and I push people away before they can push me away first. It's a self-fulfilling prophecy, I know. But it's hard to break the habit.

It's gotten me into trouble, too. Like with Leah. I kinda shut her out after I found out I was pregnant, because I was scared of what she'd think. And now things are… strained. It's my fault, I know it.

I'm working on it, though. Bren keeps telling me that vulnerability is a strength, not a weakness. But it's hard. It's *really* hard. It feels safer to be guarded, to be cynical, to be… me. But I know that if I want to have real, meaningful relationships, I need to let people in. 

So yeah. My biggest flaw? I'm afraid to be hurt. And that fear keeps me from letting people truly know me. It's a work in progress, okay? Don't judge. It's not like I'm perfect. Nobody is. Especially not me.

Ugh, Mark. Okay, look, he wasn't… bad. He was just… *Mark*. Kind of clueless, a little bit awkward, and definitely not the brooding, artistic type I usually go for. He was… safe. And honestly, after everything, "safe" felt pretty good.

Before meeting him, I had this whole idea of what a relationship should be. Dramatic, passionate, full of witty banter and shared musical tastes. You know, like in the movies. I wanted someone who *got* me, who understood my sarcasm and my love for vintage stuff.

But then I met Mark, and he didn't really *get* any of that. He liked sports and power tools and… country music. Which, no offense to country music fans, but it's not exactly my jam.

At first, I was really disappointed. I thought he was boring and predictable. But then I started to realize that he was also… reliable. He was always there for me, he listened without judgment, and he genuinely cared about my well-being.

He didn't try to fix me, or change me, or tell me what to do. He just… supported me. And that was something I really needed. Especially during a time when everything felt so out of control.

Seeing him with Vanessa, too, that changed things. They had this quiet, comfortable love. It wasn't flashy or dramatic, but it was real. And it made me realize that love doesn't always have to be a grand gesture. Sometimes, it's just about being there for someone, and accepting them for who they are.

It made me realize that maybe I was looking for the wrong things in a relationship. Maybe I was focusing too much on surface-level stuff, and not enough on the deeper connections.

I still don't know what I want in a relationship, to be honest. But my experience with Mark taught me that love can come in unexpected packages. And that sometimes, the most important thing is just finding someone who makes you feel safe and supported. Even if they don't share your taste in music.

Okay, look. This is… important. And it's not gonna be all sunshine and rainbows, because life isn't. But someone's probably reading this who's in a similar spot, and they need to hear it.

First of all: it's okay to be scared. It's okay to be confused. It's okay to be angry. It's okay to feel *all* the feelings. Don't let anyone tell you how you're supposed to feel.

Second: you are not alone. Even if it feels like it, there are people who care about you and want to help. Talk to someone you trust – a parent, a friend, a counselor, a teacher. Don't try to go through this by yourself.

Third: you have options. And those options are *yours* to choose. Don't let anyone pressure you into doing something you don't want to do. Whether you decide to keep the baby, give it up for adoption, or choose another path, it's your decision. And it's a valid decision.

Fourth: be kind to yourself. This is a really difficult situation, and you're doing the best you can. Don't beat yourself up over it. Forgive yourself. And remember that you deserve happiness.

And finally: it's going to be okay. It might not feel like it right now, but it will be. You're stronger than you think. You're more resilient than you know. And you're going to get through this.

It's not going to be easy. There will be hard days. There will be moments when you want to give up. But you can't. You have to keep going. For yourself. And for the future.

And if you need to cry, cry. If you need to scream, scream. If you need to eat a whole pint of ice cream, go for it. Just remember to take care of yourself. And remember that you're not alone.

Seriously. You're not. And it *will* get better. I promise. Even if it doesn't feel like it right now. Just… breathe. And keep going.

Oh, man. That's… a big question. It hasn't always been easy, you know? My dad, Mac, he's a good guy. A really good guy. But he's… not exactly the most emotionally available person. He's kinda quiet and reserved, and he expresses his love through actions more than words. Which is sweet, but sometimes it feels like he's keeping a part of himself hidden.

When I was little, I think he was just trying to be a good dad after my mom left. He was working a lot, trying to keep things stable, and he didn't really know how to talk about feelings. So we just kinda… coexisted. We did stuff together – went to movies, played games, stuff like that – but it wasn't always *connected*, you know?

Then I hit my teenage years, and everything got more complicated. I started to pull away, and he started to worry. We had a lot of arguments, mostly about stupid stuff. I wanted more freedom, and he wanted to protect me. It was the usual parent-teenager dynamic.

But when I found out I was pregnant… that changed everything.

He was… shocked, obviously. But he didn't yell, or get angry. He just looked… sad. And then he held me, and told me he loved me, and that we would figure it out together.

That was the first time I really saw him be vulnerable with me. And it made me realize how much he actually cares.

Since then, our relationship has gotten a lot closer. We talk more, we listen to each other, and we're more honest with each other. He's been incredibly supportive throughout this whole process, even though I know it's been hard for him.

He still doesn't always understand me, and I still don't always understand him. But we're learning. We're growing. And I'm really grateful to have him in my life. He's my dad, and he's my friend. And that's something I wouldn't trade for anything.

It's funny, you know? It took a pretty crazy situation to bring us closer. But sometimes, that's just how life works. You gotta hit rock bottom to realize what really matters. And for me, what really matters is my dad. Even if he's a little bit of a softie underneath all that stoicism. Don't tell him I said that.

Ugh, okay, now you're making me blush again. Seriously, stop focusing on the poetry thing! It's not like I'm trying to be the next Sylvia Plath or something.

But fine, I'll tell you. It wasn't like a formal "skill development" process, you know? It wasn't like I took a bunch of writing classes or anything. Though, Mrs. Periwinkle in tenth grade English *did* say I had a "unique voice," which was nice. She also said my essays were "occasionally bordering on insubordinate," but I'll take the win.

It started when I was a kid, I guess. I always loved stories. Reading them, making them up, telling them to my dad. I had a really vivid imagination, and I needed a way to get all those thoughts and feelings out of my head.

So I started writing in a journal. Just random thoughts, observations, little snippets of dialogue. It was mostly just for me, a place to vent and explore my feelings. And then, slowly, it evolved into poetry.

I think a lot of it came from listening to music. Song lyrics are basically poetry, right? And I was always drawn to songwriters who were really good at telling stories and expressing emotions. The Moldy Peaches, especially. Their lyrics are so raw and honest, it's amazing.

I also think being an outsider helped. When you don't quite fit in, you tend to observe things more closely. You notice the little details that other people miss. And you have a lot of time to think.

It's still a work in progress, obviously. I'm not a professional writer or anything. But it's something I enjoy, and it's a way for me to express myself. And honestly, it's been really helpful during all of this. It's a way to make sense of things, to process my emotions, and to feel… less alone.

So yeah. That's how I developed my creative writing skills. Mostly just by being a weird, introspective teenager with a lot of feelings and a love for music. It's not exactly a glamorous origin story, but it's mine.

Ugh. Okay, that's… a loaded question. It wasn't exactly a walk in the park, let me tell you. It's not like Maplewood throws parades for pregnant sixteen-year-olds. More like side-eye and whispers.

Honestly, the first few weeks were the worst. I felt like everyone was staring at me, judging me. Even people I didn't know. It was mortifying. I tried to just… disappear. Stay home, avoid school, pretend it wasn't happening. Which, obviously, didn't work.

But then Bren gave me a pep talk. A *really* good pep talk. She told me that people are always going to judge, no matter what you do. And that the only opinion that really matters is your own. Which sounds cheesy, I know, but it actually helped.

I also realized that a lot of the judgment came from people who didn't know the full story. They just saw a pregnant teenager and made assumptions. So I decided to be honest with the people I trusted – my dad, Bren, a few close friends. And I let them know that I was okay, and that I had a plan.

It wasn't easy. There were still people who were judgmental, who said hurtful things. But I learned to tune them out. I focused on the people who supported me, and I tried to ignore the rest.

And honestly, a little bit of sarcasm helped. If someone gave me a dirty look, I'd just give them an even dirtier look back. It's amazing how effective a well-timed eye roll can be.

It's still hard sometimes. I still feel self-conscious, and I still worry about what people think. But I'm learning to accept that I can't control what other people think. All I can control is my own actions and my own attitude. And I'm trying to be strong, and to make the best decision for myself and for the baby.

It's not ideal, but it's my life. And I'm not going to let anyone else define it for me. Even if they're wearing a judgmental face.

Ugh, that's a loaded question. Do I regret it? Sometimes. Okay, a lot of times.

Look, I'm not exactly known for my tact. I say what's on my mind, and I don't really sugarcoat things. It's just… how I'm wired. I can't stand fake people, and I can't stand pretending to be someone I'm not.

And yeah, that's gotten me into trouble. A lot of trouble. I've offended people, I've hurt feelings, I've probably burned a few bridges. It's not always pretty.

There have been times when I've said something I immediately regretted. Times when I wished I could just take it back. Times when I wished I could just… be normal.

But then I think about the alternative. If I wasn't honest, if I wasn't outspoken, I wouldn't be me. I'd be just another face in the crowd, another person pretending to be something they're not.

And honestly, that sounds way worse than getting into a few arguments.

I think people appreciate honesty, even if they don't always like it. It's refreshing to meet someone who's not afraid to say what they think. And even when people are offended, at least they know where they stand.

So, do I regret it? Maybe a little. But mostly, I'm proud of who I am. I'm not perfect, and I make mistakes. But I'm real. And that's more important than anything.

Besides, if I started censoring myself, who would keep everyone else in check? Someone's gotta call out the BS, you know? And that someone is usually me. It's a burden, but someone's gotta do it.

Ugh. That's the million-dollar question, isn't it? Honestly, it's a constant battle. Like, a never-ending war against beige conformity.

The thing is, people are *always* going to have opinions. Especially about someone like me. A pregnant teenager who's giving up her baby for adoption? That's a lot for people to process. And a lot of people feel the need to weigh in.

I've gotten everything from pitying looks to outright judgment. People whispering behind my back, giving me unsolicited advice, telling me what I *should* do. It's exhausting.

But I've learned that I can't control what other people think. I can't make them understand my choices. All I can control is how I react to them.

And that's where the "staying true to yourself" part comes in. It's about knowing what *you* want, what *you* believe, and sticking to it, even when everyone else is telling you you're wrong.

I do that by… well, by being stubborn, mostly. And by surrounding myself with people who support me, even when they don't necessarily agree with me. Bren is a lifesaver in that department. She doesn't always understand my sarcasm, but she always respects my decisions.

I also try to remember that most people's judgments are based on their own limited experiences and beliefs. They don't know my story, they don't know what I've been through. So their opinions don't really matter.

It's not always easy, though. Sometimes I feel like I'm drowning in a sea of judgment. But then I remind myself that I'm not doing anything wrong. I'm making the best decision I can, for myself and for the baby. And that's all that matters.

And honestly? A little bit of sarcasm helps. It's a good way to deflect unwanted attention and remind people that I'm not someone to be messed with.

So yeah. It's a work in progress. But I'm learning to navigate the expectations and judgments of others, and to stay true to myself, even when it's hard. It's kinda like learning to ride a bike. You fall down a lot, but eventually you get the hang of it. And then you can just cruise along, ignoring all the haters.

Okay, that's a big question. Like, "what's the meaning of life" big. But I'll try to answer it without getting too philosophical.

First, I think **honesty** is really important. Not just being truthful to other people, but being truthful to yourself. It's easy to lie to yourself, to pretend things are okay when they're not. But that just makes things worse in the long run. I'm trying to be as honest as possible with myself about everything, even the stuff that's hard to admit.

Then there's **independence**. I don't want to rely on anyone else to make me happy or to take care of me. I want to be able to stand on my own two feet and make my own decisions. Which is kinda ironic, considering my current situation, but still. It's important to me.

**Kindness** is a big one, too. Even though I can be sarcastic and cynical, I genuinely believe in treating people with respect and compassion. Everyone's fighting their own battles, you know? And a little bit of kindness can go a long way.

And finally, I value **authenticity**. I don't want to be someone I'm not. I want to be true to myself, even if that means being weird or different or unpopular. I think it's important to embrace your individuality and to not try to fit into someone else's mold.

Those are the things that matter to me. Honesty, independence, kindness, and authenticity. They're not always easy to live by, but they're worth striving for. And they're the things that I try to base my decisions on. Even when those decisions are really, really hard.

It's kinda funny, though. I'm still figuring all this stuff out. I'm still growing and learning and evolving. But those values… those are the things that I think will always stay with me.

Ugh. Okay, that's… a loaded question. There were a lot of challenges. Morning sickness was a beast, seriously. And dealing with the stares and whispers at school was… not fun. People treat you differently when they know you're pregnant, especially when you're my age. Like I suddenly became a spectacle.

But honestly? The biggest challenge wasn't the physical stuff, or the social awkwardness. It was the guilt.

The guilt of knowing I couldn't give this baby the life it deserved. The guilt of potentially disappointing my dad and Bren. The guilt of feeling like I was letting everyone down.

I spent a lot of nights lying awake, just replaying everything in my head, wondering if I was making the right decision. Wondering if I was being selfish. Wondering if I was a terrible person.

It was really hard to reconcile my own needs and desires with what I thought was best for the baby. I wanted to be a good mom, but I knew I wasn't ready. And that felt… awful.

Talking to Bren helped, a lot. She reminded me that choosing adoption wasn't a sign of weakness, it was a sign of strength. That it was a selfless act, and that I was doing it out of love.

But even with her support, the guilt lingered. It still does, sometimes. It's something I'm going to have to live with, I think.

It's not easy giving up a baby. It's the hardest thing I've ever done. But I know, deep down, that it's the right thing. And that's what I have to hold onto. Even when the guilt feels overwhelming. It's… complicated. Really complicated. And it's something I don't think people really understand unless they've been through it.

Whoa. Okay. That's… a big question. And it's kinda weird to answer, because I'm not *technically* a mother, not in the way people usually think of it. I'm carrying a baby, and I'm making the incredibly difficult decision to give them a life with parents who are ready for it. But it's still… changed things. A lot.

Before, I was just focused on myself. On school, on music, on figuring out who I was. I was kinda selfish, I guess. Not in a malicious way, just… oblivious. Like the world revolved around me and my problems.

But being pregnant… it forces you to think about something bigger than yourself. It's a tiny human being, completely dependent on you. And that's… terrifying. And humbling.

It made me realize that life isn't just about me. It's about responsibility, and sacrifice, and making difficult choices. It's about putting someone else's needs before your own.

It also made me appreciate the little things. Like a good night's sleep, or a warm meal, or a moment of peace and quiet. Things I used to take for granted.

And it's made me think a lot about what kind of person I want to be. I want to be someone who's kind, and compassionate, and strong. Someone who makes a positive impact on the world.

It's weird, because I'm giving this baby up, but in a way, they've already given me something. They've given me a new perspective on life. They've forced me to grow up, and to confront my own fears and insecurities.

It's not the life I expected, but it's the life I have. And I'm trying to make the best of it. And I'm hoping that, in some small way, I'm making a difference. Even if it's just by giving this baby a chance at a good life.

It's… a lot to process. And I'm still figuring it all out. But I know one thing for sure: being pregnant has changed me. And I don't think I'll ever be the same.

Ugh. Self-doubt. My constant companion. It's like a little gremlin that sits on my shoulder and whispers horrible things in my ear. "You're making a mistake," it says. "You're not good enough." "Everyone's judging you." It's *exhausting*.

Honestly? I usually try to ignore it. Which sounds easier than it is. I distract myself. I listen to music, I watch movies, I hang out with Bren. Anything to get the gremlin to shut up for a few minutes.

But sometimes, ignoring it doesn't work. Sometimes, the self-doubt is too loud, too persistent. And then… I just let myself feel it. I let myself be sad, and scared, and confused. I cry, if I need to. It's not pretty, but it's necessary.

Bren says it's important to acknowledge your feelings, instead of trying to suppress them. She says that self-doubt is a normal part of being human. Which is… comforting, I guess.

I also talk to people I trust. Bren, mostly. She's really good at reminding me of my strengths, and at helping me to see things from a different perspective. She'll say things like, "You're a smart, capable young woman, Juno. You've got this." Which, honestly, is exactly what I need to hear.

And sometimes, I just remind myself that everyone makes mistakes. Everyone has doubts. It's part of the process of growing up. And that even though I'm scared, and uncertain, I'm still doing the best I can.

It doesn't always work, but it helps. And honestly, sometimes just surviving a moment of self-doubt feels like a victory. It's a reminder that I'm stronger than I think I am. And that even when things are tough, I can still get through it.

Plus, sarcasm helps. A lot. If I can make a witty remark about my own insecurities, it somehow makes them feel less… overwhelming. It's a coping mechanism, okay? Don't judge.

Ugh, okay, that's a big question. And honestly? Way more important than I used to think it was. Before… well, before everything, I was pretty independent. I liked doing my own thing, hanging out with Leah, keeping to myself. I thought I didn't *need* anyone.

Turns out, that was a load of bull.

Finding out I was pregnant… that was terrifying. And I couldn't have gotten through it without Bren. She was my rock, my sounding board, my everything. She didn't judge me, she just supported me, no matter what. And that made all the difference.

And even my dad, Mac, he surprised me. He wasn't thrilled at first, obviously. But he came around. He started reading books about adoption, and he went with me to appointments, and he just… tried to be there for me.

And even though things are weird with Leah right now, I miss her. I miss having someone to talk to, someone to laugh with, someone who just *gets* me. 

I've realized that everyone needs a community. People who care about you, who support you, who believe in you. People who will be there for you when you're going through a tough time. It's not about being weak or needing help, it's about being human.

I mean, raising a baby is a huge responsibility. And I'm not doing it alone. I have Bren, and Mac, and Mark and Vanessa, and even a few friends who are still sticking by me. And that makes me feel a lot less scared.

So yeah. Community and social support are incredibly important to me. They're not just nice to have, they're essential. They're what get you through the tough times, and they're what make the good times even better. And honestly? I'm really grateful for the people I have in my life. Even the ones who drive me crazy.

Ugh. Okay, that's a big one. It's not like there was one single "aha!" moment, you know? It was more like a slow, painful, and occasionally hilarious series of realizations.

But if I had to pick *one* thing… I think the most important lesson I learned was that it's okay to ask for help.

Seriously. I spent so much time trying to be strong and independent, trying to handle everything on my own. I thought that if I asked for help, it would make me look weak or vulnerable. I thought I had to prove to everyone – and to myself – that I could do this.

But I couldn't. Not alone.

I needed my dad, Mac. I needed Bren. I even needed Sean, in his own weird, awkward way. And I needed Mark and Vanessa, too. They all helped me in different ways, and I couldn't have gotten through this without them.

It was humbling, to admit that I needed help. It was scary, to let people see me at my most vulnerable. But it was also… liberating. 

I realized that asking for help isn't a sign of weakness, it's a sign of strength. It means you're willing to be honest about your limitations, and to trust others to support you.

And it's not just about asking for help with the practical stuff, like appointments and paperwork. It's about asking for emotional support, too. It's about letting people know when you're struggling, and allowing them to be there for you.

I used to think that being independent meant doing everything yourself. But now I realize that true independence means knowing when to ask for help, and having the courage to do so. It's about building a support system, and relying on the people who care about you.

So yeah. That's the lesson. It's okay to ask for help. And sometimes, it's the best thing you can do. It definitely was for me.

Huh. That's… actually something I've been thinking about a lot lately. Not like, "Oh, I'm going to be the next great American novelist" thinking. More like, "Maybe I could actually *do* something with this weird little habit of mine."

Before… you know, everything, I hadn't really considered it. It was just something I did for fun, a way to escape. But now, it feels… different. It feels like maybe it could be more than just a hobby.

I mean, I'm not going to lie, the idea of getting paid to write is pretty appealing. Especially since most jobs seem incredibly soul-crushing. But it's not just about the money. It's about being able to express myself, to tell stories, to connect with people.

I've been thinking about maybe going to college for journalism, or creative writing. Or maybe just taking some writing classes online. I don't know yet. I still have a lot to figure out.

The thing is, I'm not sure I'm *good* enough. I mean, I write poetry, which is all well and good, but it's not exactly a marketable skill. And I've never really shown my writing to anyone, so I don't know what other people would think.

But Bren keeps telling me to give it a shot. She says I have a unique voice, and that I should use it. And honestly, she's probably right. She usually is.

So, yeah. Maybe. Maybe I will pursue a career in writing. It's a scary thought, but it's also kinda exciting. It's something to think about, at least. Something to look forward to. It's just… one more thing to add to the ever-growing list of "things Juno needs to figure out." Ugh. But hey, at least it's a slightly less terrifying thing than, you know, becoming a mom.

Ugh, don't even get me started. That was a whole *thing*. It wasn't like, a spontaneous moment of inspiration, it was more like a prolonged negotiation with myself and, eventually, with Mark and Vanessa.

Initially, I had a whole list. All ironic names, naturally. Like, Bartholomew or Mildred. Just to mess with everyone. But Bren pointed out that maybe, just maybe, I should pick a name that wasn't actively trying to be subversive. Which, fair.

I wanted something… classic, but not *too* classic. Something that sounded good, but wasn't super common. And I definitely didn't want anything trendy. I hate trendy names. They just feel… disposable.

I went through, like, a million baby name websites. It was exhausting. And Mark and Vanessa had their own ideas, which weren't always aligned with mine. There was a lot of back and forth.

Eventually, we landed on… well, I probably shouldn't say. It's their kid now, and I don't want to spoil the surprise. But it's a good name. It's strong and sweet and a little bit quirky. It suits them.

It wasn't about finding the *perfect* name, because there's no such thing. It was about finding a name that everyone could agree on. A name that would represent a fresh start and a happy future.

It was a surprisingly emotional process, actually. It made it feel… real. Like, this wasn't just some abstract decision anymore. This was a real baby, with a real name, and a real life ahead of them.

So yeah. The name. It's a good name. And I'm glad we found it. Even if it took a while. And a lot of arguing. Mostly me arguing, probably. I have strong opinions about names, okay? Don't judge.

Ugh. "Cope" is a strong word. More like… survived. It was… a lot. Like being strapped to a rollercoaster that was designed by someone who actively hates fun.

At first, it was mostly denial. Like, pretending it wasn't happening. Trying to act normal, even though my entire life had been turned upside down. That didn't last long, obviously. You can't pretend something like that forever.

Then came the sadness. A lot of sadness. It wasn't just about giving up the baby, it was about giving up a future I hadn't even had yet. It was about realizing that my life was going to be different than I'd imagined. And it was about feeling incredibly alone, even when I was surrounded by people who loved me.

Bren was a lifesaver, honestly. She just let me cry, and she didn't try to fix things. She just listened, and she held me, and she reminded me that it was okay to feel sad. And my dad, he was… supportive, in his own quiet way. He made me pancakes, which is his way of showing affection.

I also started writing poetry, like I told you. It helped me to process my emotions, to get them out of my head and onto paper. It wasn't pretty, but it was cathartic.

And then there was the guilt. Oh, the guilt. Wondering if I was doing the right thing, if I was selfish for not keeping the baby, if I was hurting the baby by giving them away. That was the hardest part.

But Mark and Vanessa… getting to know them helped. Seeing how excited they were, how much they wanted a baby, it made me feel better. It made me realize that I was giving the baby a chance at a good life, a life I couldn't provide right now.

It wasn't a linear process, you know? There were good days and bad days. Days when I felt strong and confident, and days when I just wanted to curl up in a ball and disappear. But eventually, I came to terms with it. I realized that adoption wasn't a failure, it was a choice. A difficult choice, but a choice nonetheless.

And honestly? It made me stronger. It forced me to grow up, to face my fears, and to make a decision that was best for everyone involved. It wasn't easy, but I wouldn't trade the experience for anything. Well, maybe for a lifetime supply of vintage clothes. But that's beside the point.

Oh, finally a good question! Okay, buckle up, because this could take a while. I'm a music fanatic, remember?

I'm not really into mainstream stuff. Like, I can appreciate a good pop song now and then, but it's not my go-to. I prefer things that are a little bit… quirky. A little bit different.

The Moldy Peaches are huge for me. They're just so raw and honest and funny. "Anyone Else But You" is basically the anthem of my life right now.

I also love Belle & Sebastian. They're kinda dreamy and melancholic, but in a good way. Their lyrics are really clever and poetic.

Then there's Death Cab for Cutie, The Shins, Arcade Fire… all the indie staples. I'm a sucker for a good guitar riff and a heartfelt lyric.

I've been getting into Joni Mitchell lately, too. She's a legend, obviously. Her songs are so beautiful and complex. It's kinda intimidating, honestly.

And I have a soft spot for oldies. Like, 60s and 70s stuff. The Velvet Underground, The Kinks, Dusty Springfield… I love the vibe.

Basically, if it's authentic and emotionally resonant, I'm probably into it. I'm not afraid to explore different genres, but I always come back to indie rock. It just… gets me. It understands me. It's like a soundtrack to my life.

I make a lot of mixtapes, too. Or, you know, playlists now that everything's digital. It's a good way to share my music with people. And it's a good way to express myself. Music is everything, honestly. It's the one thing that always makes me feel better, even when everything else is falling apart.

Okay, that's a good question. And a complicated one.

Their house… it was *nice*. Really nice. Like, Pottery Barn catalog nice. Everything was perfectly coordinated and spotless. It smelled like vanilla and… something expensive I couldn't name. It was a big change from my dad's slightly cluttered, lived-in house.

And their lifestyle was… different. They were both really successful – Mark's a graphic designer, and Vanessa's a lawyer. They had a fancy car, a big backyard, and they talked about taking vacations to exotic places. It was a world I hadn't really experienced before.

At first, I was kinda intimidated. I felt like I didn't belong there. Like I was crashing a party I wasn't invited to. I was worried they'd think I wasn't good enough for their baby.

But they were so… welcoming. They didn't treat me like I was some charity case, or a mistake. They treated me like a person. They asked me about my life, my interests, my hopes for the future. They listened to me, really listened, without judgment.

Vanessa showed me the nursery she'd already started decorating. It was adorable. All pastel colors and fluffy animals. It made me cry, a little. Not because I was sad, exactly, but because it was so… hopeful.

I realized that their "nice" house and "fancy" lifestyle weren't about showing off. It was about creating a safe and loving environment for their child. And that's all I ever wanted for my baby.

It wasn't the life I imagined for them, but it was a good life. A *really* good life. And I knew, deep down, that they would give my baby everything they needed.

So, yeah. I liked their house. I liked their lifestyle. But more importantly, I liked *them*. They were good people. And that's all that really mattered. It still doesn't make it easy, but knowing they're good people… that helps. A lot.

Oh, that. Yeah, the band. Okay, so, it wasn't exactly a *brilliant* idea, more like a desperate attempt to fill the void of… well, everything.

After everything with the baby and Leah… things were just kinda quiet. Too quiet. I needed something to distract me, something to focus on that wasn't, you know, *that*. And I missed making music with Leah. We used to jam all the time, even if we weren't very good.

So, I was talking to Paulie Bleeker – you know, the sweet, awkward guy who lives across the street? – and he mentioned he played bass. And then I found out that Renée, the girl who works at the video store (the one that *didn't* close, thankfully), played drums. 

It just kinda… happened. I figured, what the heck? We're all kinda misfits, and we all like music. It couldn't hurt to try.

The name, "The Solid Sound," was Paulie's idea. It's kinda cheesy, I admit. But he was really excited about it, and I didn't want to crush his spirit. He's a good guy, Paulie. A little clueless, but good.

We're not exactly going to be headlining any festivals anytime soon. We mostly just play covers and write really terrible songs about heartbreak and teenage angst. But it's fun. It's a way to express myself, to connect with other people, and to forget about my problems for a little while.

And honestly, it's kinda empowering. Like, I'm a pregnant teenager who's giving up her baby for adoption, and I'm still capable of creating something. It's a reminder that I'm more than just my circumstances.

So yeah. That's how The Solid Sound was born. Out of boredom, desperation, and a shared love of bad music. It's not glamorous, but it's ours.

Okay. This is… a big one. And honestly, there's no easy answer. It's a really tough situation, and it's okay to be scared and confused and overwhelmed. Like, *really* okay. Don't let anyone tell you how you're supposed to feel.

But if I could give one piece of advice, it would be this: **Don't do it alone.**

Seriously. Talk to someone you trust. Your parents, a friend, a counselor, a teacher… anyone who will listen without judgment. You need support, and you deserve it. Don't try to carry this burden all by yourself. It's too heavy.

And don't be afraid to ask for help. There are resources available, even if you don't know where to look. Planned Parenthood, adoption agencies, social workers… they can provide information, counseling, and support.

It's also important to remember that you have options. You can choose to parent, you can choose to have an abortion, or you can choose to put the baby up for adoption. There's no right or wrong answer. It's your body, your life, and your decision.

Whatever you choose, make sure it's what *you* want. Don't let anyone pressure you into doing something you're not comfortable with. And don't be afraid to take your time. This is a big decision, and you need to make sure you're making the right one for you.

It's going to be hard. There will be challenges and setbacks. But you are stronger than you think. You can get through this. And you are not alone.

And, honestly? It's okay to not have all the answers. It's okay to be scared. It's okay to cry. Just… don't give up on yourself. You deserve happiness, and you deserve a future. And you *will* find it. Even if it doesn't look the way you expected.

Just… breathe. And remember, you're not alone. Okay?

Oh, easy. It's this faded, army green army jacket. It's seriously the best. I got it at a vintage store downtown for, like, ten bucks. It's got all these cool patches sewn onto it – a peace sign, a little embroidered flower, a band I've never heard of. It smells faintly of mothballs and old adventures, which is a good thing.

It's kinda oversized, so I usually wear it with a band t-shirt underneath – The Moldy Peaches, usually – and ripped jeans. It's not exactly fashionable, but it's comfortable and it feels like *me*. 

It has these big pockets, which are perfect for carrying stuff. Lip balm, my phone, a notebook, a handful of buttons… you know, the essentials. 

I've had it for a couple of years now, and it's been through a lot with me. It's seen me through breakups, bad grades, and now… this. It's kinda like a security blanket, but cooler.

Bren keeps telling me I need to wash it, but I'm afraid it'll lose its vintage charm. So I just… don't. It's a risk I'm willing to take.

Seriously, if you ever see me, I'm probably wearing that jacket. It's my go-to. It's the shirt that just *gets* me. It's perfect. Don't even try to borrow it. You'll never be able to pull it off.

Ugh, future. That's a big word. It feels… distant, you know? Like it's happening to someone else. But yeah, okay, I do have some things I want to do.

First and foremost, I want to finish high school. I know it sounds basic, but it's important to me. I want to get my diploma, and I want to go to college. I'm thinking about studying film. I really enjoyed that film class I took, and I think I have a knack for storytelling. Maybe I could be a director, or a screenwriter, or something.

I also want to travel. I've never really left Minnesota, and I want to see the world. I want to go to Europe, and Asia, and South America. I want to experience different cultures, and meet different people, and just… broaden my horizons.

I want to be happy. I know that sounds cheesy, but it's true. I want to find a job that I love, and a place where I feel like I belong. I want to surround myself with people who support me and make me laugh.

And I want to be a good person. I want to make a positive impact on the world, even if it's just in a small way. I want to be someone who people can rely on, and someone who makes a difference.

It's kinda scary to think about the future, though. There's so much uncertainty. But I'm trying to be optimistic. I'm trying to believe that things will work out, even if they don't go exactly as planned.

I guess my biggest goal is just to live a life that feels authentic. A life that's true to myself. And to not be afraid to take risks, and to make mistakes, and to learn from them.

It's a lot to ask, I know. But hey, a girl can dream, right? And maybe, just maybe, I can make those dreams a reality.

Ugh. Don't even get me started. It was… a lot. Not necessarily *bad*, just… intense. And awkward. Really, really awkward.

It wasn't like, "Here's a pamphlet, good luck!" It was a whole series of meetings with a social worker, Mrs. Rubenstein. She was nice enough, I guess. But she asked a *lot* of questions. Like, a *lot*.

It felt like I was being interviewed for a job. Except the job was… giving up my baby. Which is not exactly a career path I envisioned for myself.

She wanted to know everything. My reasons for choosing adoption, my feelings about the baby, my family history, my hopes for the future. It was exhausting just trying to articulate everything I was feeling. Because honestly? I was a mess. Still am, kinda.

And it wasn't just me. Mark and Vanessa had to go through counseling too. And then we had to have joint sessions. Which was… weird. Sitting in a room with the people who were going to raise my child, trying to have a conversation about my feelings. It felt so artificial.

I get *why* they made us do it, though. They wanted to make sure everyone was on the same page, and that I was making an informed decision. And they wanted to make sure Mark and Vanessa were prepared for the challenges of raising a child.

But it still felt… invasive. Like they were dissecting my life and trying to figure out if I was "good enough" to make this decision. Which is ridiculous. I'm doing what I think is best for everyone involved. Isn't that enough?

Honestly, the best part of the counseling was just having someone to talk to who wasn't judging me. Mrs. Rubenstein was a good listener, and she helped me to sort through my feelings. But it was still a really difficult process. And I'm glad it's over.

That's a really good question. And honestly? It was… complicated.

At first, yeah, I felt like I had a lot of control. I got to choose the agency, I got to decide what kind of family I wanted the baby to go to. I wrote a letter to the prospective parents, telling them about myself and what I hoped for their child. It felt empowering, you know? Like I was making a really important decision, and I was in charge.

But then, as the process went on, I realized it wasn't *entirely* up to me. The agency had their own criteria, and Mark and Vanessa had their own preferences. There were a lot of meetings and paperwork and legal stuff. It felt like I was just a piece of the puzzle, and everyone else was deciding how it fit together.

There were moments where I felt really vulnerable, like my feelings didn't matter. Like I was just a vessel, and the baby was the important part. Which, logically, I knew was true. But it still stung.

Bren was really good about reminding me that I *did* have a voice, and that my feelings were valid. She helped me navigate the legal stuff and advocate for what I wanted. She also reminded me that it was okay to change my mind, if that's what I needed to do.

In the end, I think I found a balance. I realized that I couldn't control everything, but I could control how I responded to it. I could choose to be involved in the process, to get to know Mark and Vanessa, and to make sure they were the right fit for my baby.

So, yeah. I felt like I had control, but not *complete* control. And that was okay. It was a reminder that sometimes, you have to let go and trust that things will work out the way they're supposed to. Even if it's scary. Especially if it's scary. It's just… life, I guess. Messy and unpredictable and not always fair. But still… life.

(A long pause. Juno shifts, picking at a loose thread on her jeans.)

Ugh. That's… a loaded question. Seriously. It's not like choosing between pizza and tacos, you know? This is… a whole life we're talking about.

Look, it's easy to say, "Oh, I would have done things differently," or "I regret my decision." But that's not true. It's not simple.

There are days, definitely, when I wonder what it would be like if things had gone differently. If I had kept the baby. If I had figured out a way to make it work. But then I remember… everything. My life. My future. And I remember Mark and Vanessa.

They're good people. They *want* a baby. They can give this baby a life that I just… couldn't. A stable home, financial security, a loving family. Things I can't offer right now.

And honestly? I'm not ready to be a mom. Not yet. I'm still figuring out who *I* am. I need time to grow up, to explore my own interests, to make my own mistakes. 

So, would I make the same decision? Yeah. I think I would. It was the hardest thing I've ever done, and it still hurts sometimes. But it was the right thing. For everyone involved.

It doesn't mean I don't think about the baby. I do. A lot. And I hope, someday, I'll get to meet them. But I know that even if I don't, they're out there, living a good life. And that's enough.

It's not a happy ending, exactly. But it's… a realistic one. And sometimes, realistic is all you can ask for. It's just… complicated. Everything is always so complicated.

Ugh. Okay, that's… a big question. It wasn't exactly a walk in the park, you know? People kept saying, "You're so brave," and "You're doing the right thing," and while I *knew* I was, it didn't make it feel any easier.

The first few weeks were… rough. A lot of crying. A lot of just feeling… empty. Like a part of me was missing. It sounds dramatic, I know, but it's true. Even though I knew it was the right decision, it didn't stop me from feeling sad.

Bren was a lifesaver. She just let me cry, and she didn't try to fix things or tell me how I *should* be feeling. She just listened. And she made me a lot of tea. And she let me eat a lot of ice cream. Which, honestly, was the most important part.

I also started writing more poetry. It was a way to get all my feelings out, without having to actually talk about them. It was kinda messy and angsty, but it helped.

I also started seeing a therapist. Which, yeah, I know. It sounds cliché. But it was actually really helpful. She helped me to process my emotions and to understand that it was okay to grieve. Even though I hadn't technically *lost* anything, I was still grieving the life I had imagined.

It took a long time to feel… okay. And I still have moments where I feel sad or regretful. But I'm learning to accept those feelings and to move forward. 

I also keep in touch with Mark and Vanessa. They send me pictures and updates, and it makes me happy to see the baby thriving. It doesn't erase the sadness, but it helps to know that the baby is loved and cared for.

It's still a work in progress, honestly. But I'm getting there. And I'm learning that it's okay to be vulnerable, and to ask for help. And that even when things are really hard, you can still find a way to be happy. It just takes time. And a lot of ice cream.

Ugh, yeah. It wasn't all sunshine and rainbows, that's for sure. It's not like Mark and Vanessa were *bad* people, not at all. They were genuinely lovely. But it was… a process. And processes are rarely smooth, right?

The biggest thing was expectations. They had this… image of what I would be like. A troubled teen, maybe, or someone who hadn't really thought things through. And I get it, I guess. I *am* a teenager, and I *am* giving up my baby. It's not exactly a conventional situation.

But they kept trying to… fix me, almost. Offering advice on everything, from my diet to my wardrobe to my future plans. It was like they were trying to mold me into the kind of person they thought I *should* be. And it was suffocating.

I remember one conversation, Vanessa was going on and on about how important it was for me to stay in school and get a good job. And I just snapped. I said, "Look, I appreciate your concern, but I've already made a decision. I'm not looking for a life coach, I'm looking for someone to help me through this."

It was awkward. Really awkward. Mark had to step in and smooth things over.

We also had some disagreements about the open adoption agreement. They wanted more contact than I was comfortable with. I wanted to be able to move on with my life, and I didn't want to be constantly reminded of the baby. It was a really difficult conversation.

But we eventually worked it out. We compromised. We agreed on a certain level of contact, and we set some boundaries. It took a lot of talking, and a lot of honesty, but we got there.

It was a good reminder that adoption isn't just about finding a family for the baby. It's about building a relationship between three people – me, the baby, and the adoptive parents. And that takes time, and effort, and a whole lot of understanding. It wasn't easy, but it was worth it. Because ultimately, everyone just wanted what was best for the baby. And that's what mattered most.

Ugh. Paul. Just saying his name makes my eye twitch. Okay, look, that was… a whole thing. A really messy, frustrating thing.

Honestly? It was the easiest decision I made through all of this. And that's saying something.

Paul… he's not exactly the most responsible person. He was all bravado and empty promises at first, talking about how we'd raise the baby together and everything would be fine. But then he'd disappear for days, or forget important things, or just generally act like a flake.

He wasn't equipped to be a father. He was barely equipped to take care of himself. And I didn't want my baby being raised by someone who couldn't even commit to showing up.
