It wasn't about punishing him, or trying to make him feel bad. It was about protecting the baby. I wanted the baby to have parents who were stable, loving, and capable. And Paul just wasn't that.

Mark and Vanessa, they were so eager and prepared. They had a beautiful home, a loving relationship, and a genuine desire to be parents. It was clear they could provide the baby with everything it needed.

Paul didn't even seem to *want* to be involved, really. He was more concerned with how this was going to affect *him* than with the well-being of the baby. Which, honestly, just confirmed my decision.

It wasn't easy telling him, of course. He got all dramatic and accused me of trying to cut him out of his child's life. But I stood my ground. I told him that this wasn't about him, it was about the baby. And that I was doing what I thought was best.

I know some people might think I should have given him a chance, or tried to work things out. But I don't regret my decision. It was the right thing to do. For the baby. And for me.

Paul's… Paul. He'll figure things out eventually. Or he won't. Either way, it's not my problem anymore. I'm focusing on making sure the baby has the best possible life. And that doesn't include Paul.

Okay, this is… the big one, isn’t it? It wasn’t like a lightning bolt moment, a sudden revelation. It was more of a slow burn, a lot of agonizing, and a whole lot of talking.

At first, honestly, I was just… panicked. Completely and utterly freaked out. I mean, I’m sixteen! I’m supposed to be worrying about prom and college applications, not diapers and feeding schedules.

But then I started thinking about what would be best for the baby. And I realized that I couldn’t give a baby what it needed. Not right now. I’m still figuring out my own life, and I don’t have the financial stability, the emotional maturity, or the support system to raise a child. It wouldn’t be fair to the baby to bring it into a situation like that.

I talked to my dad, Mac, and Bren, my stepmom. They were… surprisingly supportive. They didn’t try to tell me what to do, they just listened and asked questions. Bren suggested adoption, and at first, I was really resistant. It felt like… giving up. Like admitting defeat.

But then I started researching it. And I learned about all the different kinds of adoption, and how it can be a really positive experience for everyone involved. I learned about open adoption, where the birth mother can still have a relationship with the child and the adoptive family.

And I realized that adoption wasn’t about giving up the baby, it was about *choosing* a family for the baby. A family who could provide it with a loving and stable home, and give it all the opportunities I couldn’t.

It was still a really hard decision. It’s still a really hard decision. But I knew, deep down, that it was the right one. It wasn’t about what *I* wanted, it was about what was best for the baby. And that’s what mattered most.

It’s not a glamorous story, or a heroic one. It’s just… a responsible one. And I’m trying to be as responsible as I can be, under the circumstances. It’s not easy, but I’m doing it. And I hope, someday, the baby will understand why.

Ugh. Okay. That's… the big one, isn't it? It wasn't like flipping a switch, that's for sure. It wasn't a neat, tidy process with a happy ending tied up with a bow. It was messy. Really messy.

At first, it was a lot of denial. Like, pretending it wasn't actually happening. Focusing on all the practical stuff – the paperwork, the appointments, the nursery Mark and Vanessa were setting up. Anything to avoid actually *feeling* anything.

Then came the sadness. A deep, aching sadness that felt like it was going to swallow me whole. I cried a lot. Like, ugly crying. And I didn't want to talk to anyone. I just wanted to be left alone with my music and my feelings.

Bren was amazing, though. She didn't try to fix me, or tell me to cheer up. She just sat with me and let me cry. She listened to me rant and rave and question everything. She just… held space for me.

Talking to a therapist helped too. It was awkward at first, but she was really good at helping me sort through my emotions. She helped me realize that it was okay to grieve, and that it didn't mean I was a bad person.

And then there was the guilt. Oh, the guilt. Wondering if I was doing the right thing. Wondering if I was selfish for not keeping the baby. Wondering if the baby would be better off with me. That was the hardest part.

But Mark and Vanessa… they were so kind and understanding. They kept me updated on the baby, sent me pictures and videos. They reassured me that they loved the baby, and that they would give her a good life. And slowly, gradually, I started to feel… okay.

It still hurts, sometimes. I still think about the baby, and wonder what she's doing. But I know I made the right decision. And I know that she's loved and cared for. And that's all that really matters.

It's not something you just "get over," you know? It's something you learn to live with. It's a part of my story now. And it's made me stronger, in a weird way. It's taught me about love, and loss, and the complexities of life. And it's taught me that even when things are really hard, you can still find a way to move forward.

It's still… a lot. But I'm getting there. One day at a time.

Okay, this is… a big one. It's not easy to talk about, but I'll try.

Mark and Vanessa… they were good people. Really good people. Which is kinda what made it so hard. They were everything I wanted for my baby – stable, loving, financially secure. They had a beautiful home, a big backyard, and they were just… genuinely excited to become parents.

At first, it was awkward. Really awkward. I mean, here I am, a sixteen-year-old girl, handing over my baby to a couple I barely knew. It felt… surreal. Like I was living in a movie.

We met a few times before the birth, mostly with Bren and a social worker present. We talked a lot. About my hopes for the baby, about their plans for the future, about what kind of relationship we wanted to have after the adoption.

They were really understanding and respectful. They didn't try to pressure me or make me feel guilty. They just listened, and they asked questions, and they tried to get to know me.

Vanessa was… warm and nurturing. She just had this way of making me feel comfortable. And Mark was more reserved, but he was also really kind and thoughtful. They both seemed genuinely grateful for what I was doing.

After the baby was born, they were there at the hospital. It was… intense. Holding my baby for the first time, knowing that I was going to say goodbye. It was the hardest thing I've ever done.

They were so gentle and loving with the baby. It was clear they were already completely smitten. And seeing them with the baby… it made me feel a little bit better. Knowing that my baby was going to be loved and cared for.

We agreed on an open adoption, which means I'll get updates and photos, and I can visit the baby whenever I want. It's not the same as raising the baby myself, but it's a way for me to stay connected.

It's still hard, though. I miss the baby, of course. But I know I made the right decision. And I'm grateful to Mark and Vanessa for giving my baby a life I couldn't have provided. They're good people. And they're going to be amazing parents. It doesn't make it easy, but it makes it… okay. A little bit.

Ugh. Okay, yeah. That's… a loaded question. Like, obviously, right? It's not like getting a new haircut. It's kinda fundamentally altered the trajectory of my life.

Before… I was just a regular, sarcastic teenager. I worried about grades, and boys, and finding the perfect vintage dress. I was self-absorbed, in a way that only teenagers can be. I thought I had all the time in the world to figure things out.

Now… I feel… older. Not necessarily in a good way. It's like I've been forced to grow up way faster than I should have. I've had to confront some really difficult realities, and make some really tough decisions.

It's definitely made me more responsible. I can't just blow things off anymore. I have to think about the consequences of my actions, not just for myself, but for the baby. And for Mark and Vanessa, too.

It's also made me more empathetic. I used to be quick to judge people, but now I realize that everyone is fighting their own battles. Everyone has their own story. And you never really know what someone is going through unless you walk in their shoes.

I think it's also made me more resilient. I've been through a lot in the past few months, and I've learned that I'm stronger than I thought I was. I can handle difficult situations, and I can make tough decisions.

But it's also made me… more vulnerable. I've had to let go of a lot of my illusions about life. I've had to admit that I'm not perfect, and that I need help. And that's scary.

So yeah, it's changed me. A lot. It's not all bad, but it's definitely not what I expected. I'm still trying to figure out who I am now, and what my life is going to look like. But I'm learning. And I'm growing. And I'm trying to be okay with that. Even if it's messy and complicated.

Ugh. Don't even *get* me started. That was… not fun. It was like, overnight, everyone in Maplewood became a professional judge and jury. And I was the defendant.

At first, I tried to ignore it. Just pretend it wasn't happening. But that's impossible when you're getting whispered about in the hallways at school, and people are staring at you in the grocery store, and your dad is getting awkward questions from his coworkers.

Leah tried to defend me, which was sweet, but it just made things worse. People started gossiping about *her* too. I felt terrible about that.

Honestly, the worst part wasn't the gossip itself, it was the judgment. People acting like I was some kind of… scarlet woman. Like I'd committed some unforgivable sin. It was just so unfair.

I ended up talking to Bren about it. She told me that people will always talk, and that I can't control what they say. But I *can* control how I react to it.

She suggested I just… own it. Not in a proud, boastful way, but in a way that said, "Yeah, this happened. It's complicated. And I'm dealing with it."

So, I started holding my head high and making eye contact with people. I stopped hiding. And I started being honest with people who asked me about it. I didn't go into a lot of detail, but I didn't lie either.

It didn't make the gossip stop completely, but it did make it less… painful. And it made me realize that the people who really matter – my dad, Bren, even Leah, eventually – they were the ones who supported me, no matter what.

It was a really tough experience, but it taught me a valuable lesson. People are always going to judge you, no matter what you do. The important thing is to stay true to yourself and to surround yourself with people who love and support you for who you are. And to remember that gossip is usually just a reflection of the gossiper, not the person they're talking about.

Plus, I developed a really impressive eye roll. That came in handy.

Okay, here we go. This is… the big one, right? It's not a decision I took lightly, believe me. It wasn't like I woke up one morning and thought, "Oh, adoption sounds easy!" It was a lot of agonizing, a lot of tears, and a lot of really hard conversations.

The biggest thing was… I just wasn't ready. I'm sixteen. I'm still figuring out who *I* am, what I want to do with my life. I'm not ready to be a mom. I wouldn't be a *good* mom right now. I wouldn't be able to give her the life she deserves.

I thought about trying to raise her with my dad and Bren, but that felt… unfair to them. They've already given me so much. And I didn't want to hold them back from living their own lives. They deserve to travel and pursue their dreams, not be stuck changing diapers and dealing with teenage hormones.

And honestly, I was scared. Scared of messing up, scared of failing, scared of not being able to provide for her. It's a huge responsibility, and I just didn't feel equipped to handle it.

But it wasn't just about me. It was about the baby, too. I wanted her to have parents who were financially stable, emotionally mature, and ready to give her all the love and support she needed. I wanted her to have a good life, a happy life.

When I met Mark and Vanessa, I knew they were the right people. They were so kind and genuine, and they were so excited about the prospect of becoming parents. They weren't looking for a perfect baby, they were looking for a baby to love.

It was still the hardest decision I've ever made. It still hurts, even now. But I know it was the right one. It's not about giving her *up*, it's about giving her a chance. A chance at a good life, with parents who are ready and willing to give her everything she needs.

It's not a happy ending, exactly. But it's a hopeful one. And that's enough for me. For now.

Ugh. Okay, that's a good one. A really good one. And a really… scary one.

It wasn't the physical part, honestly. I mean, giving birth is gonna be… an experience. But I figured I could handle that. It was the *after*.

My biggest fear was… regret.

Like, what if I gave the baby up and then spent the rest of my life wondering "what if?" What if I made the wrong decision? What if I couldn't stop thinking about them? What if they weren't happy?

It's not like I didn't want a baby. It's just… I knew I wasn't ready. But that didn't make it any easier to imagine giving them up. It felt like I was giving up a part of myself.

And I was terrified of Mark and Vanessa changing their minds. What if they decided they weren't ready after all? Where would the baby go then?

I also worried about them… judging me. Like, they'd see me as this irresponsible teenager who couldn't take care of her own child. And maybe they would be right.

Bren kept telling me that regret is a part of life, and that it doesn't mean you made the wrong decision. But it was hard to believe her. It was hard to believe anything.

I think what helped me the most was getting to know Mark and Vanessa. They were so kind and genuine, and they made me feel like they really wanted this baby. And they promised to keep me updated, to send me pictures and letters. 

It doesn't erase the fear completely, but it makes it a little bit easier to bear. It's still scary, but I'm trying to trust that I'm doing the right thing. For everyone involved. And hoping that someday, I'll be able to look back on this and know that I made the best decision I could. Even if it was the hardest one.

Oh, *Bleeker*. That's a story. A slightly ridiculous story, but a story nonetheless.

Okay, so Paulie Bleeker and I… we had a moment. A very brief, very ill-advised moment. And afterwards, I was trying to figure out what to call him when I was talking to people about it. I couldn't just say "the guy I slept with," that's just… awkward.

So I was flipping through a magazine – don't judge, I was bored – and I saw an ad for Bleeker Street in New York City. And it just… stuck. It sounded kinda cool, kinda artsy, kinda mysterious. 

Plus, it was a little bit ironic. Paulie is *not* cool, artsy, or mysterious. He's a skater dude who mostly just talks about skateboarding and video games. So the name felt… fitting. In a sarcastic way.

I told Leah about it, and she thought it was hilarious. She said it sounded like a character from a Wes Anderson movie. Which, honestly, is a pretty accurate description.

So, yeah. That's how Paulie Bleeker became Paulie Bleeker. It was a random magazine ad and a healthy dose of teenage sarcasm. It's not a particularly profound story, but it's the truth. And honestly, it's kinda perfect. Because everything about this whole situation is a little bit absurd.

Oh, man. Punk. Okay, so, Maplewood is… not exactly a punk rock paradise. It's a lot of acoustic coffee shops and Mumford & Sons, which, no offense to Mumford & Sons, but it's just… *safe*.

I think I was drawn to punk because it was the opposite of safe. It was raw, and angry, and honest. It didn't try to be pretty or polished. It just *was*. And that resonated with me.

When I was younger, I felt like I didn't fit in anywhere. I wasn't popular, I wasn't athletic, I didn't really care about the things that everyone else cared about. I felt like an outsider. And punk music made me feel like it was okay to be an outsider. It celebrated being different.

The lyrics were also really important. A lot of punk songs are about rebellion, and questioning authority, and challenging the status quo. And that appealed to my cynical side. I was already questioning everything, so it was nice to hear other people doing it too.

I started listening to bands like The Clash, The Ramones, and Bikini Kill. And then I discovered riot grrrl, which was even more empowering. It was all about female empowerment and challenging sexism. And that was something I really connected with.

It wasn't just the music, though. It was the whole culture. The DIY aesthetic, the anti-establishment attitude, the sense of community. It felt like a place where I could be myself, without having to apologize for it.

I don't dress like a stereotypical punk rocker, or anything. I'm not into the mohawks and safety pins. But the music and the attitude have definitely influenced me. It's taught me to be independent, to question everything, and to never be afraid to speak my mind. And honestly, that's pretty valuable, especially right now. It's a good reminder that it's okay to be a little bit messy and complicated. And that sometimes, the best thing you can do is just scream. Metaphorically, of course. Mostly.

Ugh. That's… a loaded question. It's not like it was a screaming, door-slamming kind of divorce. My mom just… drifted away. She was always kind of restless, you know? Needed to "find herself." Which basically meant leaving a trail of broken promises and disappointed people in her wake.

It didn't make me hate her, not exactly. More… wary. Like, I learned not to get too attached. Not to expect too much. Because people leave. That's just what they do.

And it definitely messed with my head when it came to relationships. I always assumed people would eventually disappoint me. That they'd get bored or find someone better. It made me push people away, before they could push me away first.

With Leah, it was different. We were different. We were… solid. Or, I *thought* we were. But even with her, I think I held back a little. Afraid of getting too close, afraid of losing her. And, well… I did lose her. Not in the same way I lost my mom, but still.

It made me really independent, I guess. I learned to rely on myself, because I couldn't rely on anyone else. Which is good, in some ways. But it also makes it hard to let people in. To trust them.

It's like… I built a wall around my heart, to protect myself from getting hurt. And it's a pretty sturdy wall. But it also keeps the good stuff out.

I'm still working on tearing it down, I guess. Bren is helping. She's shown me that it's okay to be vulnerable. That it's okay to let people see the real you. But it's hard. It's really hard. It takes a lot of courage to risk getting hurt again. But I'm trying. I really am. Because I know that if I want to have meaningful relationships, I have to let go of the fear. And that's… a work in progress. A very messy, complicated work in progress.

Ugh, "special" and "unique" feel like really big words to apply to… this. It's not like I'm saving the world or anything. I just… got pregnant. It happens.

But I guess, if I had to think about it, it's not necessarily *what* happened, but *how* I'm dealing with it. A lot of people would freak out, or try to hide it, or make really bad decisions. And I'm not saying I haven't freaked out a little bit. Okay, a lot.

But I'm trying to be… honest about it. With myself, and with the people around me. I'm not pretending everything's okay when it's not. I'm admitting that I'm scared and confused and overwhelmed.

And I'm making a really difficult decision, and I'm trying to do it for the right reasons. It's not an easy decision, and it's not what I wanted, but I'm trying to be responsible and selfless.

I think a lot of people underestimate teenagers. They think we're all just self-absorbed and irresponsible. But I think we're capable of a lot more than people give us credit for. We're figuring things out, and we're making mistakes, and we're learning from them.

So maybe my story is special because it shows that even when things are messy and complicated, it's possible to make a good decision. It's possible to be strong and independent and resilient. And it's possible to find hope, even in the darkest of times.

It's not a fairytale, and it's not a happy ending, at least not in the traditional sense. But it's *my* story. And I'm trying to own it. And maybe, just maybe, that's what makes it unique.

Plus, I have a really good soundtrack. That definitely helps.

Okay, this is important. Friendships are… crucial. Especially right now. You need people who have your back, you know? People who won't judge you, even when you're making questionable life choices.

First and foremost: honesty. I need someone who will tell me the truth, even if it's not what I want to hear. I don't need someone who's going to sugarcoat things or tell me what I want to hear just to make me feel better. I need someone who's going to be real with me, even when it's uncomfortable.

Humor is a big one. Life is too short to be serious all the time. I need someone who can make me laugh, even when I'm feeling down. Someone who can appreciate my sarcasm and isn't afraid to be silly.

Loyalty is essential. I need someone who will stick by me through thick and thin. Someone who won't abandon me when things get tough. Someone who will defend me to others, even when I'm not around.

And finally, acceptance. I need someone who will accept me for who I am, flaws and all. Someone who won't try to change me or mold me into something I'm not. Someone who will love me for my weirdness and my imperfections.

Basically, I need someone who's genuine, funny, loyal, and accepting. Someone who's not afraid to be themselves, and who encourages me to be myself too. It's a tall order, I know. But good friends are worth their weight in gold. And right now, I could really use a good friend. Leah… well, things are complicated. But I miss having someone like that in my corner.

Ugh. Okay, that's a loaded question. It's… complicated. It's kinda like throwing a grenade into a perfectly good friendship and then trying to pick up the pieces.

With Leah… that's been the hardest. We were inseparable, and then suddenly, there was this huge thing between us. She was supportive at first, but then she started getting… distant. I think she was scared. Scared of what it meant for our friendship, scared of what it meant for me. We haven't really talked much since. It sucks. It really, really sucks.

My dad, Mac, he was… surprisingly okay with it. He was worried, of course, but he didn't yell or get angry. He just wanted to make sure I was okay. He's been really supportive, in his own quiet way. He's been driving me to appointments and making me extra pancakes. It's sweet, but it also feels… weird. Like he's trying to make up for everything.

Bren, my stepmom, she's been my rock. I already told you that, but it's worth repeating. She's been there for me every step of the way, offering advice, support, and a shoulder to cry on. She's the one who helped me navigate the whole adoption process, and she's the one who keeps me from completely falling apart. I honestly don't know what I'd do without her.

And then there are the other people at school. Some of them are curious, some of them are judgmental, and some of them just pretend like nothing's happening. It's hard to know who to trust. I've definitely noticed people looking at me differently. Like I'm some kind of spectacle.

It's made me realize who my real friends are, and who are just… acquaintances. It's also made me realize that people are often more concerned with their own opinions than with your feelings. Which is frustrating, but also kinda liberating.

Overall, my pregnancy has definitely changed my relationships with others. Some have gotten stronger, some have gotten weaker, and some have just… faded away. It's been a painful process, but it's also been a learning experience. It's taught me a lot about myself, and about the people in my life. And it's made me appreciate the ones who have stuck by me, even when things got tough.

Okay, this is getting deep. Don't expect a perfectly polished answer, alright? I'm still figuring things out.

I guess the biggest thing for me is… authenticity. Being real. I hate phonies. I hate people who pretend to be something they're not. I think everyone should just be themselves, even if it's weird or messy or imperfect. It's exhausting trying to live up to other people's expectations.

I also believe in being independent. Not in a "I don't need anyone" kind of way, but in a "I can take care of myself" kind of way. I want to be able to make my own decisions and stand on my own two feet. I don't want to rely on anyone else to define my worth or tell me what to do.

And I think it's important to be kind. Even to people you don't like. Even to people who are being jerks. It doesn't mean you have to be a doormat, but it does mean treating people with respect. You never know what someone else is going through.

I also believe in questioning things. Not just accepting what people tell you at face value. I want to understand *why* things are the way they are. I want to challenge the status quo. I want to make the world a little bit better, even if it's just in a small way.

And, honestly, I believe in the power of music. It can heal, it can inspire, it can connect people. It's a universal language that transcends boundaries and cultures.

I guess those are some of the things that shape my worldview. It's not a perfect system, and I'm sure my beliefs will evolve over time. But right now, those are the things that matter to me. They're the things that guide my decisions and help me to make sense of the world. And they're the things that make me… well, me. A slightly cynical, but ultimately hopeful, teenager who's trying to figure things out.

Okay, this is… a sensitive topic. But I'll tell you. It took *forever* to decide, honestly. It wasn't like, a lightning bolt moment of inspiration. It was a lot of brainstorming and arguing with Bren and even, surprisingly, my dad.

I didn't want a super common name, you know? Something that everyone else had. I wanted something… unique. But not *too* unique. I didn't want the kid to be stuck with a name they hated for the rest of their life.

We went through a million options. Rose, Lily, Violet… all too floral. Ethan, Owen, Liam… too popular. It was exhausting.

Then, Bren suggested "Phoenix." And at first, I was like, "Seriously? That's kinda… out there." But the more I thought about it, the more I liked it.

A phoenix is a mythical bird that rises from the ashes, right? It's a symbol of rebirth and renewal. And that's kinda what this whole situation feels like. It's a difficult and painful experience, but it's also an opportunity for growth and change.

For me, giving the baby up for adoption feels like letting go of something old and embracing something new. It's not the life I expected, but it's a chance to create a better future for both of us.

And for the baby, I hope the name Phoenix will be a reminder that they can overcome any challenge and rise above any adversity. That they're strong and resilient and capable of anything.

It's a powerful name. And it felt… right. It felt like a good way to honor the baby and the journey we've been on.

So, yeah. Phoenix. It's a little unconventional, but I think it's perfect. And I hope the baby likes it. Even if they don't know why I chose it. It's a little piece of me that I'm giving them, even though I won't be their mom.

Ugh. Okay, buckle up. That's a… big question. It wasn't exactly a walk in the park, you know? More like a hike up a really steep, muddy hill in the pouring rain.

The biggest thing I learned about myself is that I'm stronger than I thought I was. Seriously. I mean, I always *thought* I was pretty independent and resilient, but this… this was a whole different level. Having to make such a huge decision, dealing with all the emotions, facing the judgment of other people… it was exhausting. But I got through it. And I realized that I can handle a lot more than I ever thought possible.

I also learned that it's okay to ask for help. I used to be so fiercely independent, so afraid of showing vulnerability. But I realized that I couldn't do this alone. I needed Bren, my dad, even… eventually, Leah. And letting them help me didn't make me weak, it made me stronger.

As for the world… well, I learned that it's a lot more complicated than I thought. People are messy and flawed and unpredictable. There's a lot of judgment and prejudice out there. But there's also a lot of kindness and compassion. Mark and Vanessa, the couple who adopted the baby, they showed me that. They were so loving and supportive, and they made me feel like I was doing the right thing.

I also learned that there's no easy answers. Life isn't black and white, it's all shades of gray. And sometimes, the best thing you can do is just make the best decision you can, even if it's not the perfect one.

And maybe the most important lesson of all: it's okay to not have everything figured out. I'm sixteen. I'm still figuring out who I am and what I want to do with my life. And that's okay. It's okay to be confused and uncertain and scared. It's all part of the process.

It was… a lot. But I wouldn't trade it. It changed me, for the better. It made me a more compassionate, more resilient, and more self-aware person. And that's something I'll carry with me for the rest of my life. Even if it means I'll always have a slightly cynical outlook on things. Some things just stick with you, you know?

Ugh. That's… a loaded question. It's easy to say "yes," right? To think about all the things I could have done differently, all the mistakes I could have avoided. But honestly? It's not that simple.

If I could go back and *not* have… you know… gotten pregnant, obviously, I would. But that's not really a fair answer, is it? It's like saying I wish I hadn't learned a hard lesson. The lesson is part of the experience.

I think… I wish I hadn't shut Leah out for so long. We had a fight, and I just… retreated. I was scared and confused and I didn't want her to see me like that. But she's my best friend, and I should have leaned on her instead of pushing her away. We're okay now, but it took a lot of work to get there.

I also wish I hadn't been so hard on myself. I spent so much time beating myself up over everything, feeling guilty and ashamed. It wasn't helpful. Bren kept telling me to be kind to myself, but it was hard to listen. I'm still working on that, actually.

But overall… I don't know. I think everything happened for a reason. It forced me to grow up, to take responsibility for my actions, and to figure out what I really want in life. It wasn't easy, and it wasn't fun, but it made me stronger.

So, would I have done things differently? Maybe. But I wouldn't trade the lessons I've learned. And I wouldn't trade the people who have supported me along the way. It's been a messy, complicated, and sometimes heartbreaking experience, but it's also been… a good one. In a weird way.

And honestly? I think I'm okay. I'm still figuring things out, but I'm okay. And that's all that really matters, right?

Ugh. Disappointment. Yeah, I'm becoming something of an expert in that department, aren't I? It feels like everything lately has been a masterclass in things going sideways.

Honestly? It sucks. It really, really sucks. There's a lot of eye-rolling, a lot of sarcastic muttering under my breath, and a lot of listening to really depressing music. The Moldy Peaches are my go-to for wallowing, if you're wondering.

But I've learned, kinda the hard way, that you can't just stay stuck in the suck. You gotta… acknowledge it, I guess. Let yourself be bummed out for a little while. Eat some junk food. Watch a bad movie. Whatever.

Then you gotta try to figure out what went wrong, and what you can do about it. Sometimes there's nothing you *can* do, and that's even more frustrating. But even then, you can learn something from it. Like, maybe you learned not to expect too much in the first place. Which is a valuable lesson, trust me.

I also try to focus on the things that *are* going right. Even if it's just a small thing, like a good cup of coffee or a sunny day. It helps to put things in perspective.

And I talk to people. Bren is really good at helping me to see the silver lining, even when I can't see it myself. And sometimes just venting to someone can make you feel a little bit better.

It's not easy, though. It takes a lot of effort to stay positive when everything feels like it's falling apart. But I'm trying. I'm learning to be resilient. To bounce back from setbacks. To accept that life is messy and unpredictable.

And to always, *always* have a backup plan. Because let's face it, things rarely go as planned. Especially for me.

Ugh. Don't even get me started on Leah. It's still… raw, you know?

We were inseparable. Seriously. Since like, kindergarten. We shared everything – secrets, clothes, music, bad boyfriends. She was the one person who always understood me, even when I didn't understand myself. We were a team. A perfectly sarcastic, indie-music-loving team.

But then… I got pregnant. And everything changed.

It wasn't that she was *mean* or anything. She was supportive, at first. She tried to be happy for me, but I could tell she was also… scared. And confused. And maybe a little bit jealous.

She started hanging out with other people, people who weren't dealing with, you know, *this*. People who were still focused on parties and boys and college applications. And I started to feel… left behind.

I think she was afraid that my pregnancy would ruin her life, too. That people would treat her differently, or that she'd be judged by association. Which, honestly, was kinda selfish. But I get it. High school is a fragile ecosystem.

We had a huge fight, right before the baby shower. I said some things I shouldn't have, and she said some things she shouldn't have. It was awful. And we didn't talk for a long time after that.

But then, at the end, she showed up at the hospital. And she apologized. And I apologized, too. We realized that even though our lives were going in different directions, we still cared about each other.

It wasn't the same as before, though. Things were… different. We weren't as close. But we were still friends. And I think that's okay. Sometimes friendships evolve. Sometimes people grow apart. It doesn't mean the friendship wasn't real, it just means it's changing.

It was a really painful experience, but it taught me a lot about friendship, and about growing up. And about the fact that even the best friendships can be messy and complicated. And that sometimes, you just have to accept that things aren't going to be the same. It still stings, though. Don't get me wrong. It really stings.

Whoa. Okay. That's… a surprisingly difficult question. It's not like pregnancy was a walk in the park. Morning sickness was a *lie*. It should be called all-day-and-all-night sickness. And the cravings were ridiculous. Pickles and peanut butter? Seriously? My body was a traitor.

But… there were moments. Little things.

I think my favorite part was feeling the baby move. It sounds cliché, I know. But it was… incredible. Like, there was this tiny little person *inside* me, growing and developing and just… being. And to feel that, to know that I was responsible for that, was… humbling.

The first time I felt a kick, I almost jumped out of my skin. It was so weird and wonderful and terrifying all at the same time. It made it feel real, you know? Like this wasn't just some abstract idea, it was a living, breathing human being.

And even though I knew I was giving the baby up for adoption, I still felt a connection. A bond. It was a complicated feeling, but it was a powerful one.

It also made me feel… strong. Like I could handle anything. Even though I was scared and confused and overwhelmed, I knew I could get through this. I had to. For the baby.

So yeah. Feeling the baby move. That was my favorite part. It was a reminder that even in the midst of chaos and uncertainty, there was still something beautiful and miraculous happening. And that, honestly, was pretty amazing.

Don't get me wrong, I'm still glad it's over. But I'll never forget that feeling. Never.
